entry.title: AllanPoe, All-in-one Graph-based Indexing for Hybrid Search on GPUs
entry.content:
Overview

   This paper presents Allan Poe, a groundbreaking unified graph index that fundamentally transforms hybrid search by integrating four retrieval paths—dense vector, sparse vector, full-text, and knowledge graph—within a single GPU-accelerated framework. The system addresses the critical limitations of existing paradigms through an innovative design featuring isolated heterogeneous edge storage and dynamic path fusion, achieving unprecedented performance in accuracy, efficiency, and flexibility simultaneously.

Details

   Allan Poe introduces a Unified Semantic Metric Space (USMS) that mathematically formalizes the integration of diverse retrieval methods. The core innovation lies in its isolated heterogeneous edge storage mechanism, which maintains distinct edge types while unifying them within one cohesive graph structure, enabling seamless combination of retrieval paths without reconstruction overhead.

Analysis

   The paper begins by diagnosing fundamental limitations in current retrieval ecosystems through comprehensive experimental analysis:

   THE TRILEMMA OF EXISTING PARADIGMS:

  • Single-path Retrieval (HNSW, BM25, SPLADE): Achieves high efficiency but suffers from inherent semantic gaps, with vector similarity failing to guarantee end-to-end document relevance (only ~50% accuracy in complex queries).
  • Multi-path Retrieval (Infinity, Milvus): Provides flexibility through separate-then-fuse strategies but incurs massive storage overhead (up to 21× larger indexes) and accuracy degradation due to suboptimal result fusion.
  • Fusion Retrieval (IVF-Fusion, DS-ANN): Improves accuracy over single-path methods but lacks flexibility, typically limited to two-path combinations and requiring complete reconstruction for weight changes.

   KEY MOTIVATIONAL FINDINGS:

  • Experiments on NaturalQuestions and 2WikiMultiHopQA reveal that while vector similarity accuracy reaches 99%, end-to-end accuracy remains substantially lower (around 50-70%), exposing the semantic gap limitation.
  • Hybrid search demonstrates clear advantages, but no single configuration dominates all scenarios—optimal path combinations vary significantly across datasets and query types.
  • The analysis concludes that an ideal solution must simultaneously deliver: Flexibility (arbitrary path/weight combinations), Accuracy (complementary multi-path information), and Efficiency (low-latency heterogeneous computation).

Design

Unified Graph Architecture

   Allan Poe’s hybrid index architecture integrates four retrieval paradigms through a carefully designed graph structure with three distinct edge types, each serving specific functional purposes while maintaining isolation for flexibility.
   FORMAL FRAMEWORK - USMS:
   The Unified Semantic Metric Space is defined as a tuple H={D,F,Mw}H=\{D,F,M_{\mathbf{w}}\}H={D,F,Mw​} where:

  • DDD: Document corpus
  • FFF: Feature extractors {fdense,fsparse,ffull,fkg}\{f_{\text{dense}},f_{\text{sparse}},f_{\text{full}},f_{\text{kg}}\}{fdense​,fsparse​,ffull​,fkg​}
  • MwM_{\mathbf{w}}Mw​: Composite similarity metric Mw(q,d)=∑i∈{d,s,f,k}wi⋅simi(q,d)M_{\mathbf{w}}(q,d)=\sum_{i\in\{d,s,f,k\}}\mathbf{w}_i\cdot sim_i(q,d)Mw​(q,d)=∑i∈{d,s,f,k}​wi​⋅simi​(q,d)

Hybrid Vector Representation and Theoretical Foundation

   The system employs vector fusion that concatenates dense, sparse, and full-text representations: fconcat(d)=[fdense(d),fsparse(d),ffull(d)]f_{\text{concat}}(d)=[f_{\text{dense}}(d),f_{\text{sparse}}(d),f_{\text{full}}(d)]fconcat​(d)=[fdense​(d),fsparse​(d),ffull​(d)].

   THEOREM 1. Given the RNG-based index constructed from fused vectors fconcat(d)f_{\text{concat}}(d)fconcat​(d) in USMS, for any weight vector w=[wd,ws,wf]∈R3\mathbf{w}=[\mathbf{w}_{d},\mathbf{w}_{s},\mathbf{w}_{f}]\in\mathbb{R}^{3}w=[wd​,ws​,wf​]∈R3, the nearest neighbors can always be retrieved from the index without reconstruction.

   Proof Sketch: Construct weighted query vector fconcat(q)=[wd∗fdense(q),ws∗fsparse(q),wf∗ffull(q)]f_{\text{concat}}(q)=[\mathbf{w}_{d}*f_{\text{dense}}(q),\mathbf{w}_{s}*f_{\text{sparse}}(q),\mathbf{w}_{f}*f_{\text{full}}(q)]fconcat​(q)=[wd​∗fdense​(q),ws​∗fsparse​(q),wf​∗ffull​(q)]. The inner product expansion directly corresponds to the weighted combination of individual similarities, guaranteeing retrieval correctness for arbitrary weights.

Keyword Edges Supplement

   To preserve exact keyword matching capabilities compromised by vector fusion, Allan Poe introduces a dual-assessment mechanism during graph pruning. The algorithm selectively preserves pruned edges as dedicated keyword edges based on keyword overlap conditions:

   For node AAA with pruned neighbor XXX, if ∄Y∈neighbors(A)\nexists Y \in \text{neighbors}(A)∄Y∈neighbors(A) such that K(A)∩K(X)⊆K(Y)K(A) \cap K(X) \subseteq K(Y)K(A)∩K(X)⊆K(Y), then XXX is recycled as a keyword edge. This ensures navigation paths for important keyword relationships remain accessible.

Logical Edges Augmentation

   Knowledge graph integration addresses two critical semantic search limitations:

  1. Semantically similar but logically unrelated results
  2. Multi-hop reasoning challenges

   Logical edges are established through entity-document mapping: for node XXX with entity set V(X)V(X)V(X), logical edges comprise triplets {(s,r,t)∣s∈V(X),r∈R,t∈V∖V(X)}\{(s,r,t)|s \in V(X), r \in R, t \in V\setminus V(X)\}{(s,r,t)∣s∈V(X),r∈R,t∈V∖V(X)} from knowledge graph G(V,R)G(V,R)G(V,R).

GPU-Accelerated Index Construction

   The four-stage construction pipeline leverages massive GPU parallelism for efficient hybrid index building:

   PROCEDURE 1: Initial k-NN Graph Construction

  • Employs NN-Descent algorithm with warp-level hybrid distance computation
  • Optimized dense vector processing using CUDA vectorized instructions
  • Sparse vector similarity transformed into parallel set intersection with shared memory caching

   PROCEDURE 2: RNG-IP Joint Pruning

  • Combines Relative Neighborhood Graph pruning with Inner Product pruning
  • Maintains search quality while reducing index complexity
  • Preserves aligned degree structure for GPU-friendly parallel processing

   PROCEDURE 3: Keyword-aware Neighbor Recycling

  • Recycles pruned edges as keyword edges based on keyword overlap conditions
  • Leverages computations from previous procedures to minimize overhead
  • Uses hash maps in GPU shared memory for efficient keyword lookups

   PROCEDURE 4: Logical Edge Augmentation

  • Maps knowledge graph entities to document nodes
  • Establishes logical connections between related documents
  • Optional component trading accuracy improvements against construction cost

Flexible Query Processing Framework

   The query processing engine supports dynamic path combinations through three sophisticated mechanisms:

   BASE SEMANTIC EDGES QUERY:

  • Dynamically fuses query vectors: fconcat(q,wd,ws,wf)=[wd∗fdense(q),ws∗fsparse(q),wf∗ffull(q)]f_{\text{concat}}(q,\mathbf{w}_{d},\mathbf{w}_{s},\mathbf{w}_{f})=[\mathbf{w}_{d}*f_{\text{dense}}(q),\mathbf{w}_{s}*f_{\text{sparse}}(q),\mathbf{w}_{f}*f_{\text{full}}(q)]fconcat​(q,wd​,ws​,wf​)=[wd​∗fdense​(q),ws​∗fsparse​(q),wf​∗ffull​(q)]
  • Single-path retrieval achieved by setting corresponding weight to 1 and others to 0
  • Optimized entry point selection from low-norm nodes

   DYNAMIC KEYWORD EDGE LOADING:

  • Implements just-in-time loading of keyword edges only for nodes sharing keywords with query
  • Employs twin candidate pool approach to maintain accuracy while filtering results
  • Ensures keyword constraints without compromising traversal pathways

   KNOWLEDGE GRAPH AUGMENTATION:

  • Uses entity-based entry point selection via entity-node mapping
  • Dynamically loads logical edges for nodes within xxx hops of query entities
  • Incorporates logical similarity through hop-distance-based reward mechanisms
  • Enables fine-grained entity-document joint traversal for complex queries

References

  • [1] LI Z, LI Y, ZHU Y, 等. All-in-one Graph-based Indexing for Hybrid Search on GPUs[EB/OL]. (2025). https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.00855.

entry.title: DDFH, Dynamically Detect and Fix Hardness for Efficient ANNS
entry.content:
Overview

   In this paper, we first propose Escape Hardness, a metric to evaluate the quality of graph structure around the query. And we propose Neighboring Graph Defects Fixing(NGFix) to imporve graph connectivity in regions where queries are densly distributed.

Details

   In this paper, we let X={x1,x2,...,xn}⊆RdX=\left \{ x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n} \right \} \subseteq R^{d}X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​}⊆Rd be a finite set of nnn vectors in a d-dimensional space. Let δ(⋅,⋅)\delta (\cdot ,\cdot )δ(⋅,⋅) denote the distance between two points and Ni,qN_{i,q}Ni,q​ denote the i-th NN of qqq.
   WE use a directed graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) to represent a graph index, where VVV is the set of vertices, and each vector in XXX corresponds to a vertex in VVV. The set EEE represents the edges, where each edge (u,v)∈E(u,v) \in E(u,v)∈E indicates a proximity relationship between vectices uuu and vvv. We let neighbors (G,v)(G,v)(G,v) denote the set of neighbors of vertex vvv in graph GGG. Also, we typically use Greedy Search for ANNS on graph indexes. The details of algorithm are presented in Algorithm 1.

Analysis

   To provide theoretical support, we first explore the relationship between the graph stucture and accuracy for a given query. Following previous studies, we divide the search into two phases:(1) searching from the entry point to the vicinity of the query, and (2) searching within the vicinity of the query. Greedy Search can easily reach the second pahse, but it often ends up retrieving only a subset of the nearest neighbors due to the lack of effective edges in the graph index. Therefore, we first focus on the case where the entry point is close to the query. Subsequently, since Greedy Search only explores points closest to the query, we only need to consider the graph structure in the small region around the query. To better describe the area around the query, we first define the graph structure around a query, which consists of the query’s NNs and the edges associated with them:
   DEFINITION 1.(S-Neighboring Graph with query(NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​)). Consider a directed graph index G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and a query qqq, and define VS,q={N1,q,N2,q,...,NS,q}V_{S,q}= \left \{ N_{1,q},N_{2,q}, ..., N_{S,q} \right \}VS,q​={N1,q​,N2,q​,...,NS,q​}. Then NGS,q=(VS,q,ES,q)NG_{S,q}=(V_{S,q},E_{S,q})NGS,q​=(VS,q​,ES,q​) is the subgraph induced in GGG by VS,qV_{S,q}VS,q​, where ES,qE_{S,q}ES,q​ is the edge set of the subgraph.

   We then examine the relationship between NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ and query accuracy from two perspectives: (1) A high-quality NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ guarantees high query accuracy; (2) A low-quality NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ can easily lead to significant drop in accuracy. For the first perspective, we introduce the following theorem to show that if base points uuu and vvv are connected in NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​, then Greedy Search starting from uuu is guranteed to reach vvv when the search list list size L≥SL \ge SL≥S. All the proof in this paper and more details can be found in Appendix B.
   THEOREM 1. For a directed graph index G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and query qqq. If Ni,qN_{i,q}Ni,q​ can reach Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ in NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ (1≤i,j≤S)(1 \le i, j \le S)(1≤i,j≤S). The algorithm 1 will always visit Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ when query = q, ep=Ni,qep=N_{i,q}ep=Ni,q​ and L≥SL \ge SL≥S. (That’s: a NFS,qNF_{S,q}NFS,q​ with string connectivity can gurantee search accuracy. Furthermore, for the second perspective, our experiments show that poor connectivity in the NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ significantly degrades search accuracy.)
   Reason for Using Historical Queries. Although the graph structure around the query impacts the query accuracy, the following theorem we propose demonstrates that for any query and SSS, ensuring strong connectivity in NSS,qNS_{S,q}NSS,q​ is impractical:
   THEOREM 2. Given a base dat set XXX and the DG constructed from the points in $X. If any edge of DG is removed, there exists a query qqq such that NG2,qNG_{2,q}NG2,q​ contains only two isolated nodes.
   Since DG becomes a complete graph in high-dimensioanl spaces, ensuring strong connectivity for the NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ of all queries is impractical in the real world. Therefore, the method we prose below leverages the historical queries to achieve string connectivity for the NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ in regions where queries are densly distributed.

Design

   The analysis in above section can be summarized as follows:

  1. the difficulty of a query is largely influenced by the quality of the graph structure around it, and the difficulty varies significantly across queries. So we first propose EH to measure the quality of the graph structure around a query in this section
  2. We need to utilize historical queries to enhance graph connectivity in regions where queries are densely distributed. So we propose NGFix, using EH in combination with historical queries to guide us in fixing the defective areas of the graph.
  3. There still exist a few qeries for which the search stops in the first phase and cannot reach their vicinity, so we propose RFix to enhance the navigability of some points.

   Figure 5 illustrates the overview of NGFix. We beginby constructing a base graph(Fig. 5a). For each query qqq, we compute its exact KNN(Fig. 5b) and then calculate EH for qqq(Fig. 5c). Finally, we add additional edges in the vicinity of qqq to fix the defective regions of the graph(Fig. 5d).

Preprocess

   First, we need to construct any type of graph index as a base graph, such as HNSW, NSG, etc. Then, for each query, we need to compute its exact kNN. We have the following methods for calculating kNN:

  • Collect the queries and process them after accumulating a certain amount, and then transform the computation of exact kNN into matrix multiplication, and accelerate it using matrix multiplication optimization.
  • Utilize the previously constructued graph index to perform Greedy Search, but increases the search list size to improve accuracy of approximate kNN. This method is fater then brute-force computation, but may slightly affect the ground truth quality of the queries.

Escape Hardness

   To better measure the quality of the graph structure around a query, we introduce Escape Hardness. It focuses on measuring the difficulty of reaching one point from another around the query usig Greedy Search.
   DEFINITION 2.(EH). Given a directed graph index G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and a query qqq, let P(u,v,G)P(u,v,G)P(u,v,G) denotes the set of all paths from vertex uuu to vvv in the graph GGG and Fu,qF_{u,q}Fu,q​ denote the point uuu is the Eu,qE_{u,q}Eu,q​ -th NN of qqq, the Escape Hardnedd of query qqq from vertex uuu to vertex vvv is defined as:

EH(u,v,q,G)=min⁡p∈P(u,p,G)max⁡x∈pFx,qEH(u, v, q, G) = \min_{p \in P(u, p, G)} \max_{x \in p} F_{x, q}EH(u,v,q,G)=p∈P(u,p,G)min​x∈pmax​Fx,q​

   and we define the Escape Hardness Matrix H∈{1,2,...,∣x∣}Nq×NqH \in \left \{ 1,2,..., |x| \right \}^{N_{q} \times N_{q}}H∈{1,2,...,∣x∣}Nq​×Nq​, where Hi,j=EH(Ni,q,Nj,q,q,G)H_{i,j} = EH(N_{i,q}, N_{j,q}, q, G)Hi,j​=EH(Ni,q​,Nj,q​,q,G) and NqN_{q}Nq​ represents the number of nearest neighbors considered for query qqq.
   The definition of EH(u,v,q,G)EH(u,v,q,G)EH(u,v,q,G) illustrates the hardness of searching from a point uuu to reach vvv using Greedy SEarch. The validality of EHEHEH is primary supported by the following corollary of Theorem 1. EH establishes an upper bound on the search list size required to successfully reach a point from another point around the query.
   COROLLARY 1. For a directed graph index G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and a query qqq, the Algorithm 1 will always visit Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ when query=q,ep=Ni,q,andL≥EH(Ni,q,Nj,q,q,G)query=q, ep=N_{i,q}, and L \ge EH(N_{i,q},N_{j,q}, q, G)query=q,ep=Ni,q​,andL≥EH(Ni,q​,Nj,q​,q,G).
   To compute EH, we first present THEOREM 3: If points Ni,qN_{i,q}Ni,q​ and Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ satsify the condition that Ni,qN_{i,q}Ni,q​ cannont reach Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ in NGS−1,qNG_{S-1,q}NGS−1,q​ but can reach Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ in NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​, then EH(Ni,q,Nj,q,q,G)=SEH(N_{i,q}, N_{j,q}, q, G) = SEH(Ni,q​,Nj,q​,q,G)=S and Hi,j=SH_{i,j} = SHi,j​=S
   Due to THEOREM 3, when computating EH, we start with S=1S=1S=1 and incrementally consider NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​ in ascending order of SSS. For the subgraph NGS−1,qNG_{S-1,q}NGS−1,q​, we add the point NS,qN_{S,q}NS,q​ and its associated edges to construct NGS,qNG_{S,q}NGS,q​. If the connectivity from points Ni,qN{i,q}Ni,q to Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ changes after adding point NS,qN_{S,q}NS,q​, then Hi,j=SH_{i,j}=SHi,j​=S. The connectivity updates after each addition are computed using a modifies Floyd-WArshall algorithm. The calculation of EH is finished when Ni,qN_{i,q}Ni,q​ and Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ are reachable from each other for any 1≤i,j≤Nq1 \le i,j \le N_{q}1≤i,j≤Nq​. We denote the value of SSS at the time the computation is completed as MaxSMaxSMaxS, also meaning that the subgraph at this point is NGMaxS,qNG_{MaxS,q}NGMaxS,q​. However, based on the previous analysis, the connectivity of the graph around hard queries tends to be poor, often resluting in a significant large value if MaxSMaxSMaxS. Therefore, to efficiently compute EHEHEH, we limit MaxSMaxSMaxS to a constant multiple of NqN_{q}Nq​ (e.g., MaxS \le 5N_{q}). If Ni,qN_{i,q}Ni,q​ and Nj,qN_{j,q}Nj,q​ are still not connected at this point, we consider Hi,jH_{i,j}Hi,j​ tobe infinite.
   The details of the algorithm are shown in Algorithm 2. To accelerate the computarion, we directly set MaxSMaxSMaxS to 5Nq5N_{q}5Nq​ and precesses NGMaxS,qNG_{MaxS,q}NGMaxS,q​ before calculation.

Neighboring Graph Defects Fixing

   Using Escape Hardness to guide graph construction. Since Escape Hardness describe the hardness of Greedy Search traversing from one point to another around the query, our key idea is to ensure that the Escape Hardness between all point pairs in the small region surrounding each historical query is low(i.e., fix the defects in the graph). We first define a threshold Kh(Kh≥Nq)K_{h}(K_{h} \ge N_{q})Kh​(Kh​≥Nq​) to determine whether it is hard to travel from one point to another.
   DEFINITION 3. (KhK_{h}Kh​ -reachable). Given a directed graph index G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and a query qqq, if point uuu and point vvv satisfy EH(u,v,q,G)≤KhEH(u,v,q,G) \le K_{h}EH(u,v,q,G)≤Kh​, we consider uuu to be KhK_{h}Kh​ -reachable to vvv. Then we define the KhK_{h}Kh​ -reachable matrix T∈{0,1}Nq×NqT \in \left \{ 0,1\right \}^{N_{q} \times N_{q}}T∈{0,1}Nq​×Nq​ as Ti,j={1if Hi,j≤Kh0if Hi,j>KhT_{i,j} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } H_{i,j} \leq K_h \\ 0 & \text{if } H_{i,j} > K_h \end{cases}Ti,j​={10​if Hi,j​≤Kh​if Hi,j​>Kh​​
   According to Corollary 1, ensuring low Ecape HArdness between point pairs gurantees the accuracy of Greedy Search. Therefore, our next step is to develop method to fix the defects in the graph.
   After considering both the graph’s neighborhood properties and the number of additional edges, we choose to use the idea of the minimum spanning tree(MST), and MST is a subset of RNG. We consider each edge (Ni,q,Nj,q)(N_{i,q}, N_{j,q})(Ni,q​,Nj,q​) in increasing order of weight δ(Ni,q,Nj,q)\delta(N_{i,q}, N_{j,q})δ(Ni,q​,Nj,q​). If Ti,j=0T_{i,j} = 0Ti,j​=0, we add that edge to the graph. Additionally, adding a new edge will make some points KhK_{h}Kh​ -reachable to others, so we update TTT after each edge is added to the graph. This process is repeated until all elelements of TTT are equal to 1. The details of the algorithm are shown in Algorithm 3.

   Analysis. THEOREM 4. Given a query qqq, Algorithm 3 will add at most 2(Nq−1)2(N_{q}-1)2(Nq​−1) extra directed edges.

Reachability Fixing

   In the following, we discuss how to address sitations where the search terminates far from the query. We propose Reachability Fixing(RFix). The key idea of Rfix is to expand the pruning candidate set of the ANN1,qANN_{1,q}ANN1,q​ 's neighbors for searches that fail to reach the vicinity of the historical query, where the ANN1,qANN_{1,q}ANN1,q​ refers to the approximate nearest neighbor returned by the Greedy Search.
   The details are shown in Algoritm 4 and the steps are as follows: (1) Select the centroid of the base data as the entry point. For a historical query, it is difficult to gurantee that Greedy Search starting from every entry point wil reach the vicinity of the query. Therefore, we fix the entry point as the centroid, which also help reduce the length of the search path. (2) Expand the candidate neighbor set of ANN1,qANN_{1,q}ANN1,q​. First, we perform a Greedy Search to retrieve the ANN1,qANN_{1,q}ANN1,q​ to the historical query(line 2). If the search did not reach the vicinity of the query(line 3), we expand the candidate neighbors of ANN1,qANN_{1,q}ANN1,q​. First, we collect all points uuu that satisfy δ(u,q)<δ(ANN1,q,q)\delta(u,q) \lt \delta(ANN_{1,q},q)δ(u,q)<δ(ANN1,q​,q) as the extended candiate set(line 4). Then, we apply the RNG pruning strategy to this set to ensure that the angle between any two connected edges is greater than 60°(line 5-9), which disperses the edges in different directions and enhances the navigational performance of the graph. Since these edges provide important paths to reach the query, their EH is set to infinity(line 9). Finally, we add these edges to the graph using the same EH pruning strategy as in NGFix(line 10). For the computation of extended candidate neighbor set(line 4), brute-force searching would be time-consuming. Therefore, we use a greedy search with a larger search list size and check all the points visited during the search process to replace the brute-force search.
   Since a single RFix does not gurantee the search will reach the vicinity of the query, we repeat the RFix until the search can reach the query’s vicinity or the degree limit for that points is reached. As only a small number of historical queries encounter issues where the search cannot reach the query’s vicinity, RFix does not significantly increase the graph construction time or index size. After applying both NGFix and RFix, we have the following theorem.
   THEOREM 5. Let T denote the set of historical queries. Without pruning the edges, our method ensures that when q∈Tq \in Tq∈T and k≤Nqk \le N_{q}k≤Nq​, the accuracy of GreedySearch(G,q,k,centroid,Kh)GreedySearch(G, q, k, centroid, K_{h})GreedySearch(G,q,k,centroid,Kh​) is 100%.(Algorithm 1).

Index Maintenence

   We have inreoduce how to dynamically update the graph structure based on queries. However, dynamic addition and deletion of base data is also critical issue in real-world applications. Next, we discuss how the graph index handles insertion and deletion operations on the base data.
   Insertion. To support dynamic insertion, we require a base graph structure that allows incemental updates(e.g., HNSW). When a new data point arrives, it is first inserted into the base graph following its insertion algorithm. Howerver, after a large number of insertions, the extra edges linked by NGFix and RFix may have limited impact on newly inserted points, which leads to a degratin in search performance. To address this issue, we propose a partital rebuilding strategy with the following steps: (1) For each node, randomly remove a proportion rrr (e.g., 20%) of its extra outgoing edges(will not remove the edge of base graph), and reset the EH values of the remaining edges to zero. This is because the previouslt estimiated hardness may no longer reflect the current graph structure accurately. (2) Randomly select r∣T∣r|T|r∣T∣ hsitorical queries from the set of historicaly queries TTT and apply BGFix and RFix on the updated graph. A smaller rrr leads to faster reconstruction but may result in lower graph quality.
   Deletion. The most commonly used method for deleting points is lazy deletion, where the deleted points are retained for navigation during the search process but are excluded from the final result set. This method is simple and efficient. Howerver, when a large nnumber of points are added, the deleted points in the graph can significantly prolong the search paths, resulting in degraded search performance. To address this issue, we need to completely remove the point and its associated edges from the graph. This introduces two main challenges: (1) We need to identify and remove all incoming edges to the deleted point. A trivial solution is to store all incoming edges for each point in memory, but this significantly increases memory consumption. (2) The deletion of the point may damage the structure aroud it, resulting in reduced connectivity in its neighborhood.
   For the first challenge, we adopt a lazy deletion strategy for a small number of deletions. Once the number of deleted points exceeds a certain threshold(e.g., 1% of the base data), we perform a full traversal of the graph index to remove all deleted points along with their incoming edges. For the second challenge, recall that NGFix is designed to fix degective graph structures in the vicinity of queries. Thus, we can simply treat the deleted points as a query and execute NGFix. The connectivity degradation rsulting from the point deletion will be mitigated by applying NGFix.

References

  • Source Code on Github
  • HUA Z, MO Q, YAO Z, 等. Dynamically Detect and Fix Hardness for Efficient Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search[EB/OL]. (2025). https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.22316.

entry.title: DSANN, Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search of Large Scale Vectors on Distributed Storage
entry.content:
Overview

   In this paper, we present a new graph-cluster hybrid indexing and search system which supports Distributed Storage Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search, called DSANN. DSANN can effectively index, store, search billion-scale vector database in distributed storage and gurantee the high availability of of index service. DSANN employs the concurrent index construction method to significantly reduces the complexity of index building. Then DSANN applies Point Aggregation Graph to leverage the structural information of graph to aggregate similar vectors, optimiing storage efficiency and improving query throughput via asynchronous I/O in distributed storage.

Details

DSANN Framework

Motivation

   From our perspective, we can improve the ANNS performance of distributed storage scenarios by cmobinding the advantages of graph-based and cluster-based ANNS methods. Graph-based trversal makes asynchronous I/O and computation possible and partition exploration is well adapted to huge vector retrival because of large fan-out. In summary, we aim to design a new ANNS index with high performance from the following aspects. (1) making I/O and computation decouple and balance, (2) supporting huge vector retrieval, (2)working on distributed-stirage scenarios, (4) employing numerous cost-effective machines for parallel index construction. Point(1) can be achieved by the traversal of graph while fecthing vectors from distributed storage via network I/O. For point(2)-(3), the idea of clustering is similar to compression and partition exploration is well-adapted to huge vector retrieval. Regarding Point(4), we can distribute the data across multiple machines to construct localized proximity graphs, followed by subsequent merging. Below we propose a new graph-based structure called Point Aggregation Graph, which aggregates multiple close vectors into a vertex of the proximity graph.

Overview

   The overall pipeline of Point Aggregation Graph(PAG) construction is illustrated in Figure 2. DASNN samples a small portion(10-25%) of data as aggregation points of the concurrent construction of the proximity graph. The rest data points called residual points are aggregated to the nearest aggregation points within a distance limit by the search Algorithm 1 on the graph. In addition, to improve the performance of index, we leverage the structural information of the graph to choose multiple reduandant points for residual points. And then DSANN keeps aggregation points and the proximity graph in memory while storing the residual points in the distributed storage for the separation of computation and storage.

Index Construction

Point Aggregation Graph

   Graph-based and cluster-based ANNS methods benefit from their respective index structure. Graph-based methods provide high accuracy while cluster-based methods can be viewed as a form of compression. It is intuitive to combines the adavatages of them to design a high-quality index structure that is tailored for distributed storage.
   Consider a proximity graph G(V, E) constructed on a dataset XXX consisting of billions of data points or even more. While ANNS on G using Algorithm 1 can achieve SOTA performance, it requires substantial memory to keep the index for online search. Following the clsuter-based methodology, we can aggregate the close vectors into a vertext of the graph in the memory, while the remaining points are organized as partition lists in the distributed storage. We call this index structure the Point Aggregation Graph. Before presenting out proposal, we first provide several essestial definitions as follows:
   Definition 3. Proximity Graph(PG). Given a finite vector dataset XXX of nnn vectors in space EdE^{d}Ed and a distance threshold θ>0\theta \gt 0θ>0. A proximity graph G(V,E)G(V, E)G(V,E) w.r.t θ\thetaθ on XXX is defined as follows: (1) For each vector xi⃗∈X\vec{x_{i}} \in Xxi​​∈X, there exists a corresponding vector vi∈Vv_{i} \in Vvi​∈V. (2) For any two vertices vi,vj∈Vv_{i}, v_{j} \in Vvi​,vj​∈V, if an edge vivj∈Ev_{i}v_{j} \in Evi​vj​∈E exists, then it holds that the distance δ(xi⃗,xj⃗)≤θ\delta (\vec{x_{i}},\vec{x_{j}}) \le \thetaδ(xi​​,xj​​)≤θ.
   Point Aggregation Graph(PAG). Given a finite vector dataset XXX of nnn vectors in space EdE^{d}Ed, a PG Gp(Va,Ea)G_{p}(V^{a},E^{a})Gp​(Va,Ea) on aggregation point set Xa⊆XX^{a} \subseteq XXa⊆X, residual point set Xr=X∖XaX^{r} = X \setminus X^{a}Xr=X∖Xa and an aggregation radius rrr. A point aggregation graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) is defined as follows: (1) For each vector vector xir⃗∈Xr\vec{x_{i}^{r}} \in X^{r}xir​​∈Xr, there exists a corresponding vector vir∈Vr=V∖Vav_{i}^{r} \in V^{r} = V \setminus V^{a}vir​∈Vr=V∖Va. (2) For any two vertices via∈Va,vjr∈Vrv_{i}^{a} \in V^{a}, v_{j}^{r} \in V^{r}via​∈Va,vjr​∈Vr, if an edge viavjrv_{i}^{a}v_{j}^{r}via​vjr​ exists, then it holds that the distance δ(xia⃗,xjr⃗)≤r\delta(\vec{x_{i}^{a}}, \vec{x_{j}^{r}}) \le rδ(xia​​,xjr​​)≤r. (3) For each vertex vir∈Vrv_{i}^{r} \in V^{r}vir​∈Vr, there exist a unique edge vjavir∈E∖Eav_{j}^{a}v_{i}^{r} \in E \setminus E^{a}vja​vir​∈E∖Ea, where vja∈Vav_{j}^{a} \in V^{a}vja​∈Va.
   The structure of PAG is illustrated in Figure 2. PAG categories the data points into two types: aggregation points and residual points. Aggregation points are used to construct a PG and each aggregation point is surrounded by several residual points, which tohether form a fully connected graph. It is noteworthy that every fully connected graph can be logically viewed as a partition The key difference between PAG and PG is that PAG represents the proximal relationship through partition containment, as shown in Figure 5(b) while Pg uses edge links, as shown in Figure 5(a).
   Although the structure of PAG is relatively simple, constructing such graph incurs significant computational costs, as each residual point needs linear scan to identify its corresponding aggregation point. Considering the much faster ANNS interface povided by the PG, each residual point can efficiently find its nearest neighbor as aggregation point by graph traversal. This approach constructs an approximate PAG, which we refer to naive PAG and the construct process is summarized in Algorithm 2.

Dynamic Representation Selection

   Theoretically, if the ANNS interface provided by the PG G could achieve perfect nearest neighbor retrival, the naive PAG could be regared as a PG constructed on the centroids generated by K-Means algorithm with zero iteration. However, K-Means typically requires multiple iterations to ensure the quality of clustering and relying on zero iterations fail to provide such gurantee. Furthermore, the straightforward aproach of assigning each residual point to the partition associated with nearest neighbor may yield highly imbalanced partitions due to the data skew. Such imbalance in clustering introduces two primary challenges:

  • Long Tail Effect: Imbalanced clsutering may result in partitions of two extreme sizes
  • Low Recall Rate: Significant partition imbalance indicates that centroids generated through random sampling may not adequately represent the underlying distribution of data, leading to considerable boundary problem.

   To address the challenge of imbalanced partitions, we introduce the Dynamic Representation Selection(DRS) strategy in this section, which is summarized in Algorithm 3. (1) DRS explictly constraints the capacity of each partition to prevent excessively large partitions. The sample rate ppp can be conceptually interpreted as the compression rate with 1p\frac{1}{p}p1​ indicating that the number of points each partition should ideally preserve. To handle data skew, we allow partitions to moderately exceed their ideal capcity. Specifically, we set a partition capacity limitation of λp,λ≥1\frac{\lambda}{p}, \lambda \ge 1pλ​,λ≥1. (2) Additionally, the distance limit obtained through distance sampling ensures that only residual points within this distance can be aggergated to the corresponding aggregation point, as illustrated in Figure 6(a). The aggregation point, along with it residual points, defines a sphere with center as described in Definition 4. For adatpive aggregation, we calculate the distances between each aggregation point and its neighbors in PG, then use the γ1\gamma_{1}γ1​ -th sorted distance as the radiusthreshold for aggregation. However, some aggregation points in PG lack sufficient neighgbors, making the y1y_{1}y1​ position distance meaningless. Therefore, we sort radii of all aggregation points and use the γ2\gamma_{2}γ2​ position radisu as the maximum threshold for every aggregation point. (3) Finally, residual point that cannot be aggregated into any existing aggregation points will be promoted as new aggregation points by inserting them into the PG, as shown in Figure 6(b). Through the dynamic promotion, we aim to capture the underlying distribution of dataset.

Graph-based Redundancy

   Aggregation and clustering share many similarities and offen suffer from the bounday problem. To alleviate the boundary problom, we propose a Graph-based Redundancy(GR) strategy that select redundant partitions of residual point by using the structural information of the graph, thereby avoiding overly dense and spase redundancy distributions. The core idea of the redundancy strategy is to serve the search process:

  • Nearest Neighbor Redundancy: By utilizing the ANNS interface provided by the PG, we identify the k nearest neighbors of the residual points, and then apply RNG-based rules to select redundant partitions represented by aggregation points.
  • Routing Path Redundancy: We ovserve that similar queries often follow the same routing problem. During the greedy search process of the PG, we track the routing path, and then select redundant partitions along the routing path based on RNG rules.

   Definition 5. RNG-based Rules. Given partition lists L\mathcal{L}L represent by XaX^{a}Xa and a residual point xr⃗∈Xr\vec{x^{r}} \in X^{r}xr∈Xr, aggregation point x1a⃗\vec{x_{1}^{a}}x1a​​ occludes aggregation point x2a⃗\vec{x_{2}^{a}}x2a​​ if δ(x⃗1a,x⃗r)<δ(x⃗2a,x⃗r)\delta(\vec{x}^a_1, \vec{x}^r ) < \delta(\vec{x}^a_2, \vec{x}^r )δ(x1a​,xr)<δ(x2a​,xr) and δ(x⃗1a,x⃗2a)<δ(x⃗2a,x⃗r)\delta(\vec{x}^a_1, \vec{x}_{2}^a ) < \delta(\vec{x}^a_2, \vec{x}^r )δ(x1a​,x2a​)<δ(x2a​,xr).

Concurrent Index Construction

   Although sampling methods can significantly reduce the number of points required for constructing a PG, construting such a graph remains conputatinally expensive.
   In this section, we propose Concurrent Index Construction(CIC) to achieve efficient PG construction. The details are summaized in Algorithm 4. Following DiskANN methodology, CIC splits the dataset into multiple partitions for independent graph construction and then merges all individual graphs to a complete graph. Instead of merging the neighbors redundant points used by DiskANN, CIC let each partition’s point identify their nearest neighbors from the close partitions using ANNS interfave provide by the corresponding PG, and then employ prune strategy to preserve the properties of PG such as KNNG and RNG. More importantly, CIC can be easily scaled for distributed construction across multiple machines.
   Nevertheless, the cost of ANNS on all partition is considerable, we durther enhance CIC efficieny by limiting the number of partitions that each vector searches. Ideally, an effective clustering algorithm should constrain proximate points within the same partition and points residing in adjacent partitions are likely to exhibit greater similarity. Therefore, during the graph merge stage, each point needs only to consider its neighboring partitions. Our experimental results indicate that, generally, searching partitions within a distance threshld is sufficicent to achieve comparable effectiveness to searching all partitions. Formally, this can be expresses as δ(x⃗,xc′⃗)≤ηδ(x⃗,xc⃗)\delta(\vec{x}, \vec{x_{c^{'}}}) \le \eta \delta(\vec{x}, \vec{x_{c}})δ(x,xc′​​)≤ηδ(x,xc​​), where xc⃗\vec{x_{c}}xc​​ denotes the centroid of the partition containing x⃗\vec{x}x, xc′⃗\vec{x_{c^{'}}}xc′​​ represents the partition under consideration, and η\etaη is the scaling factor.

Search On Index

Query on Index

   During the search process, DSANN follows the inverted methodology. Initially, it traverses the PG stored in memory to identify the most suitable partitions. Then a find-grained full-scan within the partitions is performed to retrieve the final results.
   The number of partitions identified duting the graph traversal significantly influsences both the recall rate and througput. Employing a strategy that probes a fiexed number of partitions may lead to over-exploration of centain points. In this paper, we propose an Adaptive Partition Probe(APP) method, which dynamically explores partitions based on the structural information of the graph to achieve eraly stopping.
   During the traversal of the PG, DSANN maintains the distance information of each visited point, creating a timeline. The traversal terminated when the distance between the query and the current point exceeds d+ri+rjd + r_{i} + r_{j}d+ri​+rj​, where ddd represents the minimal distance to the centroid, rir_{i}ri​ denoted the aggregation radius of the nearest partition, and rjr_{j}rj​ is the aggregation radius of the current partition.
   As illustrated in Figure 7, if the minimal distance between the query and agregation point is ddd, the maximum distance within the partition C1C_{1}C1​ is d+r1d + r_{1}d+r1​ because the aggregation partition is actually a sphere. Consider a sphere around the query with radius d+r1d + r_{1}d+r1​, if there exists an overlap between the partition and the sphere, we should explore the partition. For partition C2C_{2}C2​, where the distance between the query and its centroid is less than d+r1+r2d + r_{1} + r_{2}d+r1​+r2​, we will expore C2C_{2}C2​. Conversely, we will not expore C3C_{3}C3​.
   Furthermore, the number of partitions explored is closely related to kkk, which signifies the number of vectors recalled. We use ρ>1\rho \gt 1ρ>1 as the scale factor for different scenarios.

Asynchronous Query

   The inverted index method consists of two stages: a coarse-grained search followed by a fine-grained search. In the coarse-grained search stage, all residual points must be loaded into memory before entering the fine-grained stage. Therefore, the coarse-grained sage will stall the latter stage.
   In this paper, we introduce a search algorithm with asynchronous I/O and computation, as summarized in Algorithm 5. Leveraging the structural information of PG, DSANN can achieve asynchronous graph traversal in memory while concurrently retrieving the qualified partitions into mmeory for full-scan. By controlling the strictness of fetching criteria, we can effectively balance I/O and computation, improving the throughput of algorithm. For example, we can fetch the residual points as soon as the aggregation point with minimal distance is probed.

References

  • YU K, JIN J, ZHONG X, 等. Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search of Large Scale Vectors on Distributed Storage[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-10-29]. https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.17326.

entry.title: SHG, Acceleraing ANNS in Hierarchical Graphs, Efficient Level Navigation with Shortcuts
entry.content:
Overview

   Hierarchical methods still face efficicency bottlenecks because they rely on exhaustive and level-by-level traversals within hierarchical graphs. This paper introduces SHG, a novel hierarchical graph-based index that enhances search efficiency by bypassing intermediate and redundant levels. Specifically, SHG leverages a hierarchical vector compression method to reduce the time spent on distance computations, and employs a new data structure called shortcuts to determine the number of intermediate levels that can be safely skipped.

Details

Hierarchical Vector Compression For Approximate Distances

   This section first introduces a new vector compression strategy that progressively compresses vector representations as the level increases. A d-dimensional vetcor ooo is represented as [v1,v2,...,vd][v_{1}, v_{2}, ..., v_{d}][v1​,v2​,...,vd​], where viv_{i}vi​ is the coordinate value of the i-th dimension. For simplicity, we assume d=ηL−1d = \eta^{\mathcal{L}-1}d=ηL−1 for an integer L\mathcal{L}L (with default value of η\etaη set to 2). We use levell(o)level_{l}(o)levell​(o) to denote the compressed representation of this vectors’s coordinated at the level lll, where 1≤l≤L1 \le l \le \mathcal{L}1≤l≤L
   Main Idea. Eq.(2) presents the key steps of out hierarchical compression method by using progressive mean aggregation.

levell(o)={[v1,v2,⋯ ,vd]if l=1[meanl,1o,meanl,2o,⋯ ,meanl,ηl−1o]if l>1(2)\text{level}_l(o) = \begin{cases} \left[ v_1, v_2, \cdots, v_d \right] & \text{if } l = 1 \\\left[ \text{mean}_{l,1}^o, \text{mean}_{l,2}^o, \cdots, \text{mean}_{l,\eta^{l-1}}^o \right] & \text{if } l > 1 \end{cases} \tag{2}levell​(o)={[v1​,v2​,⋯,vd​][meanl,1o​,meanl,2o​,⋯,meanl,ηl−1o​]​if l=1if l>1​(2)

   Specically, at the base level(i.e., l=1l=1l=1), vectors maintain their original uncompressed representation: level1(o)=[v1,v2,...,vd]level_{1}(o)=[v_{1}, v_{2}, ..., v_{d}]level1​(o)=[v1​,v2​,...,vd​]. For upper levels(i.e., l>1l \gt 1l>1), we use meanl,jomean_{l,j}^{o}meanl,jo​ to denote the average of the coordinate values within the j-th segment at level l−1l-1l−1, which covers dimensions from η(j−1)+1\eta(j-1) + 1η(j−1)+1 to η(j−1)+η\eta(j-1) + \etaη(j−1)+η. Accordingly, meanl,jomean_{l,j}^{o}meanl,jo​ can be progressively calculated as follows:

meanl,jo={vjif l=11η∑k=1ηmeanl−1,k+η(j−1)oif l≥2(3)\text{mean}_{l,j}^o = \begin{cases} v_j & \text{if } l = 1 \\\frac{1}{\eta} \sum_{k=1}^{\eta} \text{mean}_{l-1,k+\eta(j-1)}^o & \text{if } l \geq 2 \end{cases} \tag{3}meanl,jo​={vj​η1​∑k=1η​meanl−1,k+η(j−1)o​​if l=1if l≥2​(3)

   Relative Error Analysis in Euclidean Space.(Refer to the original paper for proof) Given any two d-dimensioanl vectors o,o′∈Do, o^{'} \in Do,o′∈D under Euclidean space, for any level l∈[1,L)l \in [1, \mathcal{L})l∈[1,L), the approximate distances between them at levels lll and l+1l + 1l+1 satisfy the following ineuqlity:

dis(levell+1(o),levell+1(o′))≤1η⋅dis(levell(o),levell(o′))(4)\mathrm{dis}(\mathrm{level}_{l+1}(o), \mathrm{level}_{l+1}(o')) \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{\eta}} \cdot \mathrm{dis}(\mathrm{level}_l(o), \mathrm{level}_l(o')) \tag{4}dis(levell+1​(o),levell+1​(o′))≤η​1​⋅dis(levell​(o),levell​(o′))(4)

   Relative Error Analysis in Lp-norm.(Refer to the original paper for proof) Given any two d-dimensional vectors o,o′∈Do, o^{'} \in Do,o′∈D in Lp-norm(p≥1p \ge 1p≥1), for any level l∈[1,L)l \in [1, \mathcal{L})l∈[1,L), the approximate distances between them at levels lll and l+1l + 1l+1 satisfy the following inequality:

dis(levell+1(o),levell+1(o′))≤η−1/p⋅dis(levell(o),levell(o′))\mathrm{dis}(\mathrm{level}_{l+1}(o), \mathrm{level}_{l+1}(o')) \leq \eta^{-1/p} \cdot \mathrm{dis}(\mathrm{level}_l(o), \mathrm{level}_l(o'))dis(levell+1​(o),levell+1​(o′))≤η−1/p⋅dis(levell​(o),levell​(o′))

Shortcut-Enabled K-ANN Index

Key Component of Our Index: Shortcut

   The primary role of shortcut is to infer the number of levels that can be skipped when traversing the hierarchical graphs. This allows the shortcut to serve as an auxililary data struxture that complements ANN inexes and significantly improves the query efficiency.(In this section, we use the HNSW as an example to introduce out solution).
   Definition (Shortcut). Given a query vector and an entry vector ep in the hierarchical graph at a vertain level lll, the shortcut leverages the (approximate) distance dis^\hat{dis}dis^ between q and eq to infer the number of levels, denoted by f(dis^)f(\hat{dis})f(dis^), that can be skipped from lll. The shortcut also gurantees that ep remains the entry vector of the hierarchical graph at the target level with probability.
   For precise navigation across levels with minimal memory cost, we draw inspirations from learned index structures, which utilize machine models to fit the distributions, Prior studies demonstrate that linear model based leanred indexes are more lightweight and efficient compared to traditional data structures. Thus, we also adopt piecewise linear models to learn the number of levels that can be skipped, since it provides a worst-case error bound under various distributions. A learned shortcut is defined as follows:
   Definition (Learned Shortcut). Given a list of disance-level tuple S={(dis0^,h0),(dis1^,h1),...}S = \left \{ (\hat{dis_{0}},h_{0}), (\hat{dis_{1}}, h_{1}), ... \right \}S={(dis0​^​,h0​),(dis1​^​,h1​),...} as the training data, where disi^\hat{dis_{i}}disi​^​ is the approxiate distance between two compressed vectors, and hih_{i}hi​ is the corresponding number of levels that can be safely skipped. Let XXX denote the distance and YYY denote the levels. The mapping X→YX \rightarrow YX→Y is fitted using a set of piecewise linear functions: f(dis^)={(dis^1,slope1,intercept1),(dis^2,slope2,intercept2),⋯ }f(\widehat{dis}) = \{(\widehat{dis}_1, \text{slope}_1, \text{intercept}_1), (\widehat{dis}_2, \text{slope}_2, \text{intercept}_2), \cdots\}f(dis)={(dis1​,slope1​,intercept1​),(dis2​,slope2​,intercept2​),⋯}. Each triple (disi^,slopei,intercepti)(\widehat{dis_{i}}, slope_{i}, intercept_{i})(disi​​,slopei​,intercepti​) fits a certain range of tuples through the function: f(dis^)=dis^×slopei+interceptif(\widehat{dis}) = \widehat{dis} \times slope_{i} + intercept_{i}f(dis)=dis×slopei​+intercepti​. The learned shortcut is represented by the piecewise linear model f(dis^)f(\widehat{dis})f(dis). [For non-linear modles like the neural networks, inference time and memory usuage are significantly higher than models for learning shortcuts]

Index Construction

   Although piecewise linear models have achieved significant success in building learned indexes, we still face two major challenges to build learned shortcuts:

  • Determining Safe Skip Levels. There is currently no guideline for deciding the number of levels that can be safely skipped. Prior work on ANN search has not considered building shortcuts in hierarchical graphs, making this a novel challenge.
  • Generating Sufficient Training Samples. Unlike existing studies on learned indexes, the training data for our model is not explictly provided by the input dataset. Therefore, we need to devise an effective algorithm to generate sufficient training samples to build an accurate learned shortcut.

   Guideline for Skipping Levels. We propose a density-based criterion to determine how many levels can be safely skipped. Specically, consider ooo as the nearest neighbor of the query vector qqq at level xxx, which will serve as the entry point at level x+1x + 1x+1. If there are already numerous nearby vectors at level xxx that exhibit short distance to qqq(but longer than ooo), it is likely that ooo will remain the nearest neighbor to qqq at level x+1x + 1x+1. In such cases, traversing the proximity graph from ooo at level x+1x+ 1x+1 becomes redundant. Since ooo is the nearest vector to qqq, the nearby vector of qqq should also be close to ooo. Therefore, we use the density around the vector data o∈Do \in Do∈D to reflect the presence of nearby vectors relative to the qeury vector qqq, and derive Lemma 2 as the final guideline.
   Lemma 2. Given a vector ooo in the hierarchical graph at level xxx, we say the levels from xxx down to y+1y + 1y+1 can be skipped if yyy is the first level lower than xxx satisfying the following condition:

(dis⁡(level⁡x(o),level⁡x(ox,k)))dx≤ny⋅πdy2⋅Γ(dx2+1)nx⋅πdx2⋅Γ(dy2+1)⋅(dis⁡(level⁡y(o),level⁡y(oy,k)))dy\begin{aligned}& \left(\operatorname{dis}\left(\operatorname{level}_x(o), \operatorname{level}_x\left(o_{x, k}\right)\right)\right)^{d_x} \\& \leq \frac{n_y \cdot \pi^{\frac{d_y}{2}} \cdot \Gamma\left(\frac{d_x}{2}+1\right)}{n_x \cdot \pi^{\frac{d_x}{2}} \cdot \Gamma\left(\frac{d_y}{2}+1\right)} \cdot\left(\operatorname{dis}\left(\operatorname{level}_y(o), \operatorname{level}_y\left(o_{y, k}\right)\right)\right)^{d_y}\end{aligned}​(dis(levelx​(o),levelx​(ox,k​)))dx​≤nx​⋅π2dx​​⋅Γ(2dy​​+1)ny​⋅π2dy​​⋅Γ(2dx​​+1)​⋅(dis(levely​(o),levely​(oy,k​)))dy​​

   The parameter η\etaη in hierarchical vector compression is 2. [Refer to the original paper for proof]

k-ANN Search

   Our index accelerates search efficiency in two ways:

  • Using the vector compression method aforementioned, upper levels require fewer dimensiona to compute approximate distances. This significantly reduces computational costs
  • Using the learned shortcut, we can infer the number of levels that are confident enough to be skipped. This reduces the time spent traversing unncessary levels.

Index Maintenance

   Although ANN search is often studied over static data, some recent studies also consider the issue of index maintenance over dynamic updates. In general, dynamic updates involve two scenarios: deleting existing vectors and inserting new vectors. Our index SHG can effectively handle either scenario with the following strategies:

  • Deletion. In hierarchical graph based indexes, such as those implemented in the HNSW library, a prevalent method for deleting vectors is to mark them as deleted and verify these markers duting graph traversal. This method is also generally effective for our index. However, if a substantial portion of the dataset(e.g., 50%) has been deleted, up to half of the vectors each level may be non-existent. In such cases, search efficiency might be reduced, so it may be beneficial to rebuild the entrie index from scratch.
  • Insertion. Our index takes two main steps to insert a new vector: (i)Inserting in Hierarchical Graph: This steps adheres to the insertion routine for hierarchical graph-based indexes. Taking HNSW as an example, inserting a new vector involves establishing new edges between existing vectors and the new vector. It takes O(logN)O(log N)O(logN) time to insert a vector into a set of nnn vectors. (ii) Insertion in Learned Shortcut. Our SHG additionally performs insertions in learned shortcuts. In inserts the training data associated with the new vector and leverages the foundation model, PGM index, to process updates in O(logN)O(logN)O(logN) time.

References

  • Source code on Github
  • GONG Z, ZENG Y, CHEN L. Accelerating Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search in Hierarchical Graphs: Efficient Level Navigation with Shortcuts[J]. Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment, 2025, 18(10): 3518-3530.

entry.title: HMGI, A comprehensive Framework for Integrated Relational and Vector Search
entry.content:
Overview

   This paper introduces the Hybrid MultiModal Graph Index(HMGI), a novel framework designed to bridge the gap between vector databases and graph databases by creating a unified system for efficient, hybrid queries on multimodal data. HMGI leverages the native graph database architecture and integrated vector search capabilities, exemplified by platforms like Neo4j, to combine ANNS with pressive graph traversal queries. Key innocations of the HMGI framework include modallity-aware partitioning of embeddings to optimize index structure and query performance, and a system for adaptive, low-overhead index updates to support dynamic data ingestion.

Details

   Inspired by contemporary advacemnts in hybrid database ssytems, HMGI seamlessly integrates gaph tracersal capaabilities with vector similarity search to handle complex multimodal datasets efficiently. The methodology is structured around key components: architectural buleprint, data ingeation and processing, storage and indexing, query processing, adaptive updates, and learned optimizations.

Architectural Blueprint

   HMGI adopts a modular, microservies-based architecture to facilitate unified management of relational and vectoe data. At its core, a graph database such as Neo4j-v5 serves as the storage backbone, representing entities as nodes with embedded vectors as propoerties and interconnnections as weighted edges. Dedicated services for ingestion, indexing, storage, and query expose gRPC endpoints for inter-service communication, with Kafka enbaling asynchronous workflows and Ray orchestrating distributed tasks. The ingestion layer processes multimodal inputs, while the partitioning and indexing layers optimize data organization for sub-linear access. The query engine fuses vector and graph operations, supported by adaptive update mechanisms for dynamic environments. Optimizations layers incorporate machine learing for parameter tuning and cost-based planning. A distinguishing feature is the heterogeneous execution model, which dynamically allocates vector-intensive tasks to GPUs and graph traversals to CPUs, yielding 3-5x speedups on hybrid worklads.

Data Ingestion and Processing Pipeline

   The ingestion pipeline commences with rwo multimodal data from diverse srouces. The ingestion microservices exposes gRPC endpoints for receiving payloads, which are relayed asynchronously vis Kafka to horizontal workers for embedding generations and partitioning. Data classification by modality relies on metadata or heuristic analysis. Specialized encoders generate embeddings: SentenceTransformer(all-MiniLM-L6-v2, 384D) for text, CLIP(ViT-B/16, 512D) for mages, VideoMAE(768D) for videos, and Whisper(1280D) for audio. The encoding computes vectors e∈Rde \in R^{d}e∈Rd, where ddd varies by modality, with optional FP16 precision to reduce memory footprint during processing. To accomodate large volumes, ingestion employs batch processing with fallback for unsupported modalities, grouping records by modality for efficiency. Post-encoding, modality-aware partitioing optimizes locality using K-means:

Cluster Assignment=arg⁡min⁡c=1K∥e−μc∥2(1)\text{Cluster Assignment} = \arg\min_{c=1}^K \| \mathbf{e} - \boldsymbol{\mu}_c \|^2 \tag{1}Cluster Assignment=argc=1minK​∥e−μc​∥2(1)

   where KKK (default 2) centroids uc∈Rdu_{c} \in R^{d}uc​∈Rd are fitted on sampled embeddings, reducing search spaces by upto 70% for modality specific queries. As shown in Equation(1), e∈Rde \in R^{d}e∈Rd represents the embedding vector of a data point in a d-dimensional space, and ∣∣e−uc∣∣2||e - u_{c}||^{2}∣∣e−uc​∣∣2 denotes the squared Euclidean norm, measuring the distance between the embedding and each centroid. Partition assignments are persistened as node properties. A novel workload-aware repartitioning monitors query imbalances and trigers online adjustments without downtime, improving performance by 20-30% on evolving workloads. Batch insertion into storage leverages UNWIND for efficient Neo4j opeartions, minimizing transaction overhead.

Storage and Indexing

   HMGI utlizes Neo4j-v5 for persistent storage, levetaging its native vector indexing vis Apacha Lucene and HNSW for approximate nearest neighbor search(ANNS). The storage microservice expose gRPC interfaces over CoreStorage, with sharding via consistent hashing for distributed persistent. Modality-specific indexes are created dynamically with Cypher commands, supporting cosine similarity and condigurable dimensions

   Embeddings reside as node properties, relations as edges with weights, facilitating integrated access. Batch insertions vis NUWIND optimize throughput for large datasets. Indexing employs partitioned HNSW structures, with parameters(M=32,ef=200M=32, ef=200M=32,ef=200) tuned for balance between construction speed and query accuracy. The indexing micorservices uses Ray for distributed partitioning and index builds, scaling horizontally across nodes. A core novelty is flash quantization, dynamically compressing embedding to 4/8/16 bits based on memory thresholds(>80%, triggers 8-bit), achieving 50% memory savings with minimal recall degradation. The 8-bit quantization formula is:

q=⌊255⋅e−min⁡(e)max⁡(e)−min⁡(e)⌋(2)\mathbf{q} = \left\lfloor 255 \cdot \frac{\mathbf{e} - \min(\mathbf{e})}{\max(\mathbf{e}) - \min(\mathbf{e})} \right\rfloor \tag{2}q=⌊255⋅max(e)−min(e)e−min(e)​⌋(2)

   Also, modality-aware clustering biases HNSW edges toward semantic groups, enhancing locality.

Query Processing Engine

   The query engine interprets extended Cypher queries, argumenting standard syntax with vector operations like VECTOR_SEARCH and SIMILARITY_WEIGHT. The query microservice exposes gRPC endpoints over AsyncHMGISystem for batched and vector-specific searches. Hybrid queries initiate with partitioned ANNS via db.index.vector.queryNodes(), yielding scored candidated, followed by graph traversal to enforce relations. Fusion aggregated score via weighted summation:

S=wv⋅(1−dv)+wg⋅1h∑i=1hsgi(3)S = w_v \cdot (1 - d_v) + w_g \cdot \frac{1}{h} \sum_{i=1}^{h} s_{gi} \tag{3}S=wv​⋅(1−dv​)+wg​⋅h1​i=1∑h​sgi​(3)

   with dynamic DEG-inspired weights of wv,wgw_{v}, w_{g}wv​,wg​ for cross-modal flexibility. Here, as shown in Equation(3), SSS represents the final fused score combining vector and graph contributions, wvw_{v}wv​ is the weight for the vector similarity compoent, dv∈[0,1]d_{v} \in [0,1]dv​∈[0,1] is the normalized vector distance(e.g., cosine distance), wgw_{g}wg​ is the weight for the graph traversal component, hhh is the number of hops in the graph traversal, and sgis_{gi}sgi​ deonetes the score for the i-th hop in the graph traversal.

Adaptive Updates and Recomputation

   HMGI supports real-time data streams through multi-version concurrecy control(MVCC) with a delta store for insertions, updates, and deletions. Queries hybridize results: ANNS on the stable index plus brute-force on the delta, maintaining freshness with < 1% degradation. Asynchronous vacumming periodically flushes deltas to disk and merges incrementally into snapshots, avoiding full rebuilds. Thread allocation adapts to CPU utilization, optimizing merge overhead. This ensures sub-linear update latency, critical for dynamic encironemnts.

Learned Optimization and Cost Modeling

   Learned index structures employ random forests to predicate optimal HNSW parameters (M,ef)(M, ef)(M,ef) from worload features:

p^=f(x;θ),x=[μe,σe,∥q∥,…](4)\hat{p} = f(\mathbf{x}; \theta), \quad \mathbf{x} = [\mu_e, \sigma_e, \|\mathbf{q}\|, \ldots] \tag{4}p^​=f(x;θ),x=[μe​,σe​,∥q∥,…](4)

   delivering 25-40% recall improvements at fixed latancy. Here, as shown in Equation(4), p^\hat{p}p^​ presents the predicated HNSW parameters(e.g., M, ef), fff is the random forest model, θ\thetaθ denotes the model’s parameters, xxx is the input feature vector, ueu_{e}ue​ is the mean of the embdding vector components, σe\sigma _{e}σe​ is the standard deviation of the embdding components, and ∣∣q∣∣||q||∣∣q∣∣ is the norm of the query vector, with additional features included as needed. The formal cost model computes query expense:

C=αlog⁡N+β(d⋅h)+γplog⁡(N/p)(5)C = \alpha \log N + \beta (d \cdot h) + \gamma p \log (N / p) \tag{5}C=αlogN+β(d⋅h)+γplog(N/p)(5)

   where CCC is the estimated query execution cost, α,β\alpha, \betaα,β and γ\gammaγ are weighting coeeficients for the dataset size, dimensionality-hop product, and partitioning terms, respectively. NNN is the total number of data points, ddd is the embedding dimensionalitym hhh is the number of graph traversal hops, and ppp is the number of partitions. This facilitates greedy plan selection with optimality bounds. Dynamic repartitioning tracks query patterns, triggering online K−meansK-meansK−means adjustments if imbalances exceed thresholds, with incremental migration fro zero-downtime, enhancing adaptability by 20-30%.

References

  1. CHANDRA J, NAVNEET S K, ZHANG Y. The Hybrid Multimodal Graph Index (HMGI): A Comprehensive Framework for Integrated Relational and Vector Search[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-10-17]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2510.10123.

entry.title: PANORAMA, Fast-Track Nearest Neighbors
entry.content:
Overview

   Currently, ANNS systems spend up to 99% of query time to compute distance in their final refinement phase. In this paper, we present PANORAMA, a machine learning-driven approache that tackles the ANNS verification bottleneck through data-adaptive learned orthogonal transforms that facilitate the accretive refinement of distance bounds. Such transforms compact over 90% of signal energy into the first half of dimensions, enabling eraly candidate pruning with partial distance computations. Our contributions are as follows:

  • Cumulative distance computation: We introduce PANORAMA, an accretive ANNS refinement framework that complements existing ANNS schemes to render them effective on modern workloads. PANORAMA incrementally accumates L2 distance terms over an orthogonal transform and refines lower/upper bounds on the fly, promtly pruning candidates whose lower distance bound exceeds the running threshold.
  • Learned orthogonal transforms: We introduce a data-adaptive Cayley transform on the Stiefel manifold that concentrates energy in leading dimensions, enabling tight Cauchi-Schwarz distance bounds for early pruning.
  • Algorithm-systems co-design: We carefully co-design system aspects with specialized variants for contigunous and non-contigunous memory layouts, leveraging SIMD vectorization, cache-aware layouts, and batching, also provide theoretical guarantees alongside practical performance.
  • Integrability: We fold PANORAMA into five key ANNS indexes(IVFPQ, IVFFlat, HNSW, MRPT, Annoy) to gain speedups without loss of recall and showcase its efficaciousness through experimentation across datasets, hyperparameters, and out-of-distribution queries.

Details

PANORAMA: Distance Computation

   Kashyap & Karras[1] introduced STEPWISE KNN search, which incrementally incorporates features(i.e., dimensions) and refines lower(LB) and upper(UB) bounds for each candidates distance from the query. This accretive refinement eventually yields exact distances. In addition, STEPWISE keeps track of the kthk^{th}kth upper bound dkd_{k}dk​ in each iteration, and prunes candidates having LB>dkLB \gt d_{k}LB>dk​. When no more than k candidates remain, these form the exact KNN result. We derive distance bounds using a norm-preserving transform T:Rd→RdT: R^{d} \rightarrow R^{d}T:Rd→Rd along the lines of Kashyap&Karras, by decomposing the squared Euclidean distances as in:

∥q−x∥2=∥T(q)∥2+∥T(x)∥2−2⟨T(q),T(x)⟩(1)\| \mathbf{q} - \mathbf{x} \|^2 = \| T(\mathbf{q}) \|^2 + \| T(\mathbf{x}) \|^2 - 2 \langle T(\mathbf{q}), T(\mathbf{x}) \rangle \tag{1}∥q−x∥2=∥T(q)∥2+∥T(x)∥2−2⟨T(q),T(x)⟩(1)

   Using threshold 0=m0<m1<...<ml=d0 = m_{0} \lt m_{1} \lt ... \lt m_{l} = d0=m0​<m1​<...<ml​=d partitioning vectors into LLL levels l1,l2,...,lLl_{1}, l_{2}, ..., l_{L}l1​,l2​,...,lL​, we define partitial innner products and tail(residual) energies:

p(ℓ1,ℓ2)(q,x)=∑j=mℓ1+1mℓ2T(q)jT(x)j,RT(q)(ℓ1,ℓ2)=∑j=mℓ1+1mℓ2T(q)j2,RT(x)(ℓ1,ℓ2)=∑j=mℓ1+1mℓ2T(x)j2(2)p^{(\ell_1, \ell_2)}(\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{x}) = \sum_{j = m\ell_1 + 1}^{m\ell_2} T(\mathbf{q})_j T(\mathbf{x})_j, \quad R_{T(\mathbf{q})}^{(\ell_1, \ell_2)} = \sum_{j = m\ell_1 + 1}^{m\ell_2} T(\mathbf{q})_j^2, \quad R_{T(\mathbf{x})}^{(\ell_1, \ell_2)} = \sum_{j = m\ell_1 + 1}^{m\ell_2} T(\mathbf{x})_j^2 \tag{2}p(ℓ1​,ℓ2​)(q,x)=j=mℓ1​+1∑mℓ2​​T(q)j​T(x)j​,RT(q)(ℓ1​,ℓ2​)​=j=mℓ1​+1∑mℓ2​​T(q)j2​,RT(x)(ℓ1​,ℓ2​)​=j=mℓ1​+1∑mℓ2​​T(x)j2​(2)

   The inner product terms from level mlm_{l}ml​ to the last dimension ddd satisfy the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality: ∣∑j=mℓ+1dT(q)jT(x)j∣≤RT(q)(ℓ,d)RT(x)(ℓ,d)\left| \sum_{j = m\ell + 1}^{d} T(\mathbf{q})_j T(\mathbf{x})_j \right| \leq \sqrt{R_{T(\mathbf{q})}^{(\ell, d)} R_{T(\mathbf{x})}^{(\ell, d)}}∣∣∣∣​∑j=mℓ+1d​T(q)j​T(x)j​∣∣∣∣​≤RT(q)(ℓ,d)​RT(x)(ℓ,d)​​ , hence the bounds:

LBℓ(q,x)=RT(q)(0,d)+RT(x)(0,d)−2(p(0,ℓ)(q,x)+RT(q)(ℓ,d)RT(x)(ℓ,d))≤∥q−x∥2(3)\mathrm{LB}^\ell(\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{x}) = R_{T(\mathbf{q})}^{(0, d)} + R_{T(\mathbf{x})}^{(0, d)} - 2 \left( p^{(0, \ell)}(\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{x}) + \sqrt{R_{T(\mathbf{q})}^{(\ell, d)} R_{T(\mathbf{x})}^{(\ell, d)}} \right) \leq \| \mathbf{q} - \mathbf{x} \|^2 \tag{3}LBℓ(q,x)=RT(q)(0,d)​+RT(x)(0,d)​−2(p(0,ℓ)(q,x)+RT(q)(ℓ,d)​RT(x)(ℓ,d)​​)≤∥q−x∥2(3)

UBℓ(q,x)=RT(q)(0,d)+RT(x)(0,d)−2(p(0,ℓ)(q,x)−RT(q)(ℓ,d)RT(x)(ℓ,d))≤∥q−x∥2(4)\mathrm{UB}^\ell(\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{x}) = R_{T(\mathbf{q})}^{(0, d)} + R_{T(\mathbf{x})}^{(0, d)} - 2 \left( p^{(0, \ell)}(\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{x}) - \sqrt{R_{T(\mathbf{q})}^{(\ell, d)} R_{T(\mathbf{x})}^{(\ell, d)}} \right) \leq \| \mathbf{q} - \mathbf{x} \|^2 \tag{4}UBℓ(q,x)=RT(q)(0,d)​+RT(x)(0,d)​−2(p(0,ℓ)(q,x)−RT(q)(ℓ,d)​RT(x)(ℓ,d)​​)≤∥q−x∥2(4)

   PANORAMA, outlined in Algorithm 1, maintains a heap of the exact kNN distances among processed candidates, initialize with the k first read candidates, and the kthk^{th}kth smallest distance dkd_{k}dk​ from the query. For subsequent candidates, it monotonically tightens the lower bound as LBl(q,x)≤LBl+1(q,x)≤∣∣q−x∣∣2LB^{l}(q,x) \le LB^{l+1}(q,x) \le ||q-x||^{2}LBl(q,x)≤LBl+1(q,x)≤∣∣q−x∣∣2, and prunes the candidate once that lower bound exceeds the dkd_{k}dk​ threshold, enabling eraly termination at dimension ml<dm_{l} \lt dml​<d; otherwise, it reaches the exact distance and updates HHH accordingly(Lines 12-14). Thanks to the correctness of lower bounds and the fact that dkd_{k}dk​ holds the kthk^{th}kth distance among processed candidates, candidates thet belong in the KNN result are pruned. Algorithm 1 encapsulates a genral procedure for several execution modes of PANORAMA. Appendix C in the original paper provides further details on those modes. Notably, STWPWISE assumes a monolithic contiguous storage scheme, which does not accommodate the multifarious layouts used in popular ANNS indexes. We decouple the prunning strategy from memory layout with a batch processing pramework tha prescribes thress execution modes using two parameters: a batch size BBB and an upper bound policy π∈0,1\pi \in {0,1}π∈0,1:

  1. Point-centric(B=1,π=0B=1, \pi = 0B=1,π=0), which processes candidates individually with early abandoning, hence suits graph- and tree-based indexes that store candidates in non-contiguous layouts.
  2. Batch-noUB(B>1,π=0B \gt 1, \pi = 0B>1,π=0), which defers heap updates to reduce overhead and enhance throughput, appropriate for indexes organizing vectors in small batches.
  3. Batch-UB(B≫1,π=1B \gg 1, \pi = 1B≫1,π=1), which amortizes system costs across large batches and uses upper bounds for fine-tuned prunning within each batch.

   When using batches, we compute distances for candidates within a batch in tandem. Batch sizes are designed to fit it L1 cache and the additional cost is negligible.
   PANORAMA relies on two design choices: first a transform TTT that concentrates energy in the leading dimensions, enabling tight bounds, which we achieve through learned transforms yielding exponential decay; second, level threshold mlm_{l}ml​ that strike a balance between the computational overhead level-wise processing incurs and the pruning granularity it provides.

Learning Orthogonal Transforms

   We propose learning a tailored linear orthogonal transform for ANNS purpose. Formally, we seek a matrix T∈Rd×dT \in R^{d \times d}T∈Rd×d, with TTT=IT^{T}T = ITTT=I, such that the transform z=Txz = Txz=Tx of a signal x attains energy compaction, i.e., concentrates most energy in its leading dimensions while preserving norms by orthoganality, i.e., ∣∣z∣∣2=∣∣x∣∣2||z||_{2} = ||x||_{2}∣∣z∣∣2​=∣∣x∣∣2​

Parameterization

   We view the set of orthogonal matrices, O(d)={T∈Rd×d:TTT=I}O(d)=\left \{ T \in R^{d \times d}: T^{T}T = I \right \}O(d)={T∈Rd×d:TTT=I}, as the Stiefel manifold, a smooth Riemannian manifold where geodesics corresponds to contious rotations. The Cayley transform maps any d×dd \times dd×d real skew-symmetric(antisymmetric) matrix AAA —— i.e., an element of the Lie algebra so(d) of the special orthogonal group SO(d), with AT=−AA^{T}=-AAT=−A, hence having dim=d(d−1)/2dim=d(d-1)/2dim=d(d−1)/2 independent entries —— to an orthogonal matrix in SO(d) (exclusing rotations with -1 eigenvalus). The resulting matrix lies on a subset of the Stiefel manifold, and the mapping servers as a smooth retraction, proving a first-order approximation of a geodesci at its starting point while avoiding repeated projections:

T(A)=(I−γ2A)−1(I+γ2A)(5)T(\mathbf{A}) = \left( I - \frac{\gamma}{2} \mathbf{A} \right)^{-1} \left( I + \frac{\gamma}{2} \mathbf{A} \right) \tag{5}T(A)=(I−2γ​A)−1(I+2γ​A)(5)

   The parameter γ\gammaγ controls the step size of the rotation on the Stiefel manifold: smaller γ\gammaγ values yield smaller steps, while larger values allow more aggresive rotations but may risk numerical instability. Contrary to other parameterizations for orthogonal transform operators, such as updates via Householder reflections and Givens rotations, which apply a non-paralelizable sequence of simple rank-one or planar rotations, the Cayley map yields a full-matrix rotation in a single update step, enabling efficient learning on GPUs without ordering bias. Unlike structuredfast transforms, which rely on sparse, rigidly defined matrices crafted for special data types, the learned transform is dense and full determined by the data, naturally adapting to any dataset. Further, the Cayley map enables learning from a rich and continuous family of rotations; altoough it excludes rotations with -1 as an eigenvalue, which express a half-turn in some plane, it still allows gradient-based optimization using standard batched linear-algebra primitives, which confer numerical stability, parallelizability, and suitability for GPU acceleration.

Energy Compaction Loss

   As discussed, we prefer a transform that compacts the signal’s early energy into the leading dimensions and lets residual energies R(l,d)R^{(l,d)}R(l,d) decay exponentially. The residual energy of a signal xxx by an orthgonal transform TTT following the first lll coefficients is RTx(ℓ,d)=∑j=ℓd−1(Tx)j2R_{T\mathbf{x}}^{(\ell, d)} = \sum_{j = \ell}^{d - 1} (T\mathbf{x})_j^2RTx(ℓ,d)​=∑j=ℓd−1​(Tx)j2​. WE formulated a loss function that penalizes ddeviations of normalized residuals from exponential decay, on each dimension and for all vectors in a dataset DDD, explicitly depending on the parameter matrix AAA:

L(T(A);D)=1N∑x∈D1d∑ℓ=0d−1(RT(A)x(ℓ,d)RT(A)x(0,d)−e−αℓd)2,α>0(6)\mathcal{L}(T(\mathbf{A}); \mathcal{D}) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{D}} \frac{1}{d} \sum_{\ell = 0}^{d - 1} \left( \frac{R_{T(\mathbf{A})\mathbf{x}}^{(\ell, d)}}{R_{T(\mathbf{A})\mathbf{x}}^{(0, d)}} - e^{-\frac{\alpha \ell}{d}} \right)^2, \quad \alpha > 0 \tag{6}L(T(A);D)=N1​x∈D∑​d1​ℓ=0∑d−1​⎝⎛​RT(A)x(0,d)​RT(A)x(ℓ,d)​​−e−dαℓ​⎠⎞​2,α>0(6)

   The learning objective is thus to find the optimal skew-symmetric matrix A∗A^{*}A∗:

A∗=argminA∈so(d)L(T(A);D)\mathbf{A}^* = \underset{\mathbf{A} \in \mathfrak{so}(d)}{\text{argmin}} \mathcal{L}(T(\mathbf{A}); \mathcal{D})A∗=A∈so(d)argmin​L(T(A);D)

   We target this objective by gradient descent, updating AAA at iteration ttt as:

A(t+1)=A(t)−η∇AL(T(A(t));D)\mathbf{A}^{(t+1)} = \mathbf{A}^{(t)} - \eta \nabla_{\mathbf{A}} \mathcal{L}(T(\mathbf{A}^{(t)}); \mathcal{D})A(t+1)=A(t)−η∇A​L(T(A(t));D)

   where η\etaη is the learning rate, parameterizing only upper-triangular values of AAA to ensure it remains skew-symmetric. The process drives AAA in the skew-symmetric space so that the learned Cayley orthogonal transform T(A(t))T(A^{(t)})T(A(t)), applied to the data in each step, compacts energy in the leading coefficients, leading residual energies RT(A)x(ℓ,d)R_{T(\mathbf{A}) \mathbf{x}}^{(\ell, d)}RT(A)x(ℓ,d)​ to decay quasi-exponentially. We set A0=0d×dA^{0}=0^{d \times d}A0=0d×d, hence T(A0)=IT(A^{0}) = IT(A0)=I, and warm-start by compositing it with the orthogonal PCA basis T′T^{'}T′, and subsequent gradient updates of AAA adapt the composed orthogonal operator T(A)^T^{'} to the data.

Integration with SOTA Indexes

   On contiguous layouts, which exploit locality and SIMD parallelism, we rearrange the contiguous storage to a level-major format to facilitate PANORAMA’s level-wise refinement and bulk pruning in cache-efficient fasion. On non-contigunous layoouts, PANORAMA still curtails redundant distance computations, despite the poor locality. Here, we discuss how we integrate PANAROMA in the refinement step of both categories.

Contiguous-Layout Indexes

   L2Flat and IVFFLAT’s native storage laout does not suit PANORAMA for two reasons:

  1. Processor cache locality and prefetching: By PANORAMA refinement, we reload query slices for each each vector, preventing stride-based prefetching and causing frequent processor cache misses.
  2. Branch misprediction: While processing a single vector, the algorithm makes up to nlevelsn_{levels}nlevels​ decisions on whether to prune it, each introducing a branch, which rendes control flow irregular, defeats branch predictors, and stalls the instruction pipeline.

   To address these conserns, we integrate PANORAMA in Faiss with a batched, level-major design, restructuring each clsuter’s memory layout to support level-wise rather than vector-wise refinement. We group vectors into batches and organize each batch in level-major order that generalizes the dimension-major order that generalizes the dimension-major layout of PDX. Each level stores a contiguous group of features for each point in the batch. The algorithm refines distances level-by-level within each batch. At each level, it first computes the distance contributions for all vectors in the batch, and then makes bulk pruning decisions over all vetcors. This consolidation of branch checks in nlevelsn_{levels}nlevels​ synchronizes steps regularizes control flow, reduces branch mispredictions, and improves cache utilization.
   However, directly applying the storage layout of L2Flat/IVFFLAT to IVFPQ introduces an additional chalenge:
3. SIMD lane underutilization: When the PQ codes for a given vector are shoter than the SIMD register width, vector-wise leaves many lanes idle, underusing computr resources.

   Instead of storing PQ codes by vector, we contiguously store code slices of the same quantizer across vectors in a batch. This layout lets SIMD instructions process lookup-table(LUT) entries for multiple vectors within the register, fully utilizing compute lanes and address cache thrashing, as LUT entries of codes for the same query lines remain cache-resident for reuse.

Non-Contiguous-Layout Indexes

   Our index methods that store candidate points in noncontiguous memory, the refinement phase faces a memory-computation tradeoff. Fetching candidate vectors incurs frequent prcessor(L3) cache misses, so the cost of moving data into cache rivals that of arithmetric distance computations, rendering the process memory-layout. Even with SIMD acceleration, poor locality among candidates slows throughput, and by Amdahl’s lay, enhancing computing alone yoelds disminishing returns. Lacking a good fix, we do not rearrange the storage layout with these three indexes.
   Graph-based(HNSW). Unlike other ANNS methods, HNSW conducts no separate verifiction, as it computrs exact distances during traversal. We integrate PANORAMA by modifying how embedding enter the candidate heap to reduce distance evaluations: we prioritize candidates using running bounds, with the estimate LBl+UBl2\frac{LB^{l} + UB^{l}}{2}2LBl+UBl​, and defer computing a candidates’s exact distance until it enters the result heap.
   Tree-based(Annoy). Tree-based methods recursively partition the vector space into leaf nodes, each containing candidate vectors. Annoy constructs these partitions by spliting along hyperplanes defines by pairs of randomly selected vectors, and repeats this process to build a random forest of ntreesn_{trees}ntrees​ trees. At query time, it traverses each tree down the nearest leaf and sends the candidate vectors from all visited leaves to verification, where we interate PANORAMA.
   Locality-based(MRPT). MRPT also uses a forest of random trees, like Anooy does, yet split vis median thresholds on random linear projections rather than vis hyperplanes. This design ties MRPT to Johnson-Lindernstrauss guarantees, enbling recall tuning, and incorporates voting across trees to filter candidates. We integrate PANORAMA as-in the refinement pahse.

References

  1. Shrikant Kashyap and Panagiotis Karras. Scalable kNN search on vertically stored time series. In Proceedings of the 17th ACM SIGKDD International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining, pp. 1334–1342, 2011. ISBN 9781450308137. URL https://doi.org/10.1145/2020408.2020607
  2. Suorce code on Gtihub
  3. RAMANI V, SCHLOMER A, NAYAR A, 等. Panorama: Fast-Track Nearest Neighbors[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-10-14]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2510.00566.

entry.title: FANNS-Bench, A Unified Benchmark and Systematic Experimental Study
entry.content:
Overview

   A comprehensive survey and benchmark for FANNS is crucial to achieve the following goals: designing a fair evaluation and clarifying the classification of algorithms, conducting in-depth analysis of their performance, and establishing a unified benchmark. First, we propose a taxonomy(dividing methods into filter-then-search, search-then-filter, hybrid-search) and a systemmatic evaluation framework, integrating unified parameter tuning and standardized filtering across algorithms to reduce implementation-inducd performace variations and reflect core trade-offs. Then, we conduct a comprehensive empirical study to analyze how query difficulty and dataset properties impact performance, evaluating robustness under pressure like filter selectivity, Recall@k, and scalability to clarify each method’s strengths. Finally, we establish a standardized benchmark with real-world datasets and open-source related resources to ensure reproducible future reasearch.

Details

Preliminary

Taxonomy

   We first present four filter constraints S commonly used in recent FANNS studies, followed by an illustrating example.

  1. Definition(Containment). A vector xj∈RS(vq)x_{j} \in R_{S}(v_{q})xj​∈RS​(vq​) with label set fif_{i}fi​ satisfies fj∣Sfqf_{j} \mid_{S} f_{q}fj​∣S​fq​ iff fq⊆fjf_{q} \subseteq f_{j}fq​⊆fj​
