  2. Definition(Overlap). A vector xj∈RS(vq)x_{j} \in R_{S}(v_{q})xj​∈RS​(vq​) with lable set fjf_{j}fj​ satisfies fj∣Sfqf_{j} \mid_{S} f_{q}fj​∣S​fq​ if and only if fq∩fx≠∅f_{q} \cap f_{x} \neq \emptysetfq​∩fx​=∅
  3. Definition(Equality). A vector xj∈RS(vq)x_{j} \in R_{S}(v_{q})xj​∈RS​(vq​) with label set fjf_{j}fj​ satisfies fj∣Sfqf_{j} \mid_{S} f_{q}fj​∣S​fq​ iff fq=fjf_{q} = f_{j}fq​=fj​
  4. Definition(Fixed-Length Equality). All vectors in dataset DDD must have the same numbers of labels, i.e., ∣fi∣=∣fj∣|f_{i}| = |f_{j}|∣fi​∣=∣fj​∣ for xi,xj∈Dx_{i},x_{j} \in Dxi​,xj​∈D. And the filter constraint fj∣Sfqf_{j} \mid_{S} f_{q}fj​∣S​fq​ is satisfied if and only if fq=fjf_{q} = f_{j}fq​=fj​

Notably, beyond these filter constraints on categorical labels, recently range filters also arise, where each vector viv_{i}vi​ has a single numerical attributes like a timestamp or a price. A query consists of a vector vqv_{q}vq​ and a continuous range [l,r][l,r][l,r], aiming to find the k-nearest neighbors to vqv_{q}vq​ whose attributes fall within this range. Though there are a few specialized solutions, we find that they are merely compatile with the majority of FANNS algorithms and thus not coveredin this survey.

Filter-Then-Search ANNS Algorithms

   Filter-then-search algorithms explicitly or implicitly filter the entire dataset D={x1,x2,...,xn}D = \left \{ x_{1}, x_{2}, ..., x_{n} \right \}D={x1​,x2​,...,xn​} to extract vectors satisfying specified label constraints. This process generates a filter subset Df={xk1,xk2,...,xkm}D_{f} = \left \{ x_{k1}, x_{k2}, ..., x_{km} \right \}Df​={xk1​,xk2​,...,xkm​} where Df⊆DD_{f} \subseteq DDf​⊆D. Subsequent nearest neighbor search operates exclusively within this filtered subset DfD_{f}Df​, requireing no additional constraint verification during query processing. The search procedure reduces to solving a conventional ANNS problem over the constrained dataset.
   A critical implementation combines pre-filtering with vector quantization. This approach first utilizes a fast bitset to identify the IDs of all points that satisfy the metadata constraints. Then, a quantization algorithm is used to rapidly compare the approximate distances between these candidate points and the query vector. Finally, a small subset of the most promising candidates is selected for a reranking step using their full-precision vector representations.
   Creating the filter map relies on a pre-computed inverted index, where each label maps to a bitset indicating all vectors that possess it.
   Pre-filter Brute Force. We implement a baseline algorithm that first filter the dataset and then applies brute-force search. The filter map is used to retrieve the subset of database (Df⊆D)(D_{f} \subseteq D)(Df​⊆D) that satisfies the filter constraints. Then, it performs a brute-force, full-precision search within filtered vector set(DfD_{f}Df​) and returns the top-k results.
   ACORN-γ. The ACORN-γ algorithm constructs its without any label information in advance. This follows for flexible data updates, as labels can be assigned or modified after the index is built. The core construction idea is to create a denser graph by expanding each node’s degree by a factor γ\gammaγ, which is dtermined based on an estimated selectivity. A specialized predicate-agnostic pruning techinuqe is then applied to control the index size. At query time, ACORN-γ performs a full-dataset scan to generate a bitset of all vectors satisfying the filter constraint(which can be complex as a regular expression). The subsequent graph traversal is then guided by this bitset. When expanding its candidate list, it decompresses the neighbor information and checks filtering conditions, which broadens the search’s scope. This algorithm can be combines with mainstream indexes like HNSW and DiskANN and performs wel with high selectivity, and many vector search engines have added support for it.
   ACORN-1. In contrast to ACORN-γ, ACORN-1 offers a lightweight alternative that aims to approximate the search performance of ACORN-γ while significantly reducing index construction time and memory cost. The key difference lies in its approach to neighbor expansion. Instead of creating a denser graph during construction, ACORN-1 builds a standard, un-pruned HNSW index. During the greedy search, then visiting a node vvv, ACORN-1 dynamically expands the search scope to consider not only its direct(one-hop) neighbors but also its two-jop neighbors. This expanded candidate set is then filtered according to the query predicate before the best neighbors into the priority queue.
   UNG. The UNG algorithm precompiles lable information into a label navigating graph structure during offline construction, which encodes the containment relationships of different label sets. It groups vectors by their labels, builds intra-group graphs, and adds inter-group edges based on a label navigating graph(LNG). This design gurantees that if an edge (vi,vj)(v_{i}, v_{j})(vi​,vj​) exists, their labels satisfy a containment relationship (fi⊆fj)(f_{i} \subseteq f_{j})(fi​⊆fj​). By locating the entry labels that follow the filter constraints, greedy traversal on the proximity graph never requires further label checking, making UNG a highly efficient filter-then-search method for containment and equality predicates. However, its performance suffers significantly on queries with more complex constraints, such as label overlap scenarios, as multiple rounds of search are performed starting from different entries.

Search-Then-Filter Algorithms

   Search-then-filter algorithms performs an unconstrained approximate nearest neighbors search over the entire dataset D={x1,x2,...,xn}D = \left \{ x_{1}, x_{2}, ..., x_{n} \right \}D={x1​,x2​,...,xn​}, R={xr1,xr2,...,xrl}R = \left \{ x_{r1}, x_{r2}, ..., x_{rl} \right \}R={xr1​,xr2​,...,xrl​} ordered by their distance to the query, where typically l≫kl \gg kl≫k and kkk denotes the number of search targets. This approac provides naive compatibility with most existing ANNS algorithms. After performing the traditionaly ANNS search, the constraint verification proceeds as follows:

  • If RRR constains at least kkk vectors satisfying the label constraints, the top-k vali results are returned immediately.
  • Otherwise, the search scope lll is iteratively expanded to retrieve more candidates, repeating the verification process until kkk valid results are obtained.

   Post-filter HNSW. We implement this baseline by combining the standard HNSW algorithm with a post-filtering strategy.
   Post-filter IVF-PQ. We also implement another baseline using the Inverted File with Product Quantization(IVF-PQ) index. The post-filtering mechanism remains the same, but the nunderlying search scope is controlled by nprobenprobenprobe parameter, which specifies the number of lists to visit.

Hybrid-Search ANNS Algorithm

   Hybrid-search algorithms integrate label constraints directly into the search process, avoiding explict pre-filtering or post-filtering stages. This approach typically employs some strategies, such as constraint neighbor expansion or distance fusion. They may build upon fundationaly ANNS methods, such as Filtered-DiskANN that extends DiskANN by deeply integrating label constraints into index construction and query processing.
   Filtered-DiskANN. This algorithm is based on the Vamana graph, the core graph index of DiskANN, but modifies both the construction and search process to be label-aware. During index construction, when a new point is inserted, only neighbors that share at least one common lable with the new point(i.e., fi∩fq≠∅f_{i} \cap f_{q} \neq \emptysetfi​∩fq​=∅) are added to the candidate queue, and edges are then established with the candidates found along this search path. Finally, a lable-aware pruning strategy is applied to refine the connections. We note that the original implemention primarily supports singleton query label sets (∣fq=1∣|f_{q} = 1|∣fq​=1∣). To accomodate more genral cases (∣fq>1∣|f_{q} \gt 1|∣fq​>1∣) and more scenarios, we extend the algorithm by adding an extra filtering step: after a node is poped from the candidate queue and before it is placed into the final result, we perform a label check.
   Stitched-DiskANN. In contrast to Filtered-DiskANN’s graph approach, Stiched-DiskANN adoptes a “partition-then-stich” construcion strategy. It first partitions the dataset by creating a separate Vamana subgraph for each individual label in the entir label set L\mathcal{L}L. During the construction of each Vamana subgraph, a point is connected to other points whose labels intersect with its own; this design makes its search process highly suitable, as it only needs to expand neighbors that have label intersections with the query and ensures connectivity. These intially disconnected subgraphs are then “stiched” together into a single cohesive index. The stiching process leverages points that carry multiple labels, sinces these points naturally appear in multiple subgraphs, they serve as crucial bridge nodes that ensure connnectivity.
   NHQ. NHQ is a hybrid-search algorithm that builds upon fundationaly graph-based ANNS methods, such as kgraph and NSW, and introduces modifications to better adapt to filtering scenarios. It integrates label constraints into both the graph construction and query process by fusing label-based distances with vector distance metrics. Specifically, NHQ defines a combined weight wt(vi,vj)wt(v_{i},v_{j})wt(vi​,vj​) using the Hamming distance of the labels between two nodes and the vector distance δ(vi,vj)\delta(v_{i}, v_{j})δ(vi​,vj​), creating a weighted fusion of these two metrics. For graph construcion, NHQ employs a Navigable PG(NPG) strategy, where edges are proactively established between points in diverse directions. This ensures better navigability during the search process, allowing queries to traversa the graph efficiently.
   CAPS. CAPS algorithm construts a two-level inex by first partitioning the dataset into coarse spatical clusters using k-means. Each cluster is then further subdivided into a hierarchy of fine-grained, label-based sub-clusters. This is done by iteratively creating sub-clusters for the most frequent label among the remaining vectors, up to a specified number of sub-clusters hhh. At query time, CAPS first identifies the nearest coarse clsuter centroid. It then sequentially probes the second-level sub-clusters within that cluster in their order of creation to find matching results.

Parameter Tuning

   Existing studies demonstrates that vector databses exhibit a high dimensional parameter space where configurations are highly interdependent optimization of individual parameters. Fuethermore, tuning constitutes a complex two-objective optimization problem(maximizing both QPS and recall), making it challenging to identify parameter configurations that yeild optimal trade-offs in the QPS-Recall space.
   To address these challenges, we propose a parameter tuning approache as shown in Fig. 6, which is designed for:

  • Coverage: Comprehensive explotation of the parameter space
  • Balance: Optimal trade-offs vis the Pareto frontier
  • Robustness: Near-optimal paramters for each specific context

   Algorithm 1 begins by partitioning the entire parameter space Ω\OmegaΩ into smaller, manageable subspaces(line 1). This strategy ensures a broad exploration of different parameter regions. To accelerate the evaluation process, we perfrom searches on a randomly sampled subset of the dataset D′D^{'}D′ (line 5). For each parameter configuration θ\thetaθ within a subspace, we evaluate its performance across all defined search scenarios and compute the average QPS and Recall(line 11).
   A key step in our method is to normalize the comparison of different parameter sets. We evaluate how efficiently a confiuration can achieve specific recall targets. We define a set of fixed recall levels(e.g., 0.8, 0.9, 0.95) (linre 15) and use linear interpolation to estimate the QPS that each configuration θ\thetaθ would achieve at these exact recall values(line 13). Each configuration is then assigned a rank based on its interpolated QPS values(line 14). Finally, for each subspace, we select the parameter configuration with the best overall rank as the representative of that region

Recommendation

(We give conclusions directly below, refer the original paper for more experiment details)

  • Prefer UNG default for strong QPS-recall in Containment and Equality scenarios; uder very low selectivity or long labels, filter-then-search(e.g., UNG, ACORN-1, or even pre-filter Brute Force) keeps candidates small and throughput high; at high k, favor UNG/ACORN and avoid post-filter IVFPQ
  • Fixed-Length Equality is an easier, structured case where most methods reach high recall with proper tuning; UNG and CAPS offer top QPS at high recall
  • Prefer ACORN-1 and stitch-diskann in overlap scenario for balanced thoughput and recall; ACORN and post-filter HNSW are robust for large label space or high k; avoid UNG as query becoms more complex causing QPS/recall degradation
  • At low k(e.g., recall@1), post-filter methods and UNG are competitive with QPS; at higher k(e.g., recall@100), prefer UNG/ACORN for containment/equality and DiskANN/ACORN for overlap
  • If indexing time or memory is constrained, HNSW, IVFPQ, and ACORN-1 build quickly, are more memory-efficient, and offer greater flexibility as base labels change. Methods that rely on predicate label distribution(e.g., UNG, DiskANN variant) may incur higher build costs.

References

  • Source code on Github
  • SHI J, CAI Y, ZHENG W. Filtered Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search: A Unified Benchmark and Systematic Experimental Study [Experiment, Analysis & Benchmark][EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-10-06]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2509.07789.

entry.title: FusedANN, Convexified Hybrid ANN via Attribute-Vector Fusion
entry.content:
Summary

   We introduce FusedANN(Fused Attribute-Vector Nearest Neighbor), a geometric framework that elevates filtering into ANN optimization constraints and introduces a convex fused space cia a Lagrangian-like relaxation. Our method jointly embeds attributes and vectors through transformer-based convexification, turing hard filters into continuous, weighted penalities that preserve top-k semantics while enbaling efficient approximate search.
   FusedANN uses a filter-centric vector indexing method, a mathematically grounded transformation, that unifies attribute filtering with vector similarity search, analogous to introducing a Lagrange multipllier into a convex objective and fusion of information signals. A unfied space where: (1) the dimensionality remains unchanged, (2) the distance ordering of elements with identical attributes is preserved, and (3) a tunable parameter increases distances between differently attributed elements.

Details

Preliminaries

   (Definition) Record Set: A record is an F + 1-tuple vector oiF=[v(oi),f(1)(oi),...,f(F)(oi)]o^{F}_{i} = [v(o_{i}), f^{(1)}(o_{i}), ..., f^{(F)}(o_{i})]oiF​=[v(oi​),f(1)(oi​),...,f(F)(oi​)], where v(oi) inRdv(o_{i}) \ in R^{d}v(oi​) inRd is a content vector, and f(j)(oi)inRmjf^{(j)}(o_{i}) in R^{m_{j}}f(j)(oi​)inRmj​ is the j-th attribute vetcor in a metric space. The record set D(F)={o1F,...,onF}D^{(F)} = \left \{ o_{1}^{F}, ..., o_{n}^{F} \right \}D(F)={o1F​,...,onF​} containing nnn records of dimension FFF. Let χ={v(oi)∣oi∈DF}\chi = \left \{ v(o_{i}) | o_{i} \in D^{F} \right \}χ={v(oi​)∣oi​∈DF} and, for each j∈[1,F],Fj={f(j)(oi)∣oi∈DF}j \in [1,F], F_{j} = \left \{ f^{(j)}(o_{i}) | o_{i} \in D^{F} \right \}j∈[1,F],Fj​={f(j)(oi​)∣oi​∈DF}

   (Definition) Hybrid Query with Monotone Attribute Priority: Given a set of records D(F)D^{(F)}D(F) and a query q=[v(q),Fq(1),...,Fq(F)]q = [v(q), F^{(1)}_{q}, ..., F_{q}^{(F)}]q=[v(q),Fq(1)​,...,Fq(F)​], let Fπ(1)≻⋯≻Fπ(F)\mathcal{F}_\pi(1) \succ \cdots \succ \mathcal{F}_\pi(F)Fπ​(1)≻⋯≻Fπ​(F) be the attribute priority order (with the content as the lowest priority). For any candidate set S⊆D(F)S \subseteq D^{(F)}S⊆D(F) of size kkk, let

μS(j)=1k∑o∈Sσj(f(j)(o),Fq(j)),VarS(j)=1k∑o∈S[σj(f(j)(o),Fq(j))−μS(j)]2(3)\mu_S^{(j)} = \frac{1}{k} \sum_{o \in S} \sigma_j \big( f^{(j)}(o), F_q^{(j)} \big), \quad \text{Var}_S^{(j)} = \frac{1}{k} \sum_{o \in S} \Big[ \sigma_j \big( f^{(j)}(o), F_q^{(j)} \big) - \mu_S^{(j)} \Big]^2 \tag{3}μS(j)​=k1​o∈S∑​σj​(f(j)(o),Fq(j)​),VarS(j)​=k1​o∈S∑​[σj​(f(j)(o),Fq(j)​)−μS(j)​]2(3)

   where σj\sigma_{j}σj​ is a distance metric on FjF_{j}Fj​, which we assume to be Euclidean in this study. We say S satisfies monotone attribute priority if: VarSπ(1)≤⋯≤VarSπ(F)\text{Var}_S^{\pi(1)} \leq \cdots \leq \text{Var}_S^{\pi(F)}VarSπ(1)​≤⋯≤VarSπ(F)​. The hybrid query returns the set S∗S^{*}S∗ of size k that minimizeds the mean distances subject to monotone attribute priority:

S∗=arg⁡min⁡S⊆D(F)∣S∣=kmonotone attribute priority(μS(π(1)),…,μS(π(F)),1k∑o∈Sρ(v(q),v(o)))(4)S^* = \arg \min_{\substack{S \subseteq \mathcal{D}^{(F)} \\ |S| = k \\ \text{monotone attribute priority}}} \left( \mu_S^{(\pi(1))}, \ldots, \mu_S^{(\pi(F))}, \frac{1}{k} \sum_{o \in S} \rho(v(q), v(o)) \right) \tag{4}S∗=argS⊆D(F)∣S∣=kmonotone attribute priority​min​(μS(π(1))​,…,μS(π(F))​,k1​o∈S∑​ρ(v(q),v(o)))(4)

   in lexicographic order, i.e., by first minimizing the mean distance for the highest-priority attribute, then the next in order, and finally the average content distance p (content vector distance metric). Eq. 4 relaxes filters, prioritizing exact matches on higher-priority attributes to fill k; it still short, it fills the rest via nearest attribute clusters(k-NN)——a native expansion unlike classical filtered ANN, which requires exact metches and offers no fallback.

FusedANN Framework

   Model Overview Our framework enables hybrid search by fusing content and attribute information in a way that gives explict control over their relative influence. Given a content vector v(oi)∈Rdv(o_{i}) \in R^{d}v(oi​)∈Rd and an attribute vector f(oi)∈Rmf(o_{i}) \in R^{m}f(oi​)∈Rm with m<dm \lt dm<d, we partition v(oi)v(o_{i})v(oi​) into d/md/md/m blocks v(1),...,v(⌈d/m⌉)v^{(1)}, ..., v^{(\left \lceil d/m \right \rceil )}v(1),...,v(⌈d/m⌉), each in RmR^{m}Rm. We then define the tranformation:

Ψ(v,f,α,β)=[v(1)−αfβ,…,v(⌈d/m⌉)−αfβ]∈Rd\Psi(v, f, \alpha, \beta) = \left[ \frac{v^{(1)} - \alpha f}{\beta}, \ldots, \frac{v^{(\lceil d/m \rceil)} - \alpha f}{\beta} \right] \in \mathbb{R}^dΨ(v,f,α,β)=[βv(1)−αf​,…,βv(⌈d/m⌉)−αf​]∈Rd

   where α>1\alpha \gt 1α>1 and β>1\beta \gt 1β>1 are scaling parameters. If m∤dm \nmid dm∤d, the last partition is transformed using the attribute sub-vector, so without losing generality, we assume m∣dm \mid dm∣d.
   The parameter α\alphaα increases the separation between records with different attribute values, while β\betaβ compresses all distances to regularize the fused space(see Fig. 2(a)). In practice, α\alphaα and β\betaβ should be chosen large enough to ensure sufficient separation and regularization, but not so large as to introduce unnecessary computational complexity.

   Alg. 1 shows the building of the used space and index, query generation, and result processing; as in line 15, we choose to include approximate attributes or only exact ones. At query time, the query q=[v(q),Fq]q = [v(q), F_{q}]q=[v(q),Fq​] is transformed as q′=Ψ(v(q),Fq,α,β)q^{'} = \Psi(v(q), F_{q}, \alpha, \beta)q′=Ψ(v(q),Fq​,α,β). For each attribute aaam we define RaR_{a}Ra​ as the radius of the smallest hypersphere containing all transformed records with attribute aaa and bbb, and γa=min⁡b≠admin⁡(a,b)Ra−1\gamma_a = \min_{b \neq a} \frac{d_{\min}(a, b)}{R_a} - 1γa​=minb=a​Ra​dmin​(a,b)​−1 as the cluster speration metric. NaN_{a}Na​ denotes the number of records with attribute aaa, and NNN is the total number of records. These statistics are used to determine the optimal candidate set size k′k^{'}k′ when processing queries.

   Our theoretical analysis( reference the paper for details ) proves that the transformation Ψ\PsiΨ has several key properties: (i)it preserves the order of k-NN within clusters of records with identical attributes, anabling accurate content-based ranking within attribute groups; (ii) it increases separation between records with different attributes proportionally to α\alphaα, improving filtering effectiveness; and (iii) it scales all distance by 1/β1/ \beta1/β, controlling overall concentration. These properties enable principled parameter selection: α\alphaα shuold satisfy α>β⋅δmax⁡σmin⁡⋅d/m⋅(1+ϵf⋅βδmax⁡)\alpha > \frac{\beta \cdot \delta_{\max}}{\sigma _{\min} \cdot \sqrt{d/m}} \cdot \left(1 + \frac{\epsilon_f \cdot \beta}{\delta_{\max}}\right)α>σmin​⋅d/m​β⋅δmax​​⋅(1+δmax​ϵf​⋅β​) where δmax\delta_{max}δmax​ is the maximum content distance and σmin\sigma_{min}σmin​ is the minimum attribute distance, where β>σmaxϵf\beta \gt \frac {\sigma_{max}} {\epsilon_{f}}β>ϵf​σmax​​ ensures intra-cluster distances are bounded by ϵf\epsilon_{f}ϵf​

Multi-Attributes and Attribute Hierarchy

   In this section, we extend FusedANN to elegantly handle multiple attributes by applying our transformation sequentially, creating a natural hierarchy that controls their relative importantce. In this section, we also assume ∀j∈[1,F]:mj∣d\forall j \in [1, F]: m_j \mid d∀j∈[1,F]:mj​∣d.
   Recursive Transformation. The key insight of our approache is remarkably simple, by applying the transformation Ψ\PsiΨ repeatedly for each attribute, we create a unified space that respects attribute priorities. Starting with the original content vector v0=v(oi)v_{0} = v(o_{i})v0​=v(oi​), we apply each transformation sequence:

vj=Ψj(vj−1,f(j)(oi),αj,βj) for j=1,2,…,F(6)v_j = \Psi_j \big( v_{j-1}, f^{(j)}(o_i), \alpha_j, \beta_j \big) \text{ for } j = 1, 2, \ldots, F \tag{6}vj​=Ψj​(vj−1​,f(j)(oi​),αj​,βj​) for j=1,2,…,F(6)

   where each transformation uses its own parameters αj>1\alpha_{j} \gt 1αj​>1 and βj>1\beta_{j} \gt 1βj​>1. The final transformed vector vFv_{F}vF​ integrates information from all attributes.(See Fig. 2(b))
   For multi-attribute retrieval, we extend Alg.1 to apply transformation sequentially for each attribute(Alg. 3). The key difference are: (1) transformation are applied iteratively over all records for each attribute j∈{1,...,F}j \in \left \{ 1,...,F \right \}j∈{1,...,F}; (2) the optimal parameters α\alphaα and β\betaβ of subsequent fused space is computed for each new attribute transformation iteratively; and (3) the candidate set size k′k^{'}k′ is determined using Thm. 11, reflecting the narrow effect of multiple filters.

   Attribute Updates in FusedANN: FusedANN handles these scenarios efficiently without requiring complete index reconstruction. When adding a new attribute with the highest priority, we simply apply an additional transformation to the already vectors. For attributes inserted at lower priorities, a partial reconstruction is needed, but only from the insertion point forward. Simlilarly, when the priority orderings change, we need only to recompute transformation beyond the point where the old and new orderings differ: j=min⁡{k:∀i≥k,π(i)=π′(i)}j = \min \{ k: \forall i \geq k, \pi(i) = \pi'(i) \}j=min{k:∀i≥k,π(i)=π′(i)}. This limites the computational complexity to O(N.j.d)O(N.j.d)O(N.j.d), substantially lower than the full recompuation, since oonly a partial reconstruction is required for indexes lower than jjj (See Fig. 2c).

Range Filter on FusedANN

   Our fused space has an elegant geometric characteristics
that allows us instead of indexing the pints and the create feasible range at the runtime, index range queries and approximate nearest range query at runtime. A range query can be defined as a cylinder in the fused space tha precisely captures all potential eligable nearest points to q within [l,r]. The acis of the cylinder(line segment) obtains by Ψ\PsiΨ to the boundaries: pl:=Ψ(q,l,α,β), pu:=Ψ(q,u,α,β)p_l := \Psi(q, l, \alpha, \beta),\ p_u := \Psi(q, u, \alpha, \beta)pl​:=Ψ(q,l,α,β), pu​:=Ψ(q,u,α,β) parameterized as L(Q,t)=(1−t)⋅pl+t⋅puL(Q,t) = (1-t) \cdot p_{l} + t \cdot p_{u}L(Q,t)=(1−t)⋅pl​+t⋅pu​, where t∈[0,1]t \in [0,1]t∈[0,1] (LQL_{Q}LQ​ in short)
   For attribute values f∈[l,u]f \in [l,u]f∈[l,u] in range-filtered query, the transformed query points pf:=Ψ(q,f,α,β)p_{f} := \Psi(q, f, \alpha, \beta)pf​:=Ψ(q,f,α,β) lie exactly on LQL_{Q}LQ​ in the fused embedding space. Moreover, the vertical distance from LQL_{Q}LQ​ measures how well qqq is approximated and scales with its vector similarity. Geometrically, each range-filtered query maps to a cylinder in the fused space. This relationship offers a unified gemetric framweork for jointly handling attribute range filtering and vector similarity. Formally, if v≠qv \neq qv=q, the transformation of vf=Ψ(v,f,α,β)v_{f} = \Psi(v, f, \alpha, \beta)vf​=Ψ(v,f,α,β) vertical distance to LQL_{Q}LQ​ is exactly ∣∣v−q∣∣β\frac {||v-q||} {\beta}β∣∣v−q∣∣​. Leveraging this traceabiity, we define a sylindrical range query by introducing a radius-r query clinder around LQ:Tube(Q,r)={z∈Rd∣min⁡t∈[0,1]∥z−L(Q,t)∥≤r}L_Q: \text{Tube}(Q, r) = \left\{ z \in \mathbb{R}^d \mid \min_{t \in [0,1]} \| z - L(Q, t) \| \leq r \right\}LQ​:Tube(Q,r)={z∈Rd∣mint∈[0,1]​∥z−L(Q,t)∥≤r} (See Fig. 2d)
   During indexing, we create cylinders cover the fused space with an optimal radius r=Rr = Rr=R. This radius——ensuring high-probability top−k′top-k^{'}top−k′ reacall is precomputed for each indexed line segment using the k′−thk^{'}-thk′−th neighbor distance, dataset size, and similarity distribution. To efficiently cover the fused space with cylinder defined by pairs of offline data, which is crucial for fast retrival, we use an adaptive sampling strategy during indexing over the fused space. At query time, for a top-k query Q′=(q′,l′,u′)Q^{'} = (q^{'}, l^{'}, u^{'})Q′=(q′,l′,u′) (where k<k′k \lt k^{'}k<k′), we must find the nearest indexed cylindrical Tube(Q, R) with Hausdorff distance closest axis LQL_{Q}LQ​ to LQ′L_{Q^{'}}LQ′​. The gap between kkk and k′k^{'}k′ guarantees high recall by providing the flexibility needed to approximate LQ′L_{Q^{'}}LQ′​ with Tube(Q,R). The base radius RRR is stored with each line in the index and dtermines the extent of the corresponding cylindrical region on the maximum radius coverage.
   Hierarchical Indexing Framework. We briefly sketch the idea here. To enable efficient range queries in the fused space, we introduce a hierarchical framework of three levels in Alg. 2.

  1. Leveraing the guaranteed sample complexity, which is derived from the data pattern and range distributions, we strategically takes a sufficiently large sample from the scope of possible range queries(Fig. 3a). This approache ensures that any potential query line will closely match a pre-indexed line, which minimizing storage and accounting for the varying importance of regions in the fused space.
  1. We build a specialized line similarity index that efficiently identifies the pre-indexed line most similar to LQL_{Q}LQ​ (Fig. 3b). Our line similarity cmobines directional, positional, and length components to provide strong correlation with the Hasudorff distance between lines(Fig. 3c). Note that ANN indexing of a finite LQL_{Q}LQ​ within the cylinder defining the approximate range query differs from the approximate nearest-neighbor methods, which assume inifinite lines. Our line index organize lines by their direction vectors and then by their spatical locations. The directional partitioning creates anagular cells on the unit sphere with resolution vvv (Fig. 3d/e), assigning each line to a cell based on its orientation. Within each directional group, we further organize the lines using spatical indices based on their mid-points(Alg. 5). This hierarchical structure enables logarithmic time retrical of the indexed line most similar to any query line(Alg. 6).
  1. For each indexed line L∗L^{*}L∗, we construct a cylindrical index that partitions the points by cylindrical coordinates relative to L∗L^{*}L∗, allowing efficient retrieval of the most similar points(Fig. 3f). Every line segment is divided into sections of length of the radius(sub-lines), utilizing radius-based indices per section(with respect to the perpendicular distance to its respective section line segment) in a ball tree structure. This supports rapid retrieval of points whtin a certain range, while reducing excess calculations(Fig. 3e).

   Adaptive Error Compensation. When approximating a query line with a similar indexed line, adjust the search radius and candidate count to offset the error per the lines’ Hausdorff distance. Specifically, the radius of the cylinder increases with the Hausdorff distance between the query and the indexed lines, and the candidate count is scaled by a data-dependent factor reflecting local line density. The density is calcuclated by taking the ratio of the number of points containsed within a cylindrical region to the volume of that area. Therefore, in areas of higher density, more candidates must be considered to maintain an equivalent probability of identifying the actucal nearest neighbors. Thus, when building the index, we assume a maximum Hasudorff distance supported by the pre-indexed data, add it to the optimal radius, and then construct the index. At query time, if the radius for the query if below the maximum RRR, we apply these adjusted values of kkk and the serach radius to ensure robust retrieval performace.(Fig. 3e)
   Complete Range query Algorithm and Complexity. Our range query processing first transforms the query into a line segment in the fused space, the efficiently locates the most similar indexed line via a hierarchical line index in logarithmic time. The search radius and the candidae count are adjusted based on the Hausdorff distance between the query and the indexed lines. A cylinder search retrieves candidates within the adjusted radius, which are then filtered by attribute range and ranked by distance to the query. Alg. 2 achieves O(log⁡N+klog⁡(1/ϵ)+klog⁡k)O(\log N + k \log(1/\epsilon) + k \log k)O(logN+klog(1/ϵ)+klogk) expected query time, enabling efficient queries on very large datasets.

References

  • HEIDARI A, ZHANG W, XIONG Y. FusedANN: Convexified Hybrid ANN via Attribute-Vector Fusion[EB/OL]. (2025). https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.19767.

entry.title: DIGRA, A Dynamic Graph Indexing for ANNS with Range Filter
entry.content:
Overviw

   In this paper, we propse DIGRA, a novel graph index for range-filtered ANNS. DIGRA supports efficient dynamic updates while maintaining a balance among query efficiency, update efficiency, indexing cost, and result quality. Our approach introduces a dynamic multi-way tree structure combined with carefully integrated ANNS indices to handle range filtered ANNS efficiency. We employ a lazy weight-based update mechanism to significantly reduce update costs and adopt optimzed choice of ANNS index to lower construction and update overhead.

Details

Problem Definition

   Given a set XXX and a distance function δ\deltaδ: X×X→RX \times X \rightarrow RX×X→R, the pair (X,δ)(X, \delta)(X,δ) is called a metric space.
   Definition(NNS with Range filter): Let (x,δ)(x, \delta)(x,δ) be a metric space. Given an object set O⊆XO \subseteq XO⊆X where each object o∈Oo \in Oo∈O has an attribute ϕ(o)\phi(o)ϕ(o), a query q∈Xq \in Xq∈X, a positive integer kkk, and a range Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r], the NNS with range filter returns the nearest neighbors to qqq on δ\deltaδ within the set OQ={o∈O∣o∈O,ϕ(o)∈Q}O_{Q}=\left \{ o \in O | o \in O, \phi(o) \in Q \right \}OQ​={o∈O∣o∈O,ϕ(o)∈Q}, i.e., the objects satisfying the range filter on attribute ϕ\phiϕ.(Here, we focus on Approximate version and use Euclidean distance mtrics)

DIGRA

Index Structure

   The proposed DIGRA index uses a multi-way tree structure TTT to manage the entire object set. The tree structure TTT is similar to a B-Tree, where each node can store up to BBB children, and it separates its children by storing several key values. For each object ooo, we use attribute value ϕ(o)\phi(o)ϕ(o) as the key. For a node in TTT with ttt keys and t+1t+1t+1 children, we use u.child[i] to represent its i-th child, and u.key[i] to represent its i-th stored key value. For node uuu, we maintain an NSW-style search graph represented as u.Gu.Gu.G. It is constructed for set OuO_{u}Ou​, the object set containing all the objects stored in the subtree rooted at uuu. To speed up the search, we additionally maintain an entry node for node uuu, represented as u.enu.enu.en, which is a leaf node in the substree of uuu to help obtain the search entry in the current graph u.Gu.Gu.G. Each node in TTT further stores a value layerlayerlayer to indicate its level, with leaf nodes having a layer value of 0. For non-leaf node uuu, its layer value is the layer value of its child plus one. Similar to B-tree, DIGRA gurantees that all child nodes of any given node are assigned identical layer values. An important property of the multi-way tree structure in DIGRA is that we keep the tree TTT weight-balanced, whose definition is as follows:
   Definition 3.1(Weight Balance) Let TTT be a multi-way tree with a branching factor BBB. The tree TTT is said to be weight balanced if: For every non-root node uuu in TTT at layer iii, the size of uuu, denoted by size(u), satisfies Bi4≤size(u)≤Bi\frac{B^{i}}{4} \le size(u) \le B^{i}4Bi​≤size(u)≤Bi, where size(u) is defined as the number of leaf nodes in the subtree rooted at uuu.
   Lemma: The height of TTT is O(logN)O(logN)O(logN)
   It’s straightforward to verify using the weight balance condition and thus ommited. As to be datailed in later section, for any qrbitrary range Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r] on the attribute ϕ\phiϕ, there exists at most two nodes uuu and vvv in the tree TTT such that the union of their associated object sets, Ou∪OvO_{u} \cup O_{v}Ou​∪Ov​, includes all objects OQO_{Q}OQ​ that satisfy the range QQQ.
   One of our key observations is that out multi-way inherently includes a hierarchical structure. Consequently, we maintain an NSW index at each node without introducing an additional hierarchical layer.

Index Construction

   The key idea of DIGRA index construction is to build a dynamic multi-way tree from the bottom up, where each node maintains an NSW graph covering the objects in its subtree. We start by placing data objects into leaf nodes and constructing an NSW graph at each leaf. These leaf nodes are then grouped into higher-level nodes, merging the prebuilt graphs of their children to avoid rebuilding from scartch. This process continues iteratively until the entire tree is formed.

   Alg.3 shows the pseudo-code for building the DIGRA index. We first create leaf nodes for all objects and push them into Q0Q_{0}Q0​ (Lines 2-4). From bottom to top, we iteratively extract branch nodes from the queue of the lower layer as children of nwely created node, construct a graph on the new node, and push it into the queue of the new layer(Lines 5-13). The branch is usually set to be ⌈B/2⌉\left \lceil B/2 \right \rceil⌈B/2⌉ here. This process repeats until only one node remains in the new layer. We return this node as the root(Line 14).
   In Alg.4, we show the steps of building the NSW index for node u. First, we set entry and layer for u(Line 1). As we can obtain a multi-layer structure by visiting any path from a leaf node to u, we randomly select a leaf node from the subtree of u as its entry en. Then, we need to build the NSW for the new node by identifying edges for each o in the subtree of u(Lines 2-10). Reacalling the process of building NSW, it first finds the cloest efconef_{con}efcon​ vertices in the graph for each vertex. If all efconsef_{cons}efcons​ vertices are selected as neighbors of this vertex, the graph density will be too high. Hence, through prunepruneprune in Algo.2, only MMM vertices are chosen as neighbors. The intutition behind pruning is that if two vertices are close to each other, there is likely to be an edge between them, so we only keep one of them to be a neighbor to sparsify the graph and ensure search performance. Yet, since he NSW is built incrementally starting from an empty graph, vertices inserted earlier will have difficulty finding vertices inserted later as neighbors. To overcome this, for each ooo, we first independently find efconef_{con}efcon​ neighbors and select MMM edges through pruning in the graph of each child of uuu except the child that ooo belongs to(Lines 5-10). This allows each vertex to obtain information from the entire set OuO_{u}Ou​, ensuring search performance. Note that since HvH_{v}Hv​ is an implict hierarchical NSW structure, we use findEntry(Hu,o)findEntry(H_{u},o)findEntry(Hu​,o) to search HvH_{v}Hv​ from the top to bottom to find the entry closer to ooo, which is the same as HNSW, thereby improving the speed(Line 7).[ Ref Example3.4 in the paper for illustraction ]

Query Processing

   Given a range filter, the main idea of DIGRA for query processing is to identify a subset of nodes whose subtrees collectively contain OQO_{Q}OQ​, the set of objects satisfying the filter. We then run ANNS on the NSW index at each chosen node, merge the partial results, and return the top-k answers. As we will show, our approach can locate O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) such nodes, ensuring that only objects in [l,r][l,r][l,r] are included. However, querying all O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) nodes still incurs relatively high costs. To reduce these costs, we propose an alternative solution requiring at most two nodes that jointly cover OQO_{Q}OQ​. While this introduces a bounded number of out-of-range objects, it significantly improces query efficiency compared to the disjoint exact coverage solution requiring O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) searches.
   Definition(Disjoint Exact Coverage) A set of nodes C={u1,u2,...,ux}C = \left \{ u_{1}, u_{2}, ..., u_{x} \right \}C={u1​,u2​,...,ux​} in tree TTT disjointly covers an arbitrary range Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r] exactly if: ⋃u∈COu=OQ\bigcup_{u \in C}^{}O_{u}=O_{Q}⋃u∈C​Ou​=OQ​ and Oui∩Ouj=∅O_{ui} \cap O_{uj} = \emptysetOui​∩Ouj​=∅ for all i≠ji \neq ji=j, where OQO_{Q}OQ​ is the set of objects with attribute ϕ\phiϕ falling into QQQ, and OuO_{u}Ou​ is the set of objects in the subtree rooted at uuu.
   Lemma(3.8): DIGRA can identify a set CCC of O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) nodes in TTT that disjointly and exactly covers an arbitrary query range Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r] on the attribute ϕ\phiϕ in O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) time.
   Using Lemma 3.8, we can perform an ANNS on the NSW graph u.Gu.Gu.G for each node u∈Cu \in Cu∈C, merge the results and return the top-k answers. Yet, this still incurs high query costs due to O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) value on ϕ\phiϕ out of the range [l,r][l,r][l,r] and then prune them to save costs. The key is to bound such irrelevant objects. Thus, we prose the α-approximate range coverage.
   Theorem 3.10: For any range Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r]Q=[l,r], we can find up to two disjoint nodes uuu and vvv in TTT within O(BlogN)O(BlogN)O(BlogN) time whose range Q′=[l′,r′]Q^{'} = [l^{'}, r^{'}]Q′=[l′,r′] is a 4B-approximate coverage of QQQ, i.e., ∣Ou∪Ov∣/∣OQ∣≤4B|O_{u} \cup O_{v}|/|O_{Q}| \le 4B∣Ou​∪Ov​∣/∣OQ​∣≤4B.
   Alg.5 shows the pseudo-code for answering a query. First, we find the lowest node hNodehNodehNode that covers the range [l,r][l,r][l,r] in the tree in O(logN)O(logN)O(logN) time(Line 1). Then: (i) If hNode.layer=0hNode.layer = 0hNode.layer=0, the range covers a single leaf, so we directly return that leaf’s entry(Line 2). Next, we find lIdlIdlId and rIdrIdrId, the ids of the children which contain lll and rrr using the findPositionfindPositionfindPosition function(Lines 3-4), and check the relationship between lIdlIdlId and rIdrIdrId to determine if hNodehNodehNode can serve as an approximate range coverage(Line 6). (ii) if range [l,r][l,r][l,r] fully covers at least one child of hNode, i.e. rId>lId+1rId \gt lId + 1rId>lId+1, we perform ANNS on hNodehNodehNode(Lines 6-9). (iii) Otherwise, we search with two nodes(Lines 11-20). Specically, we use the function findNodefindNodefindNode (Lines 11-12) to locate two nodes, each having at least one child covered by [l,r][l,r][l,r]. From the lId/rIdlId/rIdlId/rId child of hNodehNodehNode, findNodefindNodefindNode recursively visists the right/left-most children until they are fully covered by [l,r][l,r][l,r], taking O(logN)O(logN)O(logN) time by the tree’s height. In addition, we optimize NSW search by leveraging a hierarchical structure. First, we use the hierarchy to find entries closer to qqq, to accelerate search convergence(Lines 7, 12-13). Second, to enhance the search quality, we expance edge coverage by incorporating edges from the same vertices at the graphs on the children(Lines 9, 16-17) and the ancestor(Line 18) of the nodes to be searched. Since there can be two search entries, and not all vertices in the graph satisfy the range filter, we use the RangeGreedySearchRangeGreedySearchRangeGreedySearch algorithm, similar to Algo.1, but two modifications: (i) initialization use multiple entries, and (ii) a vertex vvv is added to the set WWW only if l≤ϕ(v)≤rl \le \phi(v) \le rl≤ϕ(v)≤r.

Index Update

   The key to updating the DIGRA index is to ensure that while maintaining the tree’s balance condition, the ANN index maintained by each node remains up-to-date and consistent with the updated set in the corresponding subtree.
   Our update algorithms preserve the tree’s balance and the ANN index’s consistency, both crucial for efficient and accurate queries. They operate in two steps: (i) descend from the root to locate the node needing an update, refreshing each affected node’s ANN index along the way; and (ii) backtrack to detect balance violations, rebalancing vis split or merge when necessary. The first step costs no more than updating O(logN)O(logN)O(logN) vanilla NSW graphs, since a balanced tree’s search path is O(logN)O(logN)O(logN). Hence, efficient updates require bounding the second step’s overhead. Splitting or merging a node uuu of size size(u)size(u)size(u) takes O(size(u))⋅cupdO(size(u)) \cdot c_{upd}O(size(u))⋅cupd​. Frequent rebanlancing can be costly when size(u)size(u)size(u) reaches O(n)O(n)O(n).
   To address this, we employ a lazy update mechanism that permits each initially balanced node uuu to tolerate Ω(size(u))\Omega (size(u))Ω(size(u)) updates before triggering a rebalance. This strategy bounds the amortized overhead for each update to O(ccpulogN)O(c_{cpu}logN)O(ccpu​logN) time, significantly reducing the update cost. Next, we show the details of the update algorithms.
   Insertion of DIGRA index: Algo.6 outlines the pseudo-code of insertion. If the current tree is empty, we create a new node and make it the root node(Lines 1-2). Otherwise, starting from the root, we insert a new object ooo recursively(Line 4). We first find the position in the tree to insert the new node, create a leaf node and insert this leaf node into the corresponding position(Lines 11-14). Then we insert ooo into the graph of each node on the backtracking path(Lines 15-26).
   Inserting ooo into a graph follows the standard NSW insertion process, using the GraphInsertionGraphInsertionGraphInsertion algorithm described in Algo. 2.
   Next, if any child of the node has greater than B children after the insertion, we split the child(Line 17). The spliting process is similar to B-tree spliting. When we split the node n1, we divide the key and children of n1 into two parts, keeping one part for itself and moving the other part becoming the new node n2, and insert n2 after n1(Lines 18-21). As the subtree of n1 and n2 changed, we rebuild n1.Gn1.Gn1.G and n2.Gn2.Gn2.G by refresh(Line 22). When the insertion finishes, if the number of children of the root exceeds BBB, we split the root and make it a child of the new root node(Lines 5-8).

   Deletion of DIGRA index: Algo.7 outlines the pseudo-code for dealing with deletions. We first apply the same marking method as in NSW. We mark the object as deleted(Line 1). When doing RangeGreedySearchRangeGreedySearchRangeGreedySearch on any graph in query processing, we will put vertices marked for deletion into the search queue CCC, but not into the result set WWW. This completes the deletion of ooo in all NSW graphs. Next, we will focus on the cahnge in tree strctures. We proceed with the recursive deletion process starting from the root(Line 2). We find the corresponding leaf node and delete it(Lines 5-6). After deleting the leaf node, we need to check if the number of children of child[id] of the backtracked node is less than ⌈B/2⌉\left \lceil B/2 \right \rceil⌈B/2⌉. If so, we look for a sibling node whose number of children is greater than ⌈B/2⌉\left \lceil B/2 \right \rceil⌈B/2⌉. If we find such a node, we transfer a child from the sibling node and refresh the graphs of the two nodes(Lines 9-17). If we cannot find such a sibling node, we merge it with noe of its siblings on the left or right(Lines 18-19). When merging n1 and n2, we append the children and keys of n2 and n1(Lines 21-22). Then we remove n2, and rebuild the graph of n1(Line 24). Finally, if the root node has only one child left after deletion, we will remove the root node and set its child as the new node(Line 3).

   Lazy Update: The B-tree only limits the number of branches and is not a very effective balancing strategy in extreme cases. Consider a B-tree with B=3B = 3B=3. Suppose a node uuu has two children v1v_{1}v1​ and v2v_{2}v2​, where all nodes in the subtree of child v1v_{1}v1​ have 2 branches, and all nodes in the subtree of child v2v_{2}v2​ have 3 branches. Thus we no longer have size(u)=O(size(v1))size(u) = O(size(v_{1}))size(u)=O(size(v1​)), since size(v1)=2isize(v_{1}) = 2^{i}size(v1​)=2i and size(u)=3i+2isize(u) = 3^{i} + 2^{i}size(u)=3i+2i. This makes it difficult to obtain an α-approximate range coverage. To improve this, we trigger a split or merge when the balance condition introduced in 3.1 is not met. We replace the condition at line 17 in Algo. 6 with the check if the size of the node is greater than BiB^{i}Bi, and replace the condition at lines 9,10,14 in Algo.7 with the check if the size to the node is less or greater than Bi/4B^{i}/4Bi/4, where iii is the layer of the node. To balance the tree, we do not need to perform split and merge on all of the nodes every update. According to the previous work [1], if we use such a balancing strategy, we have the following therorem: It takes Ω(size(u))\Omega(size(u))Ω(size(u)) insertions or deletions to make the balanced node uuu after a merge or split operation unbalanced again.

Future work

  1. Memry limited method: our method consists of tree structure and graph index. For the graph index that cannot fit entirely into memory, one way is to store the index on disk(i.e., Diskann). Another way is to partition a dataset into multiple clsuters and store them on disk and retrieve the needed partitions into memory when necessary for query processing
  2. Concurrent updates: Although DIGRA is designed for single-threaded updatesm extending it to a multi-threaded environment could serve as a future research direction. The NSW of each node in DIGRA is independent of others. Additionally, if the tree structure remains unchanged, the NSW at one node will not be affected by changes at other nodes. Hence, we can treat the NSW as a whole and simply lock the node when updating it. When there are modifications to the tree structure, we may adopt a similar locking method as in B±tree, the advanced B±tree applies write locks only for structure modifications, while DIGRA requires locking when updating the NSW. This presents challenges for implementing an efficient locking strategy. Additionally, when processing queries synchronously during update, DIGRA needs to ensure the consistency of the NSWs stored in internal nodes, which differs from B±trees that only consider consistency among the elements stored in leaf nodes.

References

  1. Lars Arge and Jeffrey Scott Vitter. 2003. Optimal External Memory Interval Management. SIAM J. Comput. 32, 6 (2003),1488–1508
  2. Source code on Github
  3. JIANG M, YANG Z, ZHANG F, 等. DIGRA: A Dynamic Graph Indexing for Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search with Range Filter[J]. Proceedings of the ACM on Management of Data, 2025, 3(3): 1-26.

entry.title: RWalks, Ramdom Walks as Attribute Diffusers for Filtered Vector Search
entry.content:
Summary

   Existing solutions for filtered vector search are either: (1)ad-hoc, using existing techniques with no or minor modifications; (2)hybrid, providing specialized indexing and/or search algorithms. We xhow that neither is satisfactory and propose RWalks, an index-agnostic graph-based filtered vector search method that efficiently supports both filtered and unfiltered vector search. The key design features of RWalks include:

  1. A hybrid distance metric
  2. An index-agnostic attribute enrichment process
  3. A distance pruning heuristic

Details

Definitions

   We consider a dataset S={VC1,VC2,...,VCn}S = \left \{ V_{C1},V_{C2},..., V_{Cn}\right \}S={VC1​,VC2​,...,VCn​} consisting of nnn objects in a d-dimensional space. Each object VCiV_{Ci}VCi​ is associated with a p-dimensional attribute vector ACi∈{0,1}pA_{Ci} \in \left \{ 0,1 \right \}^{p}ACi​∈{0,1}p
   Definition 1. An attribute vector ACi∈{0,1}pA_{Ci} \in \left \{ 0,1 \right \}^{p}ACi​∈{0,1}p is a one-hot vector, where the presence or absence of an attribute for object VciV_{ci}Vci​ is denoted with a value of 1 or 0 respectively. The attribute vector of a query object VQV_{Q}VQ​ is denoted as AQ∈{0,1}pA_{Q} \in \left \{ 0,1 \right \}^{p}AQ​∈{0,1}p
   Definition 2. A filter is a function F:{0,1}p×{0,1}p→{0,1}F: \left \{ 0,1 \right \}^{p} \times \left \{ 0,1 \right \}^{p} \to \left \{ 0,1 \right \}F:{0,1}p×{0,1}p→{0,1} that checks if a data point’s attribute vector ACiA_{Ci}ACi​ satisfies a query’s attribute vector AQA_{Q}AQ​. Common filteres include(jjj is the attribute position / 1≤j≤p1 \le j \le p1≤j≤p):

  • Equality: Feq(ACi,AQ)=1  ⟺  ∀j, (AQ[j]=1  ⟹  ACi[j]=1)\mathbb{F}_\text{eq}(A_{Ci}, A_Q) = 1 \iff \forall j,\ (A_Q[j] = 1 \implies A_{Ci}[j] = 1)Feq​(ACi​,AQ​)=1⟺∀j, (AQ​[j]=1⟹ACi​[j]=1)
  • AND: Fand(ACi,AQ)=1  ⟺  ∀j, (AQ[j]=1  ⟹  ACi[j]=1)\mathbb{F}_{\text{and}}(A_{Ci}, A_Q) = 1 \iff \forall j,\ (A_Q[j] = 1 \implies A_{Ci}[j] = 1)Fand​(ACi​,AQ​)=1⟺∀j, (AQ​[j]=1⟹ACi​[j]=1)
  • OR: For(ACi,AQ)=1  ⟺  ∃j, (AQ[j]=1∧ACi[j]=1)\mathbb{F}_{\text{or}}(A_{Ci}, A_Q) = 1 \iff \exists j,\ (A_Q[j] = 1 \land A_{Ci}[j] = 1)For​(ACi​,AQ​)=1⟺∃j, (AQ​[j]=1∧ACi​[j]=1)
  • NOT: Fnot(ACi,AQ)=1  ⟺  ∀j, (AQ[j]=1  ⟹  ACi[j]=0)\mathbb{F}_{\text{not}}(A_{Ci}, A_Q) = 1 \iff \forall j,\ (A_Q[j] = 1 \implies A_{Ci}[j] = 0)Fnot​(ACi​,AQ​)=1⟺∀j, (AQ​[j]=1⟹ACi​[j]=0)

   Definition 4. A filtered ng-approximate k-NN query for a query object VQV_{Q}VQ​ and a filter FFF retrieves the set of kkk ng-approximate neighbors A∈{VC1,...,VCk}⊆TA \in \left \{ V_{C1},...,V_{Ck} \right \} \subseteq TA∈{VC1​,...,VCk​}⊆T, where T={VCi∈S:F(ACi,AQ)=1}T = \left \{ V_{Ci} \in S: F(A_{Ci},A_{Q}) = 1 \right \}T={VCi​∈S:F(ACi​,AQ​)=1}. Here, TTT presents the valid points that satisfy the filter FFF.

RWalks

   We propose three key desirable features of Filtered Vector Search solutions for efficiency and robustness: (1) the filter specificity should be decoupled from the recall-latency trade-off to ensure the method is robust in query workloads or varied specificity; (2) the index should be constructed to support both filtered and unfiltered vector search with minimal impact on index maintenance; (3) both index construction and search should scale well with large datasets, high dimensional, and different filter types.
   RWalks support both filtered and unfiltered vector search thanks to: (1) a post-processing algorithm that can enrich any existing graph-based vector index with attribute information(without altering the original index), and (2) a query-answering algorithm that modifies the greedy search used by state-of-the-art approaches to support filtered vector search.[ RWalks is index-agnostic, therefore, it can be used with any graph-based vector search method ]

Relaxing Specifity/Latency Dependency

   Query answering using HNSW in the unfiltered case consists of traversing a graph using a greedy search algorithm and populating a priority queue (W)(W)(W) with potential neighbors. The size of queue acts as termination condition, controlling the search latency. To support filtered search, HNSW-inline modifies the criterion for adding candidates to WWW: instead of adding candidates based on their distance to query only, it adds them only if they satisfy the query filters. This ensures recall, as all points aggregated in WWW satisfy the query filter. However, it can slow down the graph traversal in low-specificity workloads since filling up WWW takes a longer time. Removing this controlled addition of candidates to WWW results in stable traversal length regardless of specificity, but may affect recall guarantees a not all points in WWW validate the filteres. That is why solving for latency affects recall. To alleviate the issue, we build upon the following observation:
   Observation 1. Given the ounded size of WWW, points in the queue are poped when better candidates are found(i.e., closer to the query). Yet, these poped elements may satisfy the query filteres and should not be discarded.
   We introduce a twin priority queue (Wt)(W_{t})(Wt​) where poped elements that meet the query filteres are added. Once the search is complete, WtW_{t}Wt​ is merged with WWW. This simple modification reduces the drop in recall compared to a baseline HNSW search while stabilizing latency, as we eleminate the controlled addition of points to WWW thus keeping the traversal length same as in an unfiltered search.

Improving Recall with a Biased Traversal

   The proposed search modification based on Observation 1 maintains stable latency across various filter regimes, shifting the impact of filter specificity from latency to recall, albeit not to the same extent as a baseline HNSW search. For instance, with a uniform distribution of attributes, the ratio of valid points encountered during graph traversal will mirror the filter specificity. Therefore, lower specificity leads to fewer valid points, resulting in fewer candidate neighbors and consequently, lower recall. This effect is amplified if the attribute distribution negatively correlates with the vectors.
   We address this limitation by proposing a biased graph traversal that prioritizes visiting valid points. We achieve this by using a hybrid distance metric during search, unlike HQANN that uses a hybrid distance during both index construction and search.

Relaxing Sparsity with Graph Diffusion

   In low-specificity regimes, particularly there is no clustering(points in TTT are uniformly distributed in the graph), this hybrid distance may become ineffectiv. As explained in our second observation below.
   Observation 2. In low-specificity wrokloads with no clustering, few nodes share the same attributes as the query, i.e., the probability of a traversed node beling valid is low(attribute sparsity), rendering obsolete the attribute component of the hybrid distance.
   During graph traversal, neighbors of visited nodes are evalutaed using a binary question: does this neighbor satisfy query filters? We enrich the node’s attribute representation to answer the additional question: would this neighbor guide us toward nodes that satisfy query filters? We achieve this with a novel post-indexing attribute enrichment process(Algo. 1) that transforms the attribute representation from a binary form that encodes only the attributes of a given node, to a dense representation that is aware of the attributes of a node and its surroundings. We exploit graph diffusion, inspired by lable propagation in node classification where labeled nodes propogate their labels to their unlabeled neighbors.
   D-hop Random Walks as Attribute Diffusers. RWalks creates a rich attribute representation for each node $V_{i} by running multiple random walks starting from ViV_{i}Vi​, on an existing graph, and aggregates the attributes of all visited nodes via an average.

Pruning Distances with Attribute Heuristics

   In RWalks, the neighbors of a visited node can be partitioned into three classes: (1)neighbors that satisfy the query filter; (2) neighbors that do not satisfy the query filters but might guide the traversal toward valid regions in the graph; (3) neighbors that do not satisfy the query filter nor guide search toward valid regions. To improve search efficiency, we propose the following heuristic: during search, only nodes that belong to the first two classes are visited. The choice of neighbors to be evaluated is done by z-normalizing the attribute vectors in the indexing process, then applying during search a user-defined threshold τ≥0\tau \ge 0τ≥0 to decide which neigibors to visit. We z-normalize the attributes to be able to use the same parameter τ\tauτ independently of the filter specificity.[ 可以有效减少计算节点间距离操作的次数 ]

The Rwalks Search Algorithm

   We now present Algo.2, the RWalks search algorithm that exploits the ideas mentioned above to support both filtered and unfiltered vector search. Note that most SOTA graph based vector search methods answer queries using the same beam search algorithm. We highlight the modifications to this beam search with underlined text.
   The search process involves iteratively extracting the closest node from the set of candidates CCC, evaluating its neighbors, and adding them to the set of results WWW if they are closer in distance to the query(line 13). Note that the algorithm computes two distances: distVdistVdistV, the distance in vector space, and distHdistHdistH, the hybrid distance. The set of candidate nodes is processed until it becomes empty(line 2), or distance termination condition is reached(line 5). The distinctions from a baseline HNSW methods are: (1) the additional priority queue WtW_{t}Wt​ that keeps tracks of valid elements poped during the graph traversal(lines 18-19); (2) the hybrid distance metric distV+h×dattrdistV + h \times d_{attr}distV+h×dattr​ that is used to bias the graph traversal(line 13); and (3) the distance pruning heuristic that prevents the exploration of unpromissing paths(line 10). The function checkPromissingElementcheckPromissingElementcheckPromissingElement (line 11) depends on the filtering interface required. For simple euqality constraint(e.g., e_attr[index of query attribute] ＞ τ), we check if the evaluated node’s attribute(after enrichment) exceeds the pruning threshold (τ)(\tau)(τ). This can be generalized to an OR filter, and thus to a NOT filter, since the latter can be modeled as an OR filter on the remaining attributes, where at least one attribute must exceed the threshold. For an AND filter, the function checkPRomissingElementcheckPRomissingElementcheckPRomissingElement(line 11) is a dot product between the attribute enriched vector and the query vector divided by the number of active filteres/attributes. This quantity is then compared to the pruning threshold (τ)(\tau)(τ) defined by the user.

Future

  • This paper propose an index-agnostic framework for graph-based ng-approximate filtered vector search using the Euclidean distance. Support for other distance measures, types of search(e.g., range queries) and theoretical guarantees on query accuracy are out-of-scope and part of our future work

References

  • AIT AOMAR A, ECHIHABI K, ARNABOLDI M, 等. RWalks: Random Walks as Attribute Diffusers for Filtered Vector Search[J]. Proceedings of the ACM on Management of Data, 2025, 3(3): 1-26.

entry.title: HiPNG, Efficient Interval-Filtering ANNS via Hierarchical Interval Partition Navigating Graph
entry.content:
Summary

   In this paper, we introduce interval-filtering ANNS(IF-ANNS), a novel yet general retrival task where both base and query vectors are associated with numerical intervals. The goal is to retrieve nearest neighbors whose intervals are fully contained within the query interval.
   To efficiently address this problem, we propose Hierarchical Interval Partitioning Navigating Graph(Hi-PNG), a framework that hierarchically partitions the interval space to efficiently locate the search space, eliminating unnecessary computations and achieving significant speedups. In summary, we make the following contributions:

  • We formulate the IF-ANNS, a more general constraint work that generalizes existing filtered ANNS and Rf-ANNS problems. IF-ANNS adds interval constraints for base and query vectors, enhancing support for complex nearest neighbor search.
  • We develop the Hierarchical Interval Partition Navigating Graph(IF-ANNS). By embedding proximity graphs into tree nodes, it efficiently partitions the interval space, balancing query performance and memory efficiency for IF-ANNS.
  • We provide a thretical analysis of the search process and estimiate the candidate space reduction. Under unifor interval distribution, the candidate space can be reduced by a factor of 6p2\frac {6} {p^{2}}p26​(where p<1p \lt 1p<1) compared to full space

Details

Preliminary

   Table 1 lists the most frequently-used terms throughout this paper.
   Let D={(v1,[sv1,tv1]),…,(vn,[svn,tvn])}\mathcal{D} = \big\{ (v_1, [s_{v_1}, t_{v_1}]), \ldots, (v_n, [s_{v_n}, t_{v_n}]) \big\}D={(v1​,[sv1​​,tv1​​]),…,(vn​,[svn​​,tvn​​])} denote the dataset of nnn pairs (vi,[svi,tvi])(v_i, [s_{v_i}, t_{v_i}])(vi​,[svi​​,tvi​​]), where each viv_{i}vi​ is a d-dimensional vector in RdR^{d}Rd, and [svi,tvi][s_{v_i}, t_{v_i}][svi​​,tvi​​] is the corresponding interval. The set of interval is represented as III
   Definition 2.2(k-interval-filtering Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search, shorted as k-IF-ANNS). Given the dataset DDD and the query vector qqq with interval [sq,tq][s_{q},t_{q}][sq​,tq​], there exists a nearest subset T⊆DT \subseteq DT⊆D of kkk vectors s.t. ∀v∈T, [sv,tv]⊆[sq,tq]\forall v \in T, \, [s_v, t_v] \subseteq [s_q, t_q]∀v∈T,[sv​,tv​]⊆[sq​,tq​]. k-IF-ANNS returns an approximate subset SSS of kkk vectors that ∣S∩T∣|S \cap T|∣S∩T∣ us as large as possible.

Hierarchical Interval Partition Navigating Graph

Interval Space and Field

   Given a dataset DDD, let III denote the set of intervals in DDD. Each interval [s,t]∈I[s,t] \in I[s,t]∈I can be represented as a point (s,t)(s,t)(s,t) in a 2-dimensional space. Thus, all possible intervals produce an interval space(uinverse set), denoted as Ω\OmegaΩ, such that Ω={(s,t)∈R2∣s≤t}\Omega = \{(s, t) \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid s \leq t\}Ω={(s,t)∈R2∣s≤t}. Actually, the interval space Ω\OmegaΩ can be represented as a half-pane in R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2. The inclusion relationship between intervals can be regarded as the inclusion relationship between regions in the interval space. To this end, we define the concept of field.
   Definition 3.1(Field). A field is a retangle region in R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2, which can be determined by its upper left corner (su,tu)(s_{u},t_{u})(su​,tu​) and lower right corner (sv,tv)(s_{v},t_{v})(sv​,tv​), denoted by F(su,tu)×(sv,tv)\mathcal{F}_{(s_u,t_u) \times (s_{v},t_{v})}F(su​,tu​)×(sv​,tv​)​ or Fu×v\mathcal{F}_{u \times v}Fu×v​ for short.

Fu×v={(s,t)∣(s,t)=(su+γ1,tu−γ2)}\mathcal{F}_{u \times v} = \big\{ (s,t) \mid (s,t) = (s_u + \gamma 1, t_u - \gamma 2) \big\}Fu×v​={(s,t)∣(s,t)=(su​+γ1,tu​−γ2)}

   where 0≤γ1≤sv−su, 0≤γ2≤tu−tv0 \leq \gamma_1 \leq s_v - s_u,\ 0 \leq \gamma_2 \leq t_u - t_v0≤γ1​≤sv​−su​, 0≤γ2​≤tu​−tv​.
   A point (s,t)(s,t)(s,t) belonging to a field is expressed as (s,t)∈Fu×v(s,t) \in F_{u \times v}(s,t)∈Fu×v​, Given the set of intervals III, we can determine a proper field that covers all the points corresponding to the intervals in III as follows:

(su,tu)=(min⁡s∈ILs,max⁡t∈IRt) and (sv,tv)=(max⁡t∈IRt,min⁡s∈ILs)(s_u, t_u) = (\min_{s \in I_L} s, \max_{t \in I_R} t) \text{ and } (s_v, t_v) = (\max_{t \in I_R} t, \min_{s \in I_L} s)(su​,tu​)=(s∈IL​min​s,t∈IR​max​t) and (sv​,tv​)=(t∈IR​max​t,s∈IL​min​s)

   Where IL={s∣[s,t]∈I}I_{L} = \left \{ s|[s,t] \in I \right \}IL​={s∣[s,t]∈I} are left bounds and IR={t∣[s,t]∈I}I_{R} = \left \{ t|[s,t] \in I \right \}IR​={t∣[s,t]∈I} are right bounds. For simplicity, this field generated by III is denoted as F(I)F(I)F(I) or F(D)F(D)F(D). Obviously, F(I)F(I)F(I) is symmetric abour the straight line t−s=0t - s = 0t−s=0. Similarly, for the query range interval [sq,tq][s_{q},t_{q}][sq​,tq​], we can also determine the field F(sq,tq)×(tq,sq)F_{(s_{q},t_{q}) \times (t_{q},s_{q})}F(sq​,tq​)×(tq​,sq​)​, shorted by FqF_{q}Fq​.

   With the fields of base and query vectors, the interval containment relationship can be transformed into a dominance relationship between fields, as shown in the following lemma: For any two intervlas [sv,tv][s_{v},t_{v}][sv​,tv​] and [sq,tq][s_{q},t_{q}][sq​,tq​], we have [sv,tv]⊆[sq,tq][s_{v},t_{v}] \subseteq [s_{q},t_{q}][sv​,tv​]⊆[sq​,tq​] if and only if (s_{v},t_{v}) \in \F_{q}.[ 证明见原文 ]
   According to lemma above, given the query interval [sq,tq][s_{q},t_{q}][sq​,tq​], we can obtain the candidate space defined as follows, which the region encompassing all vectors that satisfy the query interval constraint.
   Definition 3.4(Candidate Space). Given a query vector qqq with the associated interval [sq,tq][s_{q}, t_{q}][sq​,tq​], the candidate space is defined as the minimal set of fields whose union contains the query field FqF_{q}Fq​.

Hierarchical Interval Space Partition

   The candidate space includes all results that satisfy the query constraints. However, it may be only a small part of the interval space, and searching the full interval space is both costly and unnecessary. To address this, we employ a hierarchical interval space partitioning to efficiently locate the candidate space.
   Definition 3.6(Hierarchical Interval Space Partition). The interval space Ω\OmegaΩ is recursively partitioned into rectangle regions, referred to as fields. Starting with the entire interval space F0F_{0}F0​, the partitioning process follows these rules: (1) Each field FXF_{X}FX​ is divided into four mutually exclusive child fields, denoted as F4x+1,F4x+2,F4x+3,F4x+4F_{4x+1}, F_{4x+2}, F_{4x+3}, F_{4x+4}F4x+1​,F4x+2​,F4x+3​,F4x+4​, such that Fx=⋃i=14F4x+i,F4x+i∩F4x+j=∅ for i≠j\mathcal{F}_x = \bigcup_{i=1}^{4} \mathcal{F}_{4x + i}, \quad \mathcal{F}_{4x + i} \cap \mathcal{F}_{4x + j} = \emptyset \text{ for } i \neq jFx​=⋃i=14​F4x+i​,F4x+i​∩F4x+j​=∅ for i=j. (2) The partitioning continues recursively until the number of intervals within each field is less than or equal to a predefined threshold, call leaf size lslsls. This recursive process results in a hierarchical structure of fields of varying sizes, facilitating efficeient searchs by focusing on smaller regions.

   Observation. Given any two fields FiF_{i}Fi​ and FjF_{j}Fj​, if FiF_{i}Fi​ contains FjF_{j}Fj​, then all sub-fields within FjF_{j}Fj​ will be contained by the field FiF_{i}Fi​. And according to the lemma and observation aforementioned, if a field FiF_{i}Fi​ has no overlap with the query range FqF_{q}Fq​, all its child fields can be filtered out. Conversely, if FiF_{i}Fi​ overlaps with FqF_{q}Fq​, we only need to focus on its overlapping child fields and ignore the rest. Through fine-grained heirarchical interval space partitioning, we can quickly find the region meeting query interval constraints and reduce the candidate space.

Hi-PNG Index Structure

   With the hierarchical interval space partition, we can obtain a tree rooted at F0F_{0}F0​ s.t. each internal node has 4 child nodes. Since each tree node corresponds to a specific field FiF_{i}Fi​, we can build a proximity graph GiG_{i}Gi​ as follows.
   Definition(Proximity Graph for a field). For each field FiF_{i}Fi​, withn the interval space, we define its proximity graph GiG_{i}Gi​ built by any graph-based ANNS method, where each vector is associated with the interval region defined by the Field FiF_{i}Fi​.
   Definition(Hi-PNG Index). The Hi-PNG index is a hierarchical structure consisting of fields from the interval space partition, where each field FiF_{i}Fi​ is associated with a proximity graph GiG_{i}Gi​.

Answering IF-ANNS Queries

   The query process begins by identifying nodes(fields) intersecting with the interval [sq,tq][s_{q},t_{q}][sq​,tq​]. Then, for each selected node, the proximity graph GiG_{i}Gi​ is used to find the nearest vectors.

Locating Candidate Nodes

   Given the Hi-PNG index, to find the candidate tree nodes of the candidate space, we use a top-down traversal in Algorithm 1. Starting from the root, it recursively explores the tree and gives the desired tree nodes with labels “1” or “0”. Label “1” means its fields is within the query field FqF_{q}Fq​, and label “0” means its field has sufficient overlap with FqF_{q}Fq​ as determined by a threshold σ\sigmaσ.

Searching the Proximity Graph

   Using candidate nodes CCC from Algorithm 1, we perform greedy search w.r.t. query qqq with an graph-based ANNS index, which merges results from different graphs, handling two cases based on candidate node labels: (1) if the node ccc is labeled as “1”, the field FCF_{C}FC​ is fully contained in the query field FqF_{q}Fq​, i.e., any vector in GcG_{c}Gc​ satisfies the query interval constraint. (2) Otherwise, the node ccc labeled with “0” may have a portion of vectors that do not meet the query interval constraint. Thus, we search the graph GGG of node ccc with the post-filtering graph search in Algorithm 5, ensuring that each returned vector failes into the query interval.

Index Construction

   Given the dataset DDD and its corresponding intervals III, the construction of the Hi-PNG index begins with the hierarchical tree structure build through interval space partitioning. Then we build a proximity graph with existing graph-based ANNS methods for each tree node.

Building Hi-PNG

   Algorithm 3 constructs a hierarchical structure of Hi-PNG index by recursively partitioning the interval space. It starts by initializing the index as an empty set and sets the field which is determined by (mins∈ILs,maxt∈IRt)(min_{s \in I_{L}}s, max_{t \in I_{R}}t)(mins∈IL​​s,maxt∈IR​​t) in line 1. Then, it invokes function INTERVALPARTITION to recursively partition the input field FxF_{x}Fx​ to the index. Then, if there are fewer than lslsls vectors in the current tree node, current field FxF_{x}Fx​ is divided into four sub-fields in line 7. After that, vectros are assigned to sub-partitions within the corresponding sub-fields, as described in line 10.
   In the hierarchical structure of Hi-PNG, each tree node corresponds to the field FxF_{x}Fx​ that is formed by a subset of vectors VxV_{x}Vx​. Finally, we construct a proxmity graph with existing graph-based ANNS methods over such vectors for each tree node, which captures the vector similarity relationships between the vectors.

Partition Point Selection

   This section investigates how to select a partition point in the interval space during partitioning.

  1. Interval Space Balanced Partitioning. Based on the principle of interval space balancing, we select a partition point to ensure an even division of the field. To achieve this, we identify the center point of the field, which lies in the midpoint of the diagonal connecting the upper left and lower right corners of the rectangle. By this, the field is evenly divided into four sub-fields, each maintaining a balanced area in the interval universe.
  2. Partition Size Balanced Partitioning. Algorithm 4 aims to find the most balanced partition point in a given field FFF. Its general idea is to select the best one (s∗,t∗)(s^{*}, t^{*})(s∗,t∗) with the lowest score of

∑cnt,cnt′∈{cntTL,cntTR,cntBL,cntBR}∣cnt−cnt′∣\sum_{cnt,cnt^{'}{\in \{\mathrm{cnt}_{TL}, \mathrm{cnt}_{TR}, \mathrm{cnt}_{BL}, \mathrm{cnt}_{BR}\}}}^{}\vert \mathrm{cnt} - \mathrm{cnt}' \vert cnt,cnt′∈{cntTL​,cntTR​,cntBL​,cntBR​}∑​∣cnt−cnt′∣

   in which cntTL,cntTR,cntBL,cntBRcnt_{TL}, cnt_{TR}, cnt_{BL}, cnt_{BR}cntTL​,cntTR​,cntBL​,cntBR​ are the number of vectors in the top-left, bottom-left, top-right and bottom-right field of the partition point (s,t)(s,t)(s,t). The algorithm maintains two sets for each point (s,t)∈F:L={t′∣(s′,t′)∈F, s′<s}(s,t) \in \mathcal{F} : L = \big\{ t' \mid (s', t') \in \mathcal{F},\, s' < s \big\}(s,t)∈F:L={t′∣(s′,t′)∈F,s′<s} and R={t′∣(s′,t′)∈F, s′>s}R = \big\{ t' \mid (s', t') \in \mathcal{F},\, s' > s \big\}R={t′∣(s′,t′)∈F,s′>s}, which store the second coordinate of points to the left and right of (s,t)(s,t)(s,t), respectively. It iterates through FFF in ascending order of the first coordinate, updating LLL and RRR according to the mechanisms in lines 3 and 7. To capature cntTLcnt_{TL}cntTL​ and cntTRcnt_{TR}cntTR​, a balanced binary search tree is used for both sets, ensuring a time complexity of O(nlogn)O(nlogn)O(nlogn).

Analysis of REduction Efficiency

   Refer to the original paper for more details and rigorous prrof.

References

  1. source code on Github
  2. YANG M, CAI Y, ZHENG W. Hi-PNG: Efficient Interval-Filtering ANNS via Hierarchical Interval Partition Navigating Graph[C/OL]//Proceedings of the 31st ACM SIGKDD Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining V.2. Toronto ON Canada: ACM, 2025: 3518-3529[2025-08-17]. https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3711896.3736997.

entry.title: UNIFY, Unified Index for Range Filtered ANNS
entry.content:
Summary

   This paper presents an efficient and scalable framework for Range Filtered Approximate Nearest Neighbors Search(RF-ANNS) over high-dimensional vectors associated with attribute values. Though bilding dedicated indexes for each strategy(pre-filter/post-filter/hyrbid-filter) and selecting the best one based on qeury range can address this problem, it leads to index consistency and maintenance issues.
   Our framework, called UNIFY, constructs a unified Proximity Graph-based index that seamlessly suuports all three strategies. In UNIFY, we introduce SIG, a novel Segmented Inclusive Graph, which segments the dataset by attribute values. It ensures the PG objects from any segment combinations is a sub-graph of SIG, thereby enabling efficient hybrid filtering by reconstructing and searching a PG from relevant segments. Moreover, we present Hirarchical Segmented Inclusive Graph(HSIG), a variant of SIG that incoporates a hierarchical structure inspired by HNSW to achieve logarithmic hybrid filtering complexity. We also implement pre- and post-filtering for HSIG by fusing skip list connections and compressed HNSW edges into the hierarchical graph.

Details

Segmented Inclusive Graph

SIG overview

   Attribute Segmentation. Given a dataset of nnn objects, RF-ANNS is concerend only with the n′n^{'}n′ objects within the query range, where n′<nn^{'} \lt nn′<n. To efficiently filter out the qualified objects, we employ the attribute segmentation method to reduce the search space. Assuming that the attribute distribution remains stable, we first sample objects from the dataset and sort them by their attribute values, then apply an equi-depth histogram to partition them. The histogram bin boudaries define the attribute intervals for each segment, partitioning the dataset into disjoint subsets with similar sizes for further indexing.
   Graph Inclusivity and SIG. After attribute segmentation, we focus on designing a graph for efficient hybrid filtering. Since a query range intersects a few segments, a straightforward approach is to independently build PGs for each segment. For an RF-ANNS query, we search the local PGs in intersected segments and merge the reuslts for the global KNN. However, this method results in search time increasing linearly with the number of intersected segments. We tackle it by introducing a novel graph family known as the Segmented Inclusive Graph(SIG). An SIG ensures that the PG of any segment combination is included in the SIG. Leveraging this characteristic, termed graph inclusivity, allows efficient hybrid filtering by reconstructing and searching smaller PG of a few segments covering the query range. Below, we introduce the formal definitions of graph inclusivity and SIG.
   Definition 2(Graph Inclusivity and Segmented Inclusive Graph). Let G(X)G(X)G(X) denote a PG constructed over the dataset XXX. Given a dataset DDD segmented into SSS disjoint subsets P={D1,D2,...,Ds}P=\left \{ D_{1},D_{2},...,D_{s}\right \}P={D1​,D2​,...,Ds​}, a segmented inclusive graph SIG(D)SIG(D)SIG(D) is a type of graph that posseses the property of graph inclusivity defined as

∀r∈{1,2,⋯ ,S}, ∀C∈P(r),G(⋃e∈Ce)⊆SIG(D),(2)\forall r \in \{1, 2, \cdots, S\},\ \forall \mathcal{C} \in \mathcal{P}^{(r)},G\left( \bigcup_{e \in \mathcal{C}} e \right) \subseteq \text{SIG}(\mathcal{D}), \tag{2}∀r∈{1,2,⋯,S}, ∀C∈P(r),G(e∈C⋃​e)⊆SIG(D),(2)

   where P(r)P^{(r)}P(r) denotes all possible combinations of rrr elements from PPP.
   Based on Definition 2, we derive an exhaustive SIG construction algorithm: build PGs for all segment combinations and merge them into a single graph. While it gurantees graph inclusicity, it faces significant computational challenges. With SSS segments, the number of combinations is ∑i=1s(si)=2s−1\sum_{i=1}^{s} \binom{s}{i} = 2^{s} - 1∑i=1s​(is​)=2s−1, and the space comlexity of SIG scales as O(2S−1)O(2^{S}-1)O(2S−1), making the construction of all PGs both computationally and spatially prohibitive. Thus, we propose a space-efficient SIG index that scales as O(S)O(S)O(S) in the next section.

SIG-KNNG

   Limitation of the Exhaustive Method. For each object vvv in a dataset DDD, constructing a KNNG involves adding a directed edge (v,o)(v,o)(v,o) for each object o∈KNN(v,D∖v)o \in KNN(v,D \setminus {v})o∈KNN(v,D∖v). When the dataset is divided into the SSS subsets by attribute segmentation, the exhaustive method requires running the construction algorithm 2S−12^{S} - 12S−1 times. Such exhaustive construction is unnecessary, as the KNN of a union is inherently within the individual KNN sets.
   Struture of SIG-KNNG. Inspired by the prior observations, we introduce SIG-KNNG, a novel graphb structure that achieves inclusivity without the need for exhaustive KNNG construction. SIG-KNNG uses a segmented adjacency list to store the outgoing edges for each object in the graph. As illustrated in Figure 2, given a dataset DDD segmented into SSS subsets D1,...,DsD_{1},...,D_{s}D1​,...,Ds​, the adjacency list for any object vvv is divided into SSS chunks. For example, the full adjacency list G[v4]G[v_{4}]G[v4​] of object v4v_{4}v4​ is segmented into two chunks G[v4][1]G[v_{4}][1]G[v4​][1] and G[v4][2]G[v_{4}][2]G[v4​][2]. The i-th chunk stores only vvv’s KNN within DiD_{i}Di​. Based on this design, to add SIG-KNNG edges for vvv, we perform KNN searches SSS times to find its neighbors in each subset, instead of searching 2S−12^{S} - 12S−1 times across all subset combinations.
   Definition 3(SIG-KNNG). Given a dataset DDD segmented into SSS disjoint subsets D1,D2,...,DsD_{1},D_{2},...,D_{s}D1​,D2​,...,Ds​, the SIG-KNNG on DDD is defined as Fk(D)=(VF,EF)F_{k}(D)=(V_{F},E_{F})Fk​(D)=(VF​,EF​), where VF=DV_{F}=DVF​=D and EF=⋃e∈D⋃i=1SEik(e)E_{F} = \bigcup_{e \in \mathcal{D}} \bigcup_{i=1}^{S} E_i^k(e)EF​=⋃e∈D​⋃i=1S​Eik​(e). Here, Eik(v)E_{i}^{k}(v)Eik​(v) is the set of sedges based on the i-th chunk of vvv’s adjacency list, defined as Eik(v)={(v,o)∣o∈kNN(a,Di∖{v})}E_i^k(v) = \big\{ (v,o) \mid o \in k\text{NN}(a, \mathcal{D}_{i} \setminus \{v\}) \big\}Eik​(v)={(v,o)∣o∈kNN(a,Di​∖{v})}

Hierarchical Segmented Inclusive Graph

   SIG-KNNG offers an efficient approach to build an SIG with segmented adjacency lists. Though it theoretically guatantees inclusivity, the underlying KNNG is not competitive with SOTA PGs like HNSW. Additionally, SIG-KNNG lacks support for incremental insertion.
