In this section, we expand the basic idea of SIG-KNNG, introducing the Hierarchical Segmented Inclusive Graph(HSIG), which uses HNSW as a building block to achieve incremental constrction and a logarithmic search complexity.
   Figure 4 provides an overview of HSIG, showcasing a hierarchical structure that follows the structure of HNSW and skip lists. HSIG is a unified structure that indexes both vectors and attributes by leveraging the strengths of vector-oriented HNSW and attribute-oriented skip lists. For vector indexing, HSIG organizes the outgoing edges of each object into chunks based on attribute segmentation, inspired by SIG-KNNG. Each chunk contains the edges of an HNSW for the corresponding segmentation. Thus, the backbone graph of HSIG can be seen as a set of HNSWs constructed for different segments, which are mutually connected with additional edges to ensure inclusivity. Additionally, we incoporate the skip list into the backbone graph to index attributes for efficient pre-filtering and introduce a compact auxiliary structure to optimize post-filtering.

HSIG Construction

   Backbone Graph for Hybrid Filtering. As depicted in Algorithm 3, when inserting a new object vvv into an HNSW layer, the core operation involves finding vvv’s efConsefConsefCons nearest neighbors and establishing up to MMM connections. This procedure is similar to KNNG’s construction, which finds KNN and establishes at most kkk connections. Therefore, we use the segmented adjacency list introduced by SIG-KNNG to guarantee the inclusivity for all possible HNSW connections. With SSS segments, connections are stored in SSS chunks, with a maximum degree of MMM per chunk. The values of SSS and MMM are experimentally determined, with default values set to 8 and 16, respectively. Since each chunk contains the HNSW connections in the corresponding segment, the objects and connections in chunk jjj form a sub-graph GjG_{j}Gj​ of the backbone graph in HSIG. When inserting object vvv that is located in segment iii, Algorithm 4 outlies how to build vvv’s connections in segment jjj at HNSW layer.

   Fusing Skip List Connections for Pre-Filtering. For small-range RF-ANNS queries, prefiltering with an attribute index typically outperforms PG-based methods. This is because PGs prioritize vectors over attributes, making it difficult to filter candidates within query range. Thus, we propose fusing an attribute index into the graph structure for effective pre-filtering. As described in Section 2, the skip list is a popuar index for effficient 1D key-value lookups and range searches, sharing a hierarchical structure similar to HNSW and HSIG. Inspired by this, we integrate the skip list into the backbone graph of HSIG to form a unified index. Navigated by skip list connections, we can efficiently locate and linearly search objects with the query range. As shown in Figure 4, we use an extra connection G[v].nextG[v].nextG[v].next to store the ID of vvv’s succesor object in the skip list. After inserting an object into the backbone graph via Algorithm 4, we search for its successor in the skip list and store it in G[v].nextG[v].nextG[v].next.
   Global Edge Masking for Post-Filtering. Fror large-range queries, post-filtering with a pure ANNS index is preferable. We use a global HNSW over the entire dataset to support post-filtering. Due to inclusivity, the global HNSW is (approximately) a sub-graph of HSIG. We apply a global edge pruning method to identify these HNSW edges from HSIG edges and compact bitmap to mask the unused edges. Since each segment’s sub-graph has a maximum degree of MMM, we similarly limit the connections in the global graph to a maximum of MMM. This procedure is detailed in Algorithm 5. First, we obtain the object vvv’s connections in all segemnts and select MMM connections using the PrunePrunePrune algorithm(line 1). Next, we create a bitmap whose size equals the number of vvv’s neighbors in all segments and set the position of vvv’s MMM neighbors to 1(line 2). For each neighbor ooo in the MMM neighbors(line 3), if vvv is also a neighbor of vvv, set the position of vvv in ooo’s bitmap to 1(line 4-6). Then, we update the bitmap of ooo (line 7-9).
   Complete Insertion Algorithm. As aforementioned, the adjacency list of a node in HSIG consists of (1) several chunks for backbone graph connections, (2) a skip list connections, and (3) a bitmap for global connections. The bottom-right of Figure 4 illustrates an example. Here, G[v][i]G[v][i]G[v][i] is the backbone graph connections of vvv in the i-th segment, G[v].nextG[v].nextG[v].next stores the ID of vvv’s successors in the skip list, and G[v].bitmapG[v].bitmapG[v].bitmap stores the global edge masks.
   Next, we present the complete insertion algorithm for constructing an HSIG. The HSIG structure consists of a set of HNSWs for different segments, argumented with auxiliary structures for pre- and post- filtering. Construction involves thress main steps: building the HNSW in each segemt, adding skip list connections, and applying global edge masking. Each step is performed hierarchically and incrementaly, as outlined in Algorithm 6. First, we fine the segment to which object vvv belongs(Line 1). The maximum layer level of vvv is randomly assigned using an exponentially decaying probability distribution normalized by mLm_{L}mL​ (Line 2). We then traversal all segments(Line 3) to sequentially build the HNSW HGjHG_{j}HGj​ in each segment jjj, determining its maximum level LLL and entry point epepep (Lines 4-5). For each layer lll from LLL to level+1level + 1level+1, we use ANNSearch(Algorithm 1) to find the nearest neighbor epepep of vvv in HGjlHG_{j}^{l}HGjl​, where HGjlHG_{j}^{l}HGjl​ denotes layer lll in HGjHG_{j}HGj​ (Lines 6-7). Then, for each layer lll from levellevellevel to 000, we employ BackboneConnectionsBuild(Algorithm 4) to insert vvv into HGjlHG_{j}^{l}HGjl​, using its nearest neighbor as the entry point for the next layer(Lines 8-10). After building HGjHG_{j}HGj​, we update its entry point if necessary(Line 11), ensureing the first object in the topmost layer servers as the entry. Next, vvv is inserted into the skip list. Finally, we use GlobalEdgeMasking(Algorithm 5) to mask unncessary edges for post-filtering from layer 0 to level(Lines 13-14).

Search on HSIG

   To adapt to different query ranges, we propose three search strategies and a range-aware search strategy selection method.
   Strategy A(Pre-Filtering). Navigated by the hierarchical skip list connections, we can quickly reach the bottom layer to identify the first object whose attribute value fall within the query range. From there, a linear search is performed to collect the query vector’s KNN among those vectors with qualified values.
   Strategy B(Post-Filtering). We employ the hierarchical search scheme in Algorithm 2 for ANNS, followed by filtering objects within the query range. ANNS is performed over a global HNSW with edges marked by bitmaps. During the search, only outgoing edges marked as 1 in an object’s bitmap are considered. The search retrieves the top-ef nearest neighbors(ef>kef \gt kef>k) in the bottom layer, after which attribute filtering is applied to obtain the top-k results.
   Strategy C(Hybrid Filtering). We perform hybrid filtering by reconstructing and searching the HNSW of segments covering the query range. The search follows the hierarchical scheme is Algorithm 2, starting from the topmost entry point of graphs in all segments. Since each object has MMM connections per segment, and assuming there are S′S^{'}S′ segments intersecting the query range, this requires visiting MS′MS^{'}MS′ neighboring nodes, leading to a large search space and high computational complexity. Thus, we introduce the search parameter mmm to reconstruct an HNSW with a maximum degree of mmm runtime. We propose two neighbor selection strategies to select mmm neighbors from MS′MS^{'}MS′ connections: (1) compute the distances between node vvv and its neighbors across all S′S^{'}S′ segments, then select the top-m neighbors by sorting them by distance; and (2) select the top-(⌈m/S′⌉)\text{top-}\big( \lceil m / S' \rceil \big)top-(⌈m/S′⌉) neighbors from each chunk of adjacency list. Since neighbors in each chunk are naturally ordered by distance to vvv upon acquisition vis ANNSearch, we simply take the first ⌈m/S′⌉\lceil m / S' \rceil⌈m/S′⌉ objects. We adopt the second strategy as the default.

   Range-aware Strategy Selection. Let YYY be the cardinality of objects within a query range. Observing the pre-, post-, and hybrid filtering perfrom best for small-, large, and mid-range queries. We propose the following heuristic for strategy slection: use strategy A if Y≤τAY \le \tau_{A}Y≤τA​, Strategy B if Y≥τBY \ge \tau_{B}Y≥τB​, and Strategy C if τA<Y<τB\tau_{A} \lt Y \lt \tau_{B}τA​<Y<τB​. Here, τA\tau_{A}τA​ and τB\tau_{B}τB​ are thresholds distinguishing the optimal ranges for each strategy, derived from historical data analysis. Given these thresholds, we estimate the cardinality of an incoming query to apply the heuristic. Since stattistic collection and cardinality estimation are well studied and not the focus of this paper, we provide a simple processing method to validate our heuristic. Specifically, we sample objects from the base dataset as queries and assign each a random query range. We then execute these queries using the three strategies and record recall and latency metrics. Given a recall target, we analyze records meeting this requirement and identify two turning points where pre- and post-filtering outperform hybird filtering. These points establish τA\tau_{A}τA​ and τB\tau_{B}τB​, guiding strategy selection for future queries.

Discuss/Future

  • Range-ware strategy selection: our range-ware strategy selection method is based on historical data statistics, not query patterns
  • RF-ANNS with Multiple Attributes

References

  • source code on Gtihub
  • LIANG A, ZHANG P, YAO B, 等. UNIFY: Unified Index for Range Filtered Approximate Nearest Neighbors Search[J]. Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment, 2024, 18(4): 1118-1130.

entry.title: SHINE, A Scalable HNSW Index in Disaggregated Memory
entry.content:
Summary

   In this work, we propose a scalable HNSW index for ANN search in disaggregated memory. In contrast to existing distributed approaches, which partition the graph at the cost of accuracy, our method builds a graph-preserving index that reaches the same accuracy as a single-machine HNSW. Continuously fetching high-dimensional vector data from remote memory leads to severe net-work bandwidth limitations, which we overcome by employing an efficient caching mechanism. Since answering a single query involves processing numerous unique graph nodes, caching alone is not sufficient to achieve high scalability. We logically combine the caches of the compute nodes to increase the overall cache effectiveness and confirm the efficiency and scalability of our method in our evaluation.

Details

Baseline & Limitations

   This section introduces our baseline HNSW index design for the disaggregated memory architecture. Importantly, we build a global HNSw index that preserves the original HNSW structure while being distributed to arbitrarily many MNs(Memory nodes). This allows to achieve exactly the same accuracy, whereas other distributed approaches loas accuracy as they split the HNSW index.

Index Layout

   A graph node in HNSW stores the d-dimensional vector components and its outgoing neighbor nodes for each level on which the node occurs. We represent them compactly in memory as shown in Figure 2. To uniquely identify a node, we use a header that stores the node id, the maximum level at which this node for insertions. Similar to the original HNSW implementation, the lock is only used to construct the index concurrently. For each level, we store a neighbor list prefixed by a 64-bit remote pointer: The 48 least significant bits encode the virtual address of a memory region within the MN, and the remaining bits encode the identifier of the MN. Hence, the remote pointer is a globally unique address among all MNs.
   When inserting a node, we randomly choose a MN on which we atomically increase a bump pointer using a remote FAA via RDMA. In summary, a node is stored on randomly chosen MN, and its outgoing neighbors are represented by remote pointers(that point to other nodes) compactly stored in a fixed-size memory region.

Query Processing

   To process a query in HNSW, the nodes at the top-most level are greedily traversed(starting from a fixed entry point) until the nearest neighbor to a query qqq is reached. Typically, the entry point is the first node that has been inserted at the top-most level. The nearest neighbor found at level lll serves as entry point for the next level l−1l - 1l−1 . Algorithm 1 with l=0l = 0l=0 shows the base level search, where the greedy search is expanded by searching the ef−ef-ef− nearest neighbors using two heap data structures based on the distance to the query.
   The only difference between SHINE and standard HNSW search is that nodes and neighbor lists are read from remote memory(line 6 and 12). The address of a neighbor list can be deduced from the node’s remote pointer(line 5).

Scalability Constraints

   In disaggregated memory, all computations are executed on CNs. Thus, answering a single K-NN query involves fetching many high-dimensional vectors from the MNs to the CN that processes the query. Note that the entire vectors are required for distance computations(line 15 in Algo 1). As a result, the throughout is network-bound despite the use of an ultra-fast low-latency network. The natural solution to this problem is to cache frequently accessed graph nodes on the CNs to reduce memory reads(line 10-13 in Algo 1). The latency gap between local and remote is 10-100x lower than the gap between main memory and SSD. Hence, an extremely fast cache with a low-overhead replacement strategy is crucial to reach high throughputs.
   In contrast to many other index structures, an HNSW index in disaggregated memory poses a unique challenge to a caching mechanism: A single query requires access to many different graph nodes, in particular at the base level. This results in many cache misses if (a) the cache is not sufficiently large or (b) the workload follows a uniform distribution.
   To address this problem and overcome the network bound, we propose to logically combine the caches of all CNs and route queries to the best matching CN.

Index Updates

   A limitation of HNSW lies in its static nature since the index has not been inherently designed for dynamic datasets. The index structure allows updates, but particularly deletes and subsequent inserts are very efficient and can lead to unreachable graph nodes. To alleviate this issue, it is common to rebuild the index after a certain amount of deletions. Supporting efficient index updates is considered an orthogonal research direction, and we focus only on K-NN queries in this work. Note that supporting insertions(without deletions) can be straightforwardly integrated into our method by using the insert procedure for constructing the graph, and locking neighbor lists during the search to guarantee consistent query processing. Notably, our cache design is suitable for index updates and requires no coherency protocol(only neighbor lists are modified, which are not cached).

Optimizations Outline

   We identify three key challenges and briefly introduce three optimization techniques to address these challenges and optimize for scalability:

  • Read Amplification: HNSW requires to repeatedly fetch many high-dimensional vectors for distance computations, resulting in severe read amplifications. SHINE address this by caching frequently accessed nodes in the small memory CNs to save remote reads
  • Cache Segmentation: The cache capability of a CN is limited and shared among all workers on this CN. In addition, the number of cache entries is restricted as high-dimensional vectors must be stored, and the caches of different CNs will largely overlap, thereby wasting valuable cache capacity and effective reducing the overall cache size. SHINE logically combines the CN caches by assigning each CN to a specific portion of the index. In particular, the HNSW graph is logically divided into ∣CN∣|CN|∣CN∣ many partitions, where each partition represents a CN’s cache. Once a query arrives at a CN, an oracle determines the CN that can process the query most efficiently by finding the query’s best fitting partition.
  • Query Routing: A query is processed by a random CN whose cache may not represent the target partition of this query. Hence, a query must be forwarded to the CN with the best matching cache. SHINE implements adaptive query routing, where a query is forworded to the CN returned by the oracle via a random MN using two-side RDMA. The destined CN receives the message and processes the query. This strategy reduces the overlap of nodes among caches, which ultimately increases the hit rate and the throughput.

Node Caching

   Processing a query involves reading numerous graph nodes and their neighbor lists from remote memory, resulting in heavily high read amplifications. To save remote memory accesses, SHINE implements a lightweight software-level cache that keep hot nodes in the local memory of a CN.
   A major challenge is achieving efficient synchronization between cache accesses and replacements, which quickly becomes a bottlrneck if the latency gap between local and remote memory is low. We overcome this issue with lock-free reads and a lighweight replacement strategy.
  What to cache: In addition to caching vector components that are required for distance computations, neighbor lists(per level) can be cached. However, since neighbor lists contribute only a small fraction of RDMA reads, we do not cache them.[ 此处应有数学推导证明为什么仅是小部分，见原文 ]
  Cache implementation: The cache is implemented as a concurrent hash table mapping a remote pointer to a linked list of cache entries to resolve hash collisions with chaining. The list can be locked for insertions and deletions, and a cache entry stores the keys, a cooling flag, and a pointer to a local memory location that stores the vector. Since cache accesses must be efficient due to the low latency gap between local and remote memory, cache lookups are lock-free, which is realized with pointer tagging: A cache entry stores (1)a tag and (2)a tagged pointer to the subsequent entry in the chain. The pointer tag must match the entry tag that the pointer references, otherwise the entry is corrupted( has been freed and potentially reused by another thread ) and the cache lookup must the restarted. Deleting a cache entry occurs under a lock on the list and increments the entry’s tags, thereby invalidating the pointer that references that entry. The released entry may then be reused. We prefer pointer tagging over lock versioning as it validates individual cache entries instead the entire chain.

Cache Replacement

   Since the latency gap between local and remote memory accessed vis RDMA(~2us) is notably smaller than the gap between main memory and SSDs(~10-100us), a cache replacement strategy with very low overhead is crucial. Conventioal replacement strategies, such as LRU, MRU, or frequency-based methods, must constantly update head and tail pointers of a centralized data structure(shared among all compute threads) to track information for future eviction. Moreover, in disaggregated memory, where the core count of CNs is typically high, maintaining such data structures, i.e., performing extra work for every cache hit, can lead to severe scalability bottlenecks. For this reason, we choose a relaxed LRU variant following the design of [1] that randomly puts cache entries into a cooling state and avoids updating tracking information for each cache hit. A cache entry remains in the cooling state for a certain amount of time and is eventually evicted if meanwhile no hit occurs.[ 近似LRU ]
   The cooling mechanism is implemented via a hash table, where each bucket stores a fixed-size FIFO array, containing 8B keys(remote pointers) that represent entries in the cooling state, protected by a lock. Rather than using a single cooling array, the hash table reduces the pressure of a single lock and thus increases scalability. The size of the cooling table is relative to the cache size and keeps a fixed amount of cache entries(e.g., 10%) in the cooling state.

Cache Admission

   Since the amount of memory of CNs is small and caching nodes is inherently space consuming, it is important to keep only hot nodes in the cache. If the cache is full, admitting a new node triggers an eviction of another node. Many cache design for disaggregated memory optimistically adimit every item in the cache. But possibly, the evicted entry is hotter than the new item, which is unknown at time of admission. Moreover, frequent evictions come with non-negligible synchronization verhead in the hash tables and thus reduce the overall cache performance.
   To reduce the number of cache evictions, SHINE adimts base-level nodes only with a fixed probability as proposed by [1]. Our experiments have shown that admitting 1% of the base-level nodes works well in practice, i.e., nodes that are accessed frequently will eventually make it to the cache. Upper-level nodes that are crucial for navigation are always admitted.

Deadling with Cache Segmentation

   As discussed in the previous section, caching for HNSW indexes is challenging due to the large number of nodes that must be cached. Moreover, the high dimensionality of the indexed vectors further constraints the number of cache entries that can be stored. Therefore, it is crucial that the available cache memory is used effectively.
   The distribued nature of our setting makes it difficult to effectively utilize the globally available cache memory, i.e., the sum of all cache memories across all CNs. The cache memory of an individual CN is shared by all workers on that node, and the caches of other CNs cannot be accessed. As all CNs process queries from the same global distribution, the overlap of cache nodes between differecnt CNs is large, wasting valuable cache capacity. Although the global cache size increases with more CNs, the effective cache size will not scale due to repetitive entries between caches on different CNs.

Cache Segmentation Penalty

   We introduce a new concept, the cache segmentation penalty, which quantifies the performance impact of dividing global cache meory among multiple nodes. While cache hit – defined as the number of cache hits divided by the total number of accessed nodes – is commobly used to access cache performance, it fails to isolate the effect of segmentation: the hit rate is heavily influenced by the relative size of the cache and the index, making it difficult to attribute performance of changes specifically to segmentation.
   Intuitively, the cache segmentation penalty measures the ratio between the achieved cache hit rate(CHR) in distributed system and the optimal hit rate(CHRmaxCHR_{max}CHRmax​) achievable in the same setting. The optimal rate corresponds to a scenario where no duplicate entries are stored across caches, modeled as the a single cache shared by all CNs, with the same aggreated cache size over all CNs.
  (Definition) Cache Segmentation Penalty: Given k=∣CN∣k = |CN|k=∣CN∣ compute nodes with cache sizes c1,c2,...,ckc_{1},c_{2},...,c_{k}c1​,c2​,...,ck​. Let CHR be the measured cache hit rate for a given query load in the distributed cache setting, and CHRmaxCHR_{max}CHRmax​ the cache hit rate achieved for the same setting except that all compute nodes share a single cache size of C=∑i=1kciC= {\textstyle \sum_{i=1}^{k}c_{i}}C=∑i=1k​ci​. The cache segmentation penalty(CSP) is defined as:

CSP=1−CHRCHRmax(1)\mathrm{CSP} = 1 - \frac{\mathrm{CHR}}{\mathrm{CHR}_\mathrm{max}} \tag{1}CSP=1−CHRmax​CHR​(1)

Logical Index Partitioning

   We propose logical index partitioning to mitigate the negative effects of cache segmentation. The core idea is to divide the nodes of HNSW index into disjoint partitions, assigning each CN to a unique partition. As a result, each CN becomes responsible for a specific portition of the index primarily handles queries that are cloest to its assigned partition. This specialization reduces overlap between caches, improving the cache segmentation penalty.
   We propose a technique to efficiently clsuter the index into partitions of similar size and discuss the oracle used to assign queries to the most appropriate partition(i.e., CN). Note that the partitioning is purely logical: no data is moved, and the structure of the index(i.e., its nodes and edges) remains unchanged.
  Clustering. We use balanced k-means to cluster the nodes of the index into k=∣CN∣k=|CN|k=∣CN∣ many partitionss of near-equal size. Conventional k-means aims to build k disjoint clusters such that the sum of squared distances of the data points to the cluster centroids is minimized. Unfortunately, for high-dimensional vector spaces, often some very small culsters emerge, even if the data has a balanced distribution. Balanced k-means additionally minimizes the difference in cluster sizes and thus, ensures that each cluster consists of a similar number of points. Since finding optimal cluster is NP-hard, we use the approximation proposed by [2] and cluster only on a small(<100k) subset of the nodes in the index. In particular, we choose the first level of the HNSW index(from top to bottom) that contains ≥1000\ge 1000≥1000 nodes as a representative sample.
   We found that for small and odd kkk values(e.g., 3 or 5 CNs), the approximation may fail to generate well-balanced clusters. To address this, we apply a simple yet effective heuristic: We first double the number of clusters until the resulting clusters are nearly equal in size. Then, we greedily merge the pairwise cloest clusters(based on centroid distance) until only k=∣CN∣k=|CN|k=∣CN∣ clusters remain.
   Clustering is highly efficient(takes less than 1s) due to the small number of nodes involved. In our implementation, each CN performs clustering using the same randome seed, ensuring identical cluster assignments. Only the cluster centroids are stored on each CN.
   Oracle. The oracle predicates the best fitting CNs for a given query q. It stores a mapping from the cluster centroids to the CNs and resturns a list of CNs ranked by the distance between q and the representaive centroids. The CN that best fits q is the first entry in the list, and the last entry is the CN with the most distant centroid. Depending on the routing policy, a query may not be assigned to the best fitting CN; therefore, the oracle maintains a ranked list.

Query Routing

   In order to imprve the cache efficiency, SHINE aims to process queries on the best maching CNs are proposed by the oracle. The queries received by a CN(e.g., from clients) are appeneded to its input queue. The CN pops queries from the input queue and either routes them to another CN or appends them to the CN’s working queue to be processed locally. Since the disaggregated memory architetcure does not allow direct communication between CNs(due to scalability reasons), MN must be involved to route queries.

Routing Mechanism

   In our disaggregated memory setting, we use two-side RDMA verbs to route queries through MNs. That’s, SHINE leverages the low compute power of MNs for routing: Each CN and MN spawns a router thread responsible for routing. A CN’s router wraps the query into a message and appends a header to encode the destination CN. Then the router SENDs the message to a random MN; the MS is choosen randomly to evenly distribute the routing load. Upon receiving the request, the MN reads the header and forwards the message(using SEND operation) to the target CN. Finally, the destination CN receives the message and inserts the query into its local working queue.

Routing Polices

   The overall goal of a routing policy is to increase the query throughput for a wide range of workloads. SHINE use adaptive routing to solve this problem, which dynamicall adjusts the per-node query limit for each batch(relative to Balanced Routing that send at most b∣CN∣\frac{b}{|CN|}∣CN∣b​ queries to each CN in one batch and reset query counter for all CN at the end of each batch). Each CN periodically broadcast the length ppp of its local working queue to all other CNs. The relative queue lengths are then used to distribute the next batch of queries: CNs with longer queues receive fewer queries to balance the load.
  Algorithm 2 outlines the adaptive query routing procedure. For each query, the oracle returns a ranked list of CNs, ordered by the distance between the query and the cluster centroids. The router selects the first CN δ\deltaδ in this list that has not yet reached its query limit for the current batch(line 3). If δ\deltaδ corresponds to the local CN, the query is added to its local working queue(line 4); othrwise, the query is forwarded to CNδCN_{\delta}CNδ​ via a random MN.
   After processing a batch of size bbb, the CN’s router tracks the number of remaining queries ppp in its local working queue and broadcasts ppp(vis a random MN) to all other CNs to inform them about its current progress(line 7-8). Since the router thread on a CN only sends and receives queries, it progresses faster then the other threads that must answer queries. Therefore, after tracking the progress value ppp, the router thread sleeps until the length of the local working queue falls below ttt(line 9). Note that the choice of ttt is not critical as it only serves for synchronization.
   Finally, we update the limits for all CNs by computing a weight www that captures the relative lengths of the working queues ppp. The weighted limits for each CN are computed as w⋅b∣CN∣\frac{w \cdot b}{|CN|}∣CN∣w⋅b​(line 12-15). Note that the weighted limits sum up to $$, and w=1w=1w=1 indicates that all progress values ppp are equal.

References

  1. Baotong Lu, Kaisong Huang, Chieh-Jan Mike Liang, Tianzheng Wang, and Eric Lo. 2024. DEX: Scalable Range Indexing on Disaggregated Memory. Proc. VLDB Endow. 17, 10 (2024), 2603–2616. https://doi.org/10.14778/3675034.3675050
  2. Rieke de Maeyer, Sami Sieranoja, and Pasi Fränti. 2023. Balanced kmeans revisited. Applied Computing and Intelligence 3, 2 (2023),145–179. https://doi.org/10.3934/aci.2023008
  • source code on Github
  • WIDMOSER M, KOCHER D, AUGSTEN N. SHINE: A Scalable HNSW Index in Disaggregated Memory[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-08-08]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2507.17647.

entry.title: HQANN, Efficient and Robust Similarity Search for Hybrid Queries with Structured and Unstructured Constraints
entry.content:
Summary

   The in-memory ANNS algorithms have achieved great success for high-recall query processing, but are extremely inefficient when handling hybrid queries with unstructured constraints. In this paper, we present HQANN, a simple yet highly efficient query processing framework which can be easily embedded into existing proximity graph-based ANNS algorithms. We guarantee both low latency and high recall by leveraing navigation sense among attributes and fusing vector similarity search with attribute filtering.
   In HQANN, we argue that attibutes should be in the leading position for proximity graph-based hybrid query processing. And following the fusion strategy in Figure 1, we merge the search and filtering stage by going through the composite graph, leading to high recall hybrid ANNS algorithms with negligible extra computation overhead. The maincontributions of this paper are as follows:

  1. We introduce a novel hybrid query processing gramework, HQANN, which tactfully manages hybrid queries in a fused way. HQANN is generally applicable to many proximity graph-based ANNS algorithms. We demonstrate the flow of construction and search for proximity graphs can be easily adapted to the proposed framework
  2. We propose to leverage the navigation sense among attributes to traverse the proximity graphs.

Details

HQANN

   The performance of hybrid query processing is largely determined by the efficiency of setting attributes, as they determine the accurate search space for future vectors. From this motivation, we propose HQANN. In HQANN, all attributes is treated as a native part of the fusion distance metric, which can make full use of the inhereny Navigation feature of proximity graph-based ANNS solutions.

Fusion Distance Metric

   The key point for hybrid query processing is to define an effective distance metric to facilitate analytics on attributes. Give the fused distance function as the basic premise, a composite proximity graph-based index can be constructed and retrieved without invading its original execution flow.
   Generally, performance of a proximity graph is largely determined by the quality of the graph node neighbors. Since the feature vector search space of hybrid queries is determined by the attributes, we treat attributes as the dominant part of the fusion distance metric, which means a graoh node tend to establish links with datapoints containing the same or very similar attributes. In such circumstances, a hybrid query can quickly locate those graph nodes with exactly the same attributes and conduct detailed vector similarity search among their neighborhoods.
   Given an hybrid dataset SSS, with m−m-m−dimensional featue vector data space XXX and n−n-n−dimensional attribute data space VVV(we assume that the attributes have been pre-processed into vectors), The distance between two hybrid datapoints si,sj∈Ss_{i}, s_{j} \in Ssi​,sj​∈S can be measured as:

Dist(si,sj)=Dist(xi,xj)+Dist(vi,vj).(1)\mathrm{Dist}(s_i, s_j) = \mathrm{Dist}(x_i, x_j) + \mathrm{Dist}(v_i, v_j). \tag{1}Dist(si​,sj​)=Dist(xi​,xj​)+Dist(vi​,vj​).(1)

   Here Dist(xi,xj)Dist(x_{i}, x_{j})Dist(xi​,xj​) can represent any frequently-used vector distance metric. Let g(x,)g(x,)g(x,) and f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) denote distance funtions for feature vectors and attributes separately, and the fusion distance metric can be computed with:

Dist(si,sj)=w⋅g(xi,xj)+f(vi,vj),(2)\mathrm{Dist}(s_{i},s_{j}) = \mathcal{w} \cdot g(x_{i},x{j}) + f(v_{i},v_{j}), \tag{2}Dist(si​,sj​)=w⋅g(xi​,xj)+f(vi​,vj​),(2)

   where f(vi,vj)f(v_{i}, v_{j})f(vi​,vj​) satisfies

f(vi,vj)={0,vi=vjbias−1lg⁡(e(vi,vj)+1),vi≠vj(3)f(v_i, v_j) = \begin{cases} 0, & v_i = v_j \\[6pt]\text{bias} - \dfrac{1}{\lg\left(e(v_i, v_j) + 1\right)}, & v_i \neq v_j \end{cases}\tag{3}f(vi​,vj​)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​0,bias−lg(e(vi​,vj​)+1)1​,​vi​=vj​vi​=vj​​(3)

   with e(vi,vj)e(v_{i}, v_{j})e(vi​,vj​) and biasbiasbias as follows:

e(vi,vj)=∑k=1n∣vi[k]−vj[k]∣(4)e(v_i, v_j) = \sum_{k=1}^{n} \vert v_i[k] - v_j[k] \vert \tag{4}e(vi​,vj​)=k=1∑n​∣vi​[k]−vj​[k]∣(4)

bias≫max⁡(w⋅g(xi,xj))+1lg⁡2\text{bias} \gg \max(w \cdot g(x_i, x_j)) + \frac{1}{\lg 2}bias≫max(w⋅g(xi​,xj​))+lg21​

   Note that attribute vectors should only contain integers in production environments, thus min(e(vi,vj)=1)min(e(v_{i},v_{j}) = 1)min(e(vi​,vj​)=1). We see that when two hybrid datapoints share the same attributes, their attribute distance is defined as zero. Otherwise, biasbiasbias is applied first to keep attribute distance much larger than feature vector disance, which guarantees the cloest neighbors of a hybrid datapoint should have exctly matched attributes. Then 1lg(e(vi,vj)+1)\frac{1}{lg(e(v_{i},v_{j}) + 1)}lg(e(vi​,vj​)+1)1​ is attached as a fine-tuning effect for attribute distance values, leading to smaller distances among attributes with higher similarity. After we obtain the distance aming attribute parts, they are fused with feature vector distances with a scale factor w\mathcal{w}w, we tune w\mathcal{w}w to ensure the feature vector distance are much smaller than attribute distance, while avoid them being too small to be ignored.
   The mapping function e(x)e(x)e(x) we used here represents the Manhattan Distance among two attribute vectors, as we only focus on the representation space of attribute distances instead of their accurate values. For example, if e(vi,vj)e(v_{i}, v_{j})e(vi​,vj​) performs a xorxorxor operation for all dimension of two attribute vectors and sum them up, then return value of e(vi,vj)e(v_{i},v_{j})e(vi​,vj​) should be the same for a mass of combinations of attributes, this deprived the navigation sense among attributes and the composite proximity graph will degenerate into a normal one with feature vector similarity information only. In fact, any mapping function that is capable of preserving attribute representation space can be used as e(x)e(x)e(x)(i.e. Euclidean distance), we select Mahattan Distance here for computational efficiency. The lglglg function is applied to prevent attribute values from being too large and erase the gap among different attributes.
   Eq/2-4 provide a simple and efficient solution to fuse two disjoint distance metrics. In our experimental study, w=0.25\mathcal{w} = 0.25w=0.25 and bias=max(g(xi,xj))+1lg2=1+10.3010=4.32bias = max(g(x_{i},x_{j})) + \frac{1}{lg2} = 1 + \frac{1}{0.3010} = 4.32bias=max(g(xi​,xj​))+lg21​=1+0.30101​=4.32 work well for most datasets. We want to point out that in most production scenarios these feature vectors x∈Xx \in Xx∈X are pre-normalized with inner product(IP) as the distance metric, which means max(g(xi,xj))=1max(g(x_{i},x{j})) = 1max(g(xi​,xj))=1, thus we do not need to tune these hyper parameters specifically for most cases(to satisfy minimum priority in fusion distance metric, let g(xi,xj)=1−xi⋅xjg(x_{i},x_{j}) = 1 - x_{i} \cdot x_{j}g(xi​,xj​)=1−xi​⋅xj​ for IP)

Composite Proximity Graph

   The basic idea od HQANN is that we obtain a fusion distance metric by fine-tuning the attribute distances via feature vector distances. More specifically, the distance between two hybrid datapoints is mainly defined by their attribute distance, and their future vector distance serves as adjustment factor with limited impact on the fusion distance. During the construction stage of the proximity graphs, datapoints with the same or very similar attributes will linked first as they tend to have much smaller distcne compared with our candidates. The the remaining neighborhood vacancies would be filled up with datapoints that are relatively distant in attributes, which strongly maintains the connectivity of the graph. In the search stage, a hybrid query traverses the graph until it reaches the first node with the same attribute, by fully scanning the node’s neighborhoods, a high quality return candidate list can be efficiently accessed.
   The overall configuration of the composite proximity graph is shown in Figure 2. With attribute plays a major role in the fusion distance metric, we actually accomplish the filtering-search strategy by simple traversal of the composite graph. The numerical differences among attribute distances and feature vector distances skillfully exploiting the proximity graphs’ essence of voracious searching for graph nodes closest to the query. Hence, HQANN is robust against scale of attributes and remains highly efficient.

References

  • WU W, HE J, QIAO Y, 等. HQANN: Efficient and Robust Similarity Search for Hybrid Queries with Structured and Unstructured Constraints[C/OL]//Proceedings of the 31st ACM International Conference on Information & Knowledge Management. Atlanta GA USA: ACM, 2022: 4580-4584[2025-08-02]. https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3511808.3557610.

entry.title: HAKES, Scalable Vector Database for Embedding Search Service
entry.content:
Summary

  Graph-based indexes are costly to build, suffer from significant contention under concurrent read-write workloads, and scale poorly to multiple servers. Our goal is to build a vector database that achieves high through-put and high recall under concurrent read-write workloads.
  We first propose an ANN index with an explict two-stage design combining a fast filter stage with highly compressed vectors and a refine stage to ensure recall, and we devise a novel lightweight machine learning technique to fine-tune the index parameters. We introduce an realy termination check to dynamically adapt the search process for each query. Next, we add support for writes while maintaining search performance by decoupling the management of the learned parameters. Finally, we design HAKES, a distributed vector database that serves the new index in a disaggregated architecture. In summary, we make the following contributions:

  • We propose a novel index, HAKES-Index, that combines a compressed partitioning-based index with dimensionality reduction and quantization. The index leverages a lightweight machine learning technique to generate high-quality candidate vectors, which are then refined by exact similarity computation. It allows terminating the search realy based on the intermediate results.
  • We propose a technique that decouples index parameters for compressing vector during updates from those used for similarity computation. This ensures high performance under concurrent read-write workloads.
  • We design a distributes vector database, called HAKES, employing the new index in a disaggregated architecture. The system achieves scalability by spreading out the memory and computation overhead over multiple nodes.

Details

HAKES-INDEX

  In this section, we present a novel index, called HAKES-INDEX, that supports efficient search and index update.

Overview

  HAKES-Index consists of three parts, the two respective sets of index parameters to process the vectors for search and insert, the partitions that contain compressed vectors, and the full vectors. Each set of index parameters is composed of a dimensionality reduction module, IVF centroids, and a PQ codebook. The compressed vectors are partitioned by the IVF centroids and the compression involves dimensionality reduction followed by quantization guided by the codebook. The dimensionality reduction module uses a tranformation matrix A∈Rd×drA \in R ^{d \times d_{r}}A∈Rd×dr​ and a bias vector b∈Rdrb \in R^{d_{r}}b∈Rdr​ to compress vectors from the original d-dimensional space to that of drd_{r}dr​-dimensioanl spaces, where dr<dd_{r} \lt ddr​<d. The iVF entroids, CIVFC^{IVF}CIVF, determine the partition a new vector is attached to during the insert and rank the partitions for a query vector during the search. The quantization codeboks, CPQC^{PQ}CPQ, are used to generate the quantized vector stored in the partitions and compute the Lookup table for search. Note that dimensionality reduction is placed at the front, which speeds up all subsequent computations. We use A,b,CIVF,CPQA, b, C^{IVF}, C^{PQ}A,b,CIVF,CPQ to refer to the insert index parameters and A′,b′,CIVF′,CPQ′A^{'}, b^{'}, C^{IVF'}, C^{PQ'}A′,b′,CIVF′,CPQ′ to the search index parameters.
   Search query involves four steps. Step 1 reduces the dimensionality of the query vector from ddd to drd_{r}dr​ with A′A^{'}A′, b′b^{'}b′. Next, the output of the dimensionality reduction is used to compute the lookup table(LUT) with the quantization codebook CPQ′C^{PQ'}CPQ′ in step 2. Step 3 evaluates the drd_{r}dr​-dimension query vector with CIVF′C^{IVF'}CIVF′ to select the closest partitions for scanning using the LUT. k′≥kk^{'} \ge kk′≥k candidates are selected, and step 4 obtains the top kkk of them by comparing the query vector to their full vectors. The four steps in the search workflow can be mapped into two stages. The filter stage spand steps 1-3, where the majority of vectors are filtered out, leaving k′k^{'}k′ candidate vectors. The last step is the refine stage, when k′k^{'}k′ candidates are refined to the top kkk nearest vectors.
  To add vectors to HAKES-Index, the insert index parameters are utilized. Each new vector is transformed using the dimensionality reduction parameters and quantized using the codebook. It is then appended to both the corresponsing partition determined by the IVF centroids and the buffer holding full vectors. For deletion, HAKES-Index uses both tombstones to mark the deleted vectors. During the filter stage, the tombstones are checked before adding the vectors to the candidate set. The deleted vectors and their corresponding compressed vectors are removed by a compaction step that rewrites the partitions. This step happens when the index is being checkpointed or rebuilt. The latter is triggered by an update in the embedding model, or when the data size grows beyond certain sizes. This approach reduces the interference of deletion on the search and insert operations.

Index Construction

   We construct HAKES-Index following the procedure illustrated in Figure 5. Figure 5a shows the first step of building the base index. The insert index parameters initialized with existing processes and then the dateset is inserted into the index. Particularly, Optimal Product Quantization(OPQ) is employed to initialize AAA and CPQC^{PQ}CPQ, which iteratively finds a transformation matrix that minimizes the reconstruction error of a PQ codebook, and K-means is employed to initialize the IVF centroids, CIVFC^{IVF}CIVF. The bias vector bbb is zero. Next, the training set is prepared by sampling a set of vectors and obtaining their neighbors with the base index, as in Figure 5b. Note that another set of sampled pairs is used for validation. Then, we use a self-supervised training method to learn the search parameters, A′,b′A^{'}, b^{'}A′,b′ and CPQ′C^{PQ'}CPQ′, illustrated in Figure 5c, which is the key to HAKES-Index’s high performance at high recall. After training, the IVF centroids CIVF′C^{IVF'}CIVF′ are computed by partitioning the sample data with A,CIVFA, C^{IVF}A,CIVF, then recomputing the centroid for each partition after applying the learned A′A^{'}A′ and b′b^{'}b′ to vectors in it(Figure 5d). Finally, the newly learned A′.b′,CPQ′A^{'}. b^{'}, C^{PQ'}A′.b′,CPQ′ and CIVF′C^{IVF'}CIVF′, are installed in the index, as shown completed in Figure 5e, serving subsequent search queries.[ installed? no rebuild? 两套参数 ]
   The training process can run independently from the sering system. In practice, the index is first built and uses A,b,CIVF,CPQA, b, C^{IVF}, C^{PQ}A,b,CIVF,CPQ for both insert and search. As it serves requests, the system records samples, and the training process runs in the background. Once the training is finished, the new parameters A′,b′,CIVF′,CPQ′A^{'}, b^{'}, C^{IVF'}, C^{PQ'}A′,b′,CIVF′,CPQ′ can be used immediately to serve queries. In other words, HAKES-Index can be updated incrementally. Moreover, the construction of HAKES-Index is efficient. That reduces the time to rebuild the index for serving at an updated throughput-recall frontier, when the database sizes and distributions are significantly changed by insertion and deletion.

Learning Compression Parameters

  At the begining of training process, A′A^{'}A′ and CPQ′C^{PQ'}CPQ′ are initialized with AAA and CPQC^{PQ}CPQ that are produced by OPQ. The bias vector b′b^{'}b′ is initialized with zero. We then jointly oprtimize A′,b′A^{'}, b^{'}A′,b′ , and CPQ′C^{PQ'}CPQ′ to minimize the mismatch between the similarity score distribution after quantization and that of the original d-dimensional space. We only focus on the mismatch in a local region that the training objective is defined based on the similarity score distributions of a sampled query vector xxx and its close neighbors ANNxANN_{x}ANNx​, because distinct vectors are filtered away by soarse grained IVF partition selection during search in HAKES-Index. Specifically, the similarity score distribution before and after the dimensionality reduction are:

So,x=softmax([d(x,v1),…,d(x,vK)])(2)S_{\mathrm{o}, \mathbf{x}} = \mathrm{softmax}\big([d(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{v}_1), \ldots, d(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{v}_K)]\big) \tag{2}So,x​=softmax([d(x,v1​),…,d(x,vK​)])(2)

Sr,x=softmax([d(R′(x),R(v1)),…,d(R′(x),R(vK))])(3)S_{\mathrm{r},\mathbf{x}} = \mathrm{softmax}\big([d(R'(\mathbf{x}), R(\mathbf{v}_1)), \ldots, d(R'(\mathbf{x}), R(\mathbf{v}_K))]\big) \tag{3}Sr,x​=softmax([d(R′(x),R(v1​)),…,d(R′(x),R(vK​))])(3)

  where K=∣ANNx∣K=|ANN_{x}|K=∣ANNx​∣ is the number of retrieved close neighbors, and the softmax function converts the similarity scores to a distribution. R′(x)=A′x+b′R^{'}(x)=A^{'}x+b^{'}R′(x)=A′x+b′ and R(v)=Av+bR(v)=Av + bR(v)=Av+b represent dimensionality reduction. The distribution of the similarity scores after quantization is:

Sq,x=softmax([d(R′(x),q′(R(v1))),…,d(R′(x),q′(R(vK))])(4)S_{q,\mathbf{x}} = \mathrm{softmax}\big([d(R'(\mathbf{x}), q'(R(\mathbf{v}_1))), \ldots, d(R'(\mathbf{x}), q'(R(\mathbf{v}_K))]\big) \tag{4}Sq,x​=softmax([d(R′(x),q′(R(v1​))),…,d(R′(x),q′(R(vK​))])(4)

  where the vector approximation q′(v)=[q1′(v),q2′(v),...,qm′(v)]q^{'}(v)=[q_{1}^{'}(v), q_{2}^{'}(v),...,q_{m}^{'}(v)]q′(v)=[q1′​(v),q2′​(v),...,qm′​(v)] from PQ is modified to use both C^{PQ} and C^{PQ’}. Specifically, qj(v)=CjPQ′[argmin∣∣CjPQ[i]−vj∣∣]q_{j}(v)=C^{PQ'}_{j}[argmin||C^{PQ}_{j}[i] - v_{j}||]qj​(v)=CjPQ′​[argmin∣∣CjPQ​[i]−vj​∣∣]. It means that the indexes of the centroids of the codebook are produced by CPQC^{PQ}CPQ and the fine-tuned centroids of cPQ′c^{PQ'}cPQ′ at the corresponding position are used to approximate the vector.
  With the distributions of similarity scores, we can then reduce the mismatch by minimizing the Kullback-Leibler(KL) divergence defined over two pairs of distributions. One pairs is defined between the distribution in the original vector space(Equation 2) and that in the vector space after dimensionality reduction(Equation 3). The other pair is between (Equation2) and the distribution of similarity score calculated between a query vector after dimensionality reduction and its quantized close neighbors(Equation 4). The overall training objective is as follows:

L=−∑x∈DsampleSolog⁡Sr,xSo,x−λ∑x∈DsampleSo,xlog⁡Sq,xSo,x(5)L = -\sum_{\mathbf{x} \in D_{\text{sample}}} S_{o} \log \frac{S_{r,\mathbf{x}}}{S_{o,\mathbf{x}}} -\lambda \sum_{\mathbf{x} \in D_{\text{sample}}} S_{o,\mathbf{x}} \log \frac{S_{q,\mathbf{x}}}{S_{o,\mathbf{x}}} \tag{5}L=−x∈Dsample​∑​So​logSo,x​Sr,x​​−λx∈Dsample​∑​So,x​logSo,x​Sq,x​​(5)

  where DsampleD_{sample}Dsample​ is the sampled query vectors for training, and λ\lambdaλ is a hyperparameter to control the strength of the regularization.
  Thr training process iteratively updates A′,b′,Cpq′A^{'}, b^{'}, C^{pq'}A′,b′,Cpq′ to minimize the loss function defined in Equation 5 that is to minimize the mismatch among three similarity distributions for close vectors as illustrated in Figure 5c. It stops when the loss reduction computed on the validation set is smaller than a thresholds(e.g., 0.1).

Search Optimizations

  HAKES-Index contains two additional optimizations that improve search efficiency:

  1. The first is INT8 scalar quantization at each dimension of the IVF centroids, which allows using SIMD to evaluate 4x more dimensions in a single instruction
  2. The second optimization is to adapt the cost of filter stage based on the query. Fixing the value of nprobenprobenprobe means that the computation cost is roughly the same for every query, but in high-dimensional space, it is challenging to determine the nprobenprobenprobe based solely on the centroids. HAKES-Index introduces a heuristic ondition for early stopping the scanning of subsequent partitions based on the intermediate search results. The search process ranks the partition by the similarity score their centroids to the query, and scans the partitions in order. The key idea is that, as the search process moves away from the query vector, new partitions will contribute fewer vectors to the candidate set. We track the count of consecutively scanned partitions that each partition adds fewer than ttt vectors to the candidate set, where ttt is a search configuration parameter. When that count exceeds a specific threshold ntn_{t}nt​, it indicates that the search has likely covered all partitions containing nearest neighbors, and we terminate the filter stage. HAKES-Index terminates the filter stage either when the heuristic condition above is met, or when nprobsnprobsnprobs partitions have been scanned.

The HAKES Distributed VectorDB

Overview

  HAKES-Index processes a search query in two stages, namely the filter and refine stage. These stages do not share data, and they have distinct resource requirements due the types and amount of vectors being evaluated. We design an architecture that exploits the filter-and-refine design to disaggregate the two stages. In particular, we separate the management of the filter-stage index from the full-precision, original vectors used only in the refine stage. There are two sets of workers, the IndexWorkers and the RefineWorkers, each performs one stage of the index using the local data. The former are responsible for the filter stage, managing the replicated compressed vectors. The latter performs the refine stage, storing shards of the original vectors. And we stree that thess components can be disaggregated and scaled indenpendently.
  Discussion. HAKES architecture is different from that of existing distributed vector databases. Figure 7 compares four architectures with distinct shard layouts and communication for read and write. In the first architecture(Figure 7a), each server hosts a single read-write shard and maintains it index. A read request merges search results from every node, while a write request is routed to a single server based on a sharding policy. In the second architecture(Figure 7b), each node maintains one read-write shard and multiple read-only shards to reduce the read-write contention. The third architecture in Figure 7c extends the first two by employing multiple read-write shards and multiple read-only shard, which supports scaling out of read or wirte by adding servers for the required type of shards. We note that in these three architectures, an index is local to the shard data, i.e., the index of each sahrd is not constructed over the global set of vectors. However, building many samll indexes over multiple shards incurs significant overhead. HAKES’s architecture in Figure 7d, in contrast, maintains the global index at each server, since the filter stage index is small due to compression and supports efficient update.

HAKES Design

  The IndexWorker maintains a replica of the filter-stage index and the compressed vectors organized in IVF partitions. It takes a query vector as input and returns a set of candidate vectors. IndexWorker is compute-heavy. It implements dynamic batching with internal, lock-free task queues. In particular, vectors from different requests are batched into a matrix such that the dimensionality reduction and IVF assignment can be computed efficiently via matrix-matrix multiplication. Requests are batched only under high load, otherwise, they are processed immediately on separate CPU cores.
   The RefineWorker maintains a shard of the original vectora. It handles the refine stage, which evaluates similarity scores between the query and the candidate vectors belonging to the shard. HAKES supports two types of sharding polices for the full vectors. One policy is sharding by vector ID, in which vectors are distributed (evenly) amng the nodes by their IDs. The other is sharding by IVF assignment, in which vectors belonging to the same IVF partition are on the same REfineWroker. This policy helps reduce network communication because the refine stages only happen on a small number of nodes.
  Operation workflow. Before serving queries, HAKES builds an index over a given datase. It first takes a representative sample of the dataset to initialize the base index parameters. It then launches IndexWorkers that use the base index. Next, it inserts the vectors, and after that starts serving search requests. It builds training datasets for learning index parameters by collecting the results of ANN queries. Once the training process finishes, it installs the new parameters to all IndexWorkers with minimal disruption. Specifically, at every IndexWorker node, the new parameters are loaded to memory and the pointers in HAKES-Index are redirected to them.
   During search, the client sends the query to an IndexWorker and gets back the candidate vectors. Based on the sharding configuration, the client sends these vectors to the corresponding RefineWorkers in parallel. The client reranks the vectors returned by the RefineWorkers and outputs the top kkk vectors. During insert, the client sends the new vector to the RefineWroker that manages the shard where the vector is to be inserted. The client then picks an IndexWorker to compute the new quantized vector and update the IVF structure. This update is broadcast to all the IndexWorkers. For deletion, the client broadcasts the vector IDs to be deleted to all IndexWorkers, which then mark them as deleted in their filter-stage index.

References

  • Open Source
  • HU G, CAI S, DINH T T A, 等. HAKES: Scalable Vector Database for Embedding Search Service[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-08-01]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2505.12524.

entry.title: SIEVE, Effective Filtered Vector Search with Collection of Indexes
entry.content:
Overview

  Filtered vector search, is challenging as prior state-of-the-art graph-based(unfiltered) simialarity search tenchiques degenarate when hard constraints are considered: effective graph-based filtered similarity search relies on sufficient connectivity for reaching similar items within a few hops. To consider predicates, recent works propose modifying graph traversal to visit only items that satisfy predicates. However, they fail to offer the just-a-few-hops property for a wide range of predicates: they must restrict predicates significantly or lose efficiceny if only few items satisfy predicates.
  We propose an opposite approache: instead of constraining traversal, we build many indexes each serving different predicate forms. For effective construction, we devise a three-dimensional analytical model capturing relationships among index size, search time, and recall, with which we follow a workload-aware approache to pack as many useful indexes as possible into a collection. At query time, the analytical model is employed yet again to discern the one that offers the fastest search at a given recall.

Details

Preliminary

  SIEVE builds on HNSW, a graph-based vector index which combines the idea of small-world and skiip-lists to create a multi-layer graph structure for effective simiarity search over vector datasets. To serve for filtered vector search, SIEVE uses result-set-filtering in HNSW indexes as it is applicable without specialized graph construction, which may incur excessive time-to-index(TTL) and limit discussion to result-set-filtering in the following sections.(Note: SIEVE can also use ACORN’s filtering instead given minor adjutsments)

Framework Overview

  SIEVE effectively serves filtered vector queries by building and using an index collection.

SIEVE Construction

  During construction, SIEVE aims to build a colection of the most beneficial HNSW subindexes given a memory budget and traget recall on the data distribution and a historical query workload.
  Inputs. SIEVE takes as input (1) an attributed vector dataset, (2) a historical query workload–a set of query filters with probability/frequency counts, (3) a target recall, and (4) a memory budget.[ SIEVE does not restrict attribute or filter forms, only requiring filters to be evaluable on attributes]
  Cost Modeling. SIEVE models candidate indexes’ memory size and serving speed given their construction with sufficient density/M to serve queries at the target recall. It then accordingly sets up the candidates’ unit(marginal) benefits for optimizations.
  Optimization. SIEVE selects the subindexes to build under the memory budget with. greedy submodular optimization, prioritizing high-unit marginal benefit and/or high (re)use-probability subindexes in a manner akin to Materialized View Selection.
  Indexing. SIEVE builds the chosen sunindexes over the datasets. SIEVE always includes the base index over the entire vector dataset in the collection, which acts as a fallback for queries that any other subindex in the collection connot effectively handle. This design choice allows SIEVE to handle arbitrary (un-)filtered queries.

Serving Queries with SIEVE

  For serving, SIEVE aims to choose the optimal search method for fitered queries based on the subindexed in the built collection and (a potentially different from construction-time) target recall.
  Identifying the Optimal Indexed Search. The first, straightforward approach SIEVE uses for serving a query is with a built subindex. SIEVE finds the best subindex/sef combination for serving the query at target recall(preferably a small subindex in which the query is dense, using low sef)
  Choosing Search Method. SIEVE chooses between serving the query with the best-found subindex/sef combination or brute-force KNN. SIEVE estimates serving speed of both methods with its cost model, then chooses the faster one, analogous to MV-aware query rewriting.

Index Collection Construction(Problem Setup)

  This section defines SIEVE’s problem: candidate subindexes for construction and their benefits/costs(i.e., index speed/size when serving queries at target recall), then formalized SIEVE-Opt.
  Candidate Subindex DAG. There are expotentially many possible subindexes for an attributed dataset. Besides the base index, SIEVE limits its problem space by only considering subindexes corresponding to filters in H\mathcal{H}H. For optimization, SIEVE organizes candidates in a directed acyclic graph(DAG) where edges represent subsumption, which enables computing of subindex until marginal benefits.
  Defining Target Recall. Without loss of generality, SIEVE takes in a base M∞M_{\infty}M∞​ value for calibrating the query serving target recall, defined as the average recall of searching in the base index I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ built with M=M∞M=M_{\infty}M=M∞​ and sef=ksef=ksef=k, where kkk is the number of results to return and the lower bound of sefsefsef
  Indexing Parameters at Target Recall. SIEVE aims to build subindexes with sufficient parameters to serve queries at traget recall. Either MMM(for construction) or sefsefsef(for serving) can be tuned to achieve this; however, for construction, SIEVE assumes that all subindexes will use a uniform minimum sef=ksef = ksef=k and tunes only MMM: this is because sef=ksef = ksef=k is the lowest-recall and fastest search parameterization; if SIEVE’s subindexes(with sufficient MMM) serves queries at target recall with sef=ksef = ksef=k, SIEVE’s index collection can too; hence, SIEVE can then evaluate subindexes based on highest potential speedups. Versus M∞M_{\infty}M∞​ used for I∞I_{\infty}I∞​, candidate subindexes S(Ih)S(I_{h})S(Ih​) are evaluated and built with downscaled MMM:
  The subindex MMM downscaling function M↓M_{\downarrow}M↓​ takes in a subindex IhI_{h}Ih​, and returns the MMM value required to build IhI_{h}Ih​ with to achieve at least the same average query serving recall as the base index I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ built with M∞:M↓(Ih):=M∞log(card(h))log(N)M_{\infty}: M_{\downarrow}(I_{h}) := \frac{M_{\infty}log(card(h))}{log(N)}M∞​:M↓​(Ih​):=log(N)M∞​log(card(h))​. (Intuition: HNSW graph layers are based on Delaunay graphs, which requires suitable node degrees for effective search. Hence, each subindex Ih′sI_{h}'sIh′​s M should match its size’s logarithm: M↓(Ih)∝log(card(h))M_{\downarrow}(I_{h}) \propto log(card(h))M↓​(Ih​)∝log(card(h)))
  Subindex Memory Size. Each subindex IhI_{h}Ih​ has a memory size proportional to indexed points card(h)card(h)card(h) and MMM: S(Ih)=M⋅card(h)S(I_{h}) = M \cdot card(h)S(Ih​)=M⋅card(h). Notably, due to MMM’s effect on mmeory, SIEVE’s M downscaling(M↓M_{\downarrow}M↓​) saves memory for smaller subindexes, enabling more subindexes to be built under the same memory constraint versus a naive method that builds all subindexes with a uniform M∞M_{\infty}M∞​.
  Subindex Search Cost. SIEVE defines subindexes’ search cost as their serving latency. The Indexed Searched Cost Function CCC takes a subindex IhI_{h}Ih​, sef, and a filtered query (w,f)(w,f)(w,f), and returns the expected latency of using IhI_{h}Ih​ with sef to serve (w,f): C(h,sef,w,f)=log⁡(card(h))⋅sef⋅cor(w,f,h)card(f)C(h, \text{sef}, w, f) = \log(\text{card}(h)) \cdot \text{sef} \cdot \frac{\text{cor}(w, f, h)}{\text{card}(f)}C(h,sef,w,f)=log(card(h))⋅sef⋅card(f)cor(w,f,h)​
  SIEVE bases CCC on that HNSW’s search time scales logarithmically with graph size and linearly with sefsefsef, and there is card(h)card(f)\frac{card(h)}{card(f)}card(f)card(h)​ probability that a data vector similar to the query vector www passes the filter with result-set-filtering, scaled by query correlation——cor(w,f,h)——ratio of average distance from www to points that satisfy fff in IhI_{h}Ih​ versus non-satisfying points. Positive correlation (cor(w,f,h)<1)(cor(w,f,h) \lt 1)(cor(w,f,h)<1) improves query performance, mitigating low selectivity’s effects as satisfying vectors are reached faster. Conversely, negative correlation (cor(w,f,h)>1)(cor(w,f,h) \gt 1)(cor(w,f,h)>1) amplifies low selectivity’s impact and increases query cost. SIEVE assumes constant correlation across all subindexes and filters, i.e., cor(w,f,h)==ccor(w,f,h) == ccor(w,f,h)==c, and for discussion, set c=1c = 1c=1 and simplify C(Ih,sef,w,f)C(I_{h},sef,w,f)C(Ih​,sef,w,f) as C(Ih,f)C(I_{h},f)C(Ih​,f) (as sef is also assumed to be fixed at 1) in this section. Note that SIEVE constrains for simplicity that a subindex IhI_{h}Ih​ can only serve a query with filter fff if hhh subsumes fff; otherwise, C(Ih,f)=∞C(I_{h},f) = \inftyC(Ih​,f)=∞
  Brute-force Search Cost. Any query (w,f) can be served via brute-force KNN, performing distance computations between www and all vectors in V,A{V,A}V,A that satisfy fff, i.e., Vf:={vi∣f(ai)=1}V_{f}:=\left \{ v_{i}|f(a_{i})=1 \right \}Vf​:={vi​∣f(ai​)=1}. This trivially incurs cost Cbf(f)=card(f)C_{bf}(f)=card(f)Cbf​(f)=card(f) linear to the cardinality.
  Aligning Search cost. The alignment between indexed and brute-force search cost is influenced by factors such as distance function implementation and index memory access patterns. Hence, SIEVE scales the brute-force search cost CbfC_{bf}Cbf​ with a constant γ∈R+\gamma \in R+γ∈R+ for alignment: SIEVE compares CCC with γ⋅Cbf\gamma \cdot C_{bf}γ⋅Cbf​ when evaluating indexed versus brute-force search. For illustration purpose, however, we assume γ=1\gamma = 1γ=1. The aligned cost allow us to define the cost of the best serving method for a query (w,f)(w,f)(w,f) given an index collection III:
  The collection query serving cost function CCC takes in a subindex collection I:=Ih1,...,IhxI := I_{h1}, ..., I_{hx}I:=Ih1​,...,Ihx​ and a filtered vector query (w,f)(w,f)(w,f), and returns the cost of the best possible serving strategy given I:C(I,f):=min(Cbf(f),min({C(Ih,f)∣Ih∈I}))I: C(I,f) := min(C_{bf}(f), min(\left \{ C(I_{h},f)|I_{h}\in I \right \}))I:C(I,f):=min(Cbf​(f),min({C(Ih​,f)∣Ih​∈I})). With the collection of server cost C(I,f)C(I,f)C(I,f) and index size S(Ih)S(I_{h})S(Ih​), SIEVE’s optimization problem, SIEVE-opt, can be defined:

  Presence of the Base Index. SIEVE enforces that I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ must exist for handling arbitrary filtered queries. Worst case, SIEVE can serve queries with the better of I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ or brute-force KNN, which lower-bounds SIEVE’s serving performance.

SIEVE-opt Solution

  This section presents our solution to SIEVE-Opt, whose formulation naturally gives rise to a greedy solution for subindex selection.
  Marginal Benefits. Add a new index IhI_{h}Ih​ into III decreases the collection query serving cost by its marginal benefit w.r.t. H:C(I,H)−C(I∪{Ih},H)≥0 ∀I,H,IhH:C(I,H) - C(I \cup \left \{ I_{h} \right \},H) \ge 0 \space \forall I,H,I_{h}H:C(I,H)−C(I∪{Ih​},H)≥0 ∀I,H,Ih​. This property can generalizable:

C(I∪{hi},H)−C(I,H)⏟large marginal benefit≤C(J∪{hi},H)−C(J,H)⏟small marginal benefit∀I⊆J\underbrace{C(\mathcal{I} \cup \{h_i\}, \mathcal{H}) - C(\mathcal{I}, \mathcal{H})}_{\text{large marginal benefit}} \leq \underbrace{C(\mathcal{J} \cup \{h_i\}, \mathcal{H}) - C(\mathcal{J}, \mathcal{H})}_{\text{small marginal benefit}} \quad \forall \mathcal{I} \subseteq \mathcal{J}large marginal benefitC(I∪{hi​},H)−C(I,H)​​≤small marginal benefitC(J∪{hi​},H)−C(J,H)​​∀I⊆J

  That is, the qeury serving cost C(I,H)C(I,H)C(I,H) is a supermodular set function w.r.t. III, and SIEVE-Opt is a supermodular minimization problem with the knapsack memory constrains BBB. This problem class give rise to an empirically effective greedy algorithm——GreedyRatio: It starts with I={I∞}I= \left \{ I_{\infty} \right \}I={I∞​}, then iteartively adds the highest marginal benefit/index size ratio subindex(unit marginal benefit C(I∪{hi},H)−C(I,H)S(Ih)\frac { C(\mathcal{I} \cup \{h_i\}, \mathcal{H}) - C(\mathcal{I}, \mathcal{H})}{S(I_{h})}S(Ih​)C(I∪{hi​},H)−C(I,H)​) until reaching the constraint.

Query Serving

   This section describes SIEVE’s dynamic serving strategy with the built index collection and a target recall(potentially differenct from construction-time). SIEVE first finds the optimal subindex for an incoming query, then determines the optimal search method-parameterized index search or brute-force KNN.

Identifying the Optimal Subindex

  This section describes how SIEVE finds optimal subindexs for query serving. SIEVE’s cost model dictates that a query (w,f)(w,f)(w,f) is best served with the smallest subindex IhI_{h}Ih​ in I\mathcal{I}I where the subindex filter hhh subsumes the query filter fff, following uniform query correlation assumptions in Section “Problem Setup”.
  Index Collection DAG. SIEVE builds a DAG, specifically, a Hasse diagram, over the index collection: given two subindexes Ih,Iq∈II_{h}, I_{q} \in \mathcal{I}Ih​,Iq​∈I, a directed edge (Ih,Iq)(I_{h},I_{q})(Ih​,Iq​) exists only if hhh subsumes qqq, and there is no other Iu∈II_{u} \in \mathcal{I}Iu​∈I such that hhh subsumes uuu, and uuu subsumes qqq.
   DAG Traversal. For a filter query (w,f)(w,f)(w,f), the index collection DAG can be efficiently traversed via BFS starting from the root I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ to find the best subindex IhI_{h}Ih​: at each step, if the current subindex IqI_{q}Iq​'s filter does not subsume fff, none of its descendants can either. In other words, for any descendant IpI_{p}Ip​ of IqI_{q}Iq​ in the DAG, ppp cannot subsume fff, allowing the entire subgraph rooted at IqI_{q}Iq​ to be pruned from the search.
  Remark. SIEVE currently subsumptions for travering the Hasse diagram logically(i.e., A is subsumed by A-OR-B). However, in case where logical subsumption is rare(i.e., complex filter and attribute space), other subsumption such as bitvector-based subsumption can be used in its place[ 如何拓展到更复杂的关系 ]

Determining Optimal Search Strategy

   This section outlines how SIEVE determines the serving method based on the best-found subindex. It first determines the search parameter(sef) required for the (new) target recall, then choose between indexed search with the found sefsefsef or brute-force KNN.
  Search Parameterization. Like M∞M_{\infty}M∞​, users provide a global sef∞sef_{\infty}sef∞​ to SIEVE(potentially different from the assumed build-time sef=k) for each query representing the serving-time target recall, defined as the expected recall of (over-)searching the base index I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ with sef∞sef_{\infty}sef∞​ . And SIEVE aims to serve queries with sefsefsef values to match the target recall; hence, versus sef∞sef_{\infty}sef∞​, lower sefsefsef(increments) can be used when serving queries with subindexes.
   The Subindex sefsefsef downscaling function S↓S_{\downarrow }S↓​ takes in a subindex IhI_{h}Ih​, and returns the sefsefsef value required to search IhI_{h}Ih​ with to achieve at least the same average query serving recall as searching the base index I∞I_{\infty}I∞​ with sef∞:S↓(Ih):=max(k,sef∞log(card(h))log(N))sef_{\infty}: S_{\downarrow}(I_{h}) := max(k,\frac{sef_{\infty}log(card(h))}{log(N)})sef∞​:S↓​(Ih​):=max(k,log(N)sef∞​log(card(h))​), where kkk is the neighbors to query (and minimum value of sef) and assuming IhI_{h}Ih​ was built with proportional M=M↓(Ih)M=M_{\downarrow}(I_{h})M=M↓​(Ih​)
  SIEVE’s intution for S↓S_{\downarrow}S↓​ is that HNSW search visits O(logn)O(logn)O(logn) points in its hierarchical structure: to maintain recall, the proportion between sefsefsef – the dynamic closest neighbors list size – and lognlognlogn must be maintained, i.e., lists must cover a consistent proportion of the visited lognlognlogn points, hence S↓(Ih)∝log(card(h))S_{\downarrow}(I_{h}) \propto log(card(h))S↓​(Ih​)∝log(card(h)).
  Indexes vs Brute-force Search. Given a query (w,f)(w,f)(w,f), its best subindex IhI_{h}Ih​, and downscaled sefh=S↓(Ih)sef_{h}=S_{\downarrow}(I_{h})sefh​=S↓​(Ih​), SIEVE chooses between serving the query with indexed or brute-force KNN with its cost model from Section “Problem Setup”: it chooses the lower-cost method out indexed search (C(Ih,sefh,f))(C(I_{h},sef_{h},f))(C(Ih​,sefh​,f)) and brute-force search (γCbf(f))(\gamma C_{bf}(f))(γCbf​(f))

References

  • source code on github
  • LI Z, HUANG S, DING W, 等. SIEVE: Effective Filtered Vector Search with Collection of Indexes[EB/OL]. (2025-07-20)[2025-07-27]. http://arxiv.org/abs/2507.11907.

entry.title: VSAG, An Optimized Search Framework for Graph-based ANNS
entry.content:
Overview

  Recent graph-based ANNS algorithms have achieved high search accuracy with pratical efficiency. Despite the advancements, these algorithms still fac performance bottlenecks in production, due to the random memory access patterns of graph-based search and the high computational overheads of vector distances. In addition, the performance of a graph-based ANNS algorithm is highly sensitive to parameters, while selecting the optimal parameters is cost-prohibitive, e.g., manual tuning requires repeatedly re-building the index.
  This paper introduces VSAG, an open-source framework that aims to ehance the in production performance of graph-based ANNS algorithms. VSAG incorporates three key optimizations:

  1. efficient meory access: it reduces L3 cache misses with pre-fectching and cache-friendly vector organization
  2. automated parameter tuning: it automatically selects performance-optimal parameters without requiring index rebuilding
  3. efficient distance computation: it leverages modern hardware, scalar quantization, and smartly witches to low-precision representation to dramatically reduce the distance computation costs

Details

Framework

  VSAG integrates memory access optimization, automatic parameter tuning and distance computation optimizations into different phases for the search process. First, the PRS manages the storage of vector data and graph indexes. It stored low-precision quantized codes of vectors alongside high-precision orignal vectors to support distance computation optimization. This redundant storage is also utilized to balance resource usage and reduce memory access costs. Second, during each hop of the search process when exploring a vector, we employ Deterministic Access Greedy Search to accelerate memory access by minimizing cache misses. Finally, the visited results are pushed into a heap. We apply Selective Re-Rank to combine low- and high- precision distances, ensuring effective search performance. The search process then pops the nearest unfinished point from the heap and proceeds to the next hop. Throughout the entire life-cycle of the index, VSAG uses a smart auto-tuner to select parameters that deliver the best search performance across varying environments and retrieval requirements.

Memory Access Optimization

  deterministic Access: Distance computations for neighboring vectors often incur random memory access patterns in graph-based algorithms, leading to significant cache misses. VSAG addresses this by integrating software prefetching through a Deterministic Access strategy. VSAG strategically inserts prefetch instructions during and before critical computations, proactively loading target data into L3/high-level caches. Further more, the VSAG framework efficiently mitigates suboptimal prefetch operations through batch processing and reordering of the access sequence.
  PRS: VSAG introduces a Paritcal Redundant Storage(PRS) design(embeds compressed neighbor vectors at each graph node), which provides a flexible and high-performance stirage foundation to optimize both distance computations and memory access while balancing storage and computational resource usuage
  Balance of Resources: In particular, the system uses a parameter called the redundancy ratio δ\deltaδ to control the Balance of Computational Efficiency and Memory Utilization. In compute-bound scenarios with high-throughout demands, VASG adaptively increases the redundancy ratio to mitigate cache contention, thus minimizing CPU idle cycles during memory access while preserving storage efficiency.

Automatic Parameter Tuning

  VSAG address papramter selection complexity through a tripartite classification system with specialized optimization strategies:

  • Environment-level Parameters(ELPs): VSAG employs a grid search to identify optimal configurations for peak QPS performance through systematic parameter space exploration
  • Query-level Parameters(QLPs): VSAG implements multi-granular tuning strategies, including fine-grained adaptive optimization that dynamically adjusts parameters based on real-time query difficulty assessments
  • Index-level Parameters(ILPs): VSAG introduces a novel mask-based index compression technique that encodes multiple parameter configurations into an unified index structure. During searches edge-label filtering dynamically emulates various construction parameters, thereby reducing index-level parameters to query-level equivalents while keeping a single physical index

Distance Computation Optimization

  Quantization methods can efficiently accelerate distance computation. However, naive quantization approaches often result in significant accuracy degradation. VSAG uses Selective Re-rank to improve efficiency without sacrificing the search accuracy. Furthermore, specific distance metrics(i.e., euclidean distance) can be strategically decomposed and precomputed, effectively reducing the number of required instructions during actual search operations.

Memory Access Optimzation

  The fundamental strategy for mitigating cache-related latency lies in effectively utilizing vector computation intervals to prefetch upcoming memory requests into cache. In VSAG, three primary optimization strategies emerge for maximizing cache utiliation efficiency:

  • Leveraging software prefetching to improve cache hits rates
  • Optimizing search patterns to enhance the effectiveness of software prefetching
  • Optimizing the memory layout of indexes to efficiently utilize hardware prefetching

Software-based Prefetch: Making Random Meory Accesses Logically Continuous

  As shown in Figure 2, when computing vector distances, the vector is loaded sequentially from a segment of memory. But modern CPUs support software prefetch instructions, which can asynchronously load data into different levels of the cache. By leveragign the prefetch instruction to preload data, we can achieve a nrea-sequential memory access pattern from the CPU level. This indicates that data is preloaded into the cache before the CPU requires it, thereby preventing disruptions in the computational flaw caused by random memory address loads. More specifically, prior to computing the distance for the current neighbor, the vector for the next neighbor can be prefeched.
