As detailed in Figure 2, the green flow represents the use of prefetching. From the perspective of the CPU, the majority of distance computations make use data that has already been cached. Furthermore, because prefetching operates asynchronously, it does not obstruct ongoing computations. The synergy of asynchronous prefetching and immediate data access optimizes the utilization of CPU computational resources, thereby substantially enhancing search performance.

  The software-based prefetch mechanism initiates the fetching of next-neighbor vector upon completion of each neighbor computation. However, this method results in redundant operations because previously visited neighbors that do not require distance computations still generate prefetch time cost. In this section, we present two dedicated strategies to address the challenges.
  Deterministic Access: In contrast to prefetching during edge access checks, VSAG exclusively prefetches only those edges that have not been accessed. The mechanism begins by batch-processing all neighbor nodes to determine their access status. Following this, unvisited neighbors are logically grouped, and prefetching is performed collectively. This strategic approach ensures that each prefetched memory address corresponds exclusively to computation-essential data, thereby enhancing prefetching efficiency and minimizing redundant memory operations.
  Stride Prefetch: Batch processing ensures that each prefetch retrieves data intended for future use. However, prefetch effectiveness varies due to the asynchronous nature of prefetching and the absence of a callback mechanism to confirm prefetch completion. Optimal performance occurs when the required data reside in th cache precisely when the computation flow demands it. Premature prefetching risks cache evicion, while delayed prefetching negates performance again. The necessitates balancing prefetch timing with computation duration. To address this, stride prefetching dynamically aligns hardware computation throughput with software prefetching rates, maximizing prefetch utility. The key parameter, the prefetch stride w\mathcal{w}w, determines how many computation steps occur before each prefetch.

PRS: Flexible Storage Layout Boosting Search Performance

  While incorporating well-designed prefetch pattern into search processes can theoretically improve performance, their inherent limitations of software-based prefetch compared with hardware-based prefetch prevent guranteed memory availability for all required vectors(i.e., advisory but nor mandatory commands, cache line contention, intrinsic cost disparity between prefetch mechanisms).
  Hardware-based prefetching relies on hardware mechanisms that adaptively learn from cache miss events to predicate memory access patterns. The system employs a training buffer that dynamically identifies recurring data access sequences to automatically prefetch anticipated data into the cache hierarchy. The training mechanism shows particular effectiveness for Sequential Memory Access patters, where it can rapidly detect and exploit sequential memory access characteristics(IVF 系列索引比较适合). Conversely, graph-based ndexing architectures exhibit irregular access pattern with poor spatical locality, resulting in inefficient Random Memory Access. The inherent randomness of access sequences prevents the training buffer from establishing effective pattern recognition models.
   VSAG integrates the benefits of space-partitioned indexes into graph-based indexing algorithms through redundant vector torage. By co-locating neighbor lists with their corresponding vectors within each node’s data structure, it achieves Sequential Memory Access. This design ensures that neighbor retrieval operations only require sequential access within contiguous memory regions, thereby fully leveraging hardware prefetching capabilities.[ Figure 1]
  To address the computational-memory resource imbalance caused by fixed instance specifications in industrial applications, we propose PRS to take advantage of hardware prefetching to reduce CPU idle time. A dynamically tunable redundancy ratio δ\deltaδ controls the proportion of redundantly stored neighbor vectors in graph indexes, balancing prefetch efficiency and CPU utilization. When δ=1\delta = 1δ=1, full redundancy maximizes hardware prefetch benefits, achieving peak CPU utilization at the cost of higher memry consumption. In constrast, δ=0\delta = 0δ=0 eliminates redundancy to minimize memory usage but sacrifices prefetch efficiency.

Automatic Parameter Tuning

Search-based Automatic ELPs Tuner

  The environment-sensitive parameters(i.e., the prefetch stride w\mathcal{w}w, the prefetch depth vvv) xclusively influence algorithm efficiency metrics(e.g., QPS) while maintaining consistent effectiveness outcomes(e.g., Recall), thereby enbling independent optimization distinct from core algorithmic logic. The VSAG tunning framework implements an optimizaed three-step procedure:

  1. Conduct an exhaustive grid search for all combiniations of environment-dependent parameter
  2. Evaluate performance metrics using sampled base vectors
  3. Select parameter configurations that maximize retrieval speed while maintaining operational stability

Fine-Grained Automatic QLPs Tuner

  Experiments results show that assigning personalized optimal retrieval parameters to each query can improve performance by 3-5 times. To address the observation of QLPs, we propose a Decision Model for query difficulty classification, enabling personalized parameter tuning while maintaining computational efficiency. We introduce a learning-based adaptive parameter selection framework through a GBDT classifier with early termination capabilities, demonstrating superior performance in fixed-recall scenarios. The model architecture addresses two critical constraints: discriminative power and computational efficiency. Our feature engineering process yields the following optimal feature set:

  • Cardinality of scanned points
  • Distribution of distances among ccurrent top-5 candidates
  • Temporal distance progression in recent top-5 results
  • Relative distance differentials between top-K candidates and optimal sulution

  The candidate size is initially set to a relatively large value(e.g., efs=300ef_{s}=300efs​=300). During the search process, after ttraversing certain hops in the graph, we employ the decision tree along with the current features to determine whether the candidate size should be reduced, which effectively prevents overly simple queries from undergoing extensive and unnecessary search process.

Labelling-based Automatic ILPs Tuner

  The retrieval efficiency and effectiveness of graph-based indexes are fundamentally determined by their structural properties. Modifications to ILPs induce concurrent alternations in both graph topology and search dynamics, creating non-linear interactions between retrieval speed and accuracy.
  Compression-Based Construction Framework: We empirically observe that indexes constructed with varying ILPs substantial edge overlap, as formalized in Theorem 4.1, when maintaining a fixed pruning rate α\alphaα, a graph built with lower maximum degree mcm_{c}mc​ consititues a strict subgraph of its higher-degree counterpart.
  Theorem 4.1(Maximum Degree-Induced Subgraph Hierarchy): Let GaG^{a}Ga and GbG^{b}Gb denote indexes constructued with maximum degrees mc=am_{c} = amc​=a and mc=bm_{c} = bmc​=b respectively, under identical initialization conditions and fixed α\alphaα. Given equivalent greedy search outcomes ANNk(x)ANN_{k}(x)ANNk​(x) for all points xxx under both configurations then a<b⟹Ga⊂Gba \lt b \Longrightarrow G^{a} \subset G^{b}a<b⟹Ga⊂Gb where ∀(xi,xj)∈E(Ga),(xi,xj)∈E(Gb)\forall (x_{i}, x_{j}) \in E(G^{a}), (x_{i},x_{j}) \in E(G^{b})∀(xi​,xj​)∈E(Ga),(xi​,xj​)∈E(Gb).
  The lifecycle of the index in VSAG is divided into three distinct pahses: building, tuning, and searching. In contrast, traditional indexing frameworks typically consist of only two phases: building and searching. They select edges to construct the index structure using a set of fixed index-leve parameters. The reason behind our design is that we believe it is insufficient to rely solely on the raw data for selecting edges during the construction phase. These parameters may need to be dynamically adjusted based on varying user requirements and query complexities.
  VSAG employs an index compression strategy that constructs the index once using relaxed ILPs while labeling edges with specific ILPs. Then, VSAG can dynamically select edges by leveraging labels, shifting the edge selection process from the index construction phase to the tuning phase. It enables adaptive edge selection without index construction. Thus, it achieves equivalent search performance to maintaining multiple indexes with different parameter configurations, while incurring onlt the overhead of constructing a single index. The parameter labeling mechanism maintains topological flexibility while enhancing storage efficiency through a compressed index representation.
  VSAG Index Construction Algorithms:In VSAG, the insertion process for each new point xix_{i}xi​ can be divided into three steps. First, a search is conducted on the graph to obtsain the ANNk(xi)ANN_{k}(x_{i})ANNk​(xi​) and their corresponding distances TiT_{i}Ti​. Next, pruning is performed on ANNk(xi)ANN_{k}(x_{i})ANNk​(xi​), and the edges along with their labels are addded to the graph index. Instead of performing actual pruning, VSAG assigns a label Li,jL_{i,j}Li,j​ to each edge in graph. Note that the label is used to indicate whether an edge exists under a certain construction parameter. Given asa_{s}as​, if Li,j≤asL_{i,j} \le a_{s}Li,j​≤as​, it indicates that the edge Gi,iG_{i,i}Gi,i​ exists in the graph constructed using asa_{s}as​ or larger value as the pruning rate. During the search and pruning process, only edges satisfying Li,j≤asL_{i,j} \le a_{s}Li,j​≤as​ need to be considered to retrieve the graph corresponding to the given construction parameters.
  Next, for each new neighbors, reverse edges are added, and pruning is performed. If the distance Ti,jT_{i,j}Ti,j​ from the current neighbor xjx_{j}xj​ to xix_{i}xi​ is greater than the maximum distance among xjx_{j}xj​'s neighbors and xjx_{j}xj​'s neighbor list is already full, no reverse edge is added. Otherwise, xix_{i}xi​ is inserted into xjx_{j}xj​'s neighbor list at an appropriate position rrr to maintain GjG_{j}Gj​ and TjT_{j}Tj​ in ascending order. Subsequently, pruning and lebeling are reapplied to the neighbors of xjx_{j}xj​ located after position rrr. Finally, the algorithm returns the edges GGG and labels LLL of the graph index.
  Prun-based Labeling Algorithm: The pruning strategy of VSAG is shown in Algorithm 2. First, we initialize the out-edges of xix_{i}xi​ by ANNk(xi)r:ANN_{k}(x_{i})_{r:}ANNk​(xi​)r:​. Each edge is then assigned a label of 0. Note that when r>0r \gt 0r>0, it indicates that the current pruning occurs during the reverse edge addition phase, and only the labels of edges within the interva [r:∣Gi∣][r:|G_{i}|][r:∣Gi​∣] need to be updated. Otherwise,all labels should be updated. We use countcountcount to record the number of neighbors that have non-zero labels. When count \eq r, it means we have already collected all the neighbors we need. At this point, the algorithm should terminae.
  Next, each aca_{c}ac​ is examined in ascending order. For each unlableed neighbor xjx_{j}xj​, neighbor xkx_{k}xk​ with smaller distance is used to make pruning decision. The pruning decision requires satisfying two conditions: (a)The neighbor xkx_{k}xk​ exists in the graph constructed with the ac(i.e.,0<Li,k≤ac)a_{c}(i.e., 0 \lt L_{i,k} \le a_{c})ac​(i.e.,0<Li,k​≤ac​). (b) The pruning condition is satisfied(i.e., ac⋅τ(xj,xk)≤τ(xi,xj)a_{c} \cdot \tau(x_{j},x_{k}) \le \tau(x_{i},x_{j})ac​⋅τ(xj​,xk​)≤τ(xi​,xj​)).Here, we accelerated the computation of τ(xi,xj)\tau(x_{i},x_{j})τ(xi​,xj​) by using the cached result Ti,jT_{i,j}Ti,j​. It no neighbor can prun xjx_{j}xj​ with aca_{c}ac​, it is assigned with label Li,j⟵acL_{i,j} \longleftarrow a_{c}Li,j​⟵ac​. Finally, the algorithm returns the neighbor set GiG_{i}Gi​ and the label set LiofxiL_{i} of x_{i}Li​ofxi​.( Building upon the parameter analysis of mcm_{c}mc​, we formally establish the subgraph inclusion property for graphs constructued with varying pruning rates aca_{c}ac​ in Algorithm 2 )

Distance Computation Acceleration

  Recent studies illustarte that the exact distance computation takes the majority of the time cost of graph-based ANNS. Approximate distance techniques, such as scalar quantization, can accelarate this process at the cost of reduced search accuracy. VSAG adopt a two-stage approach that first performs an approximation distance search followed by exact distance re-ranking.

Distance Computation Cost Analysis

  VSAG employs low-precision vectors during traversal operations while resercing precise distance computations exclusively for final result reranking. The dual-precision architecture effectively minimizes distance computation operations(DCO) overhead while preserving search accuracy through precision-aware hierarchical processing.
  It we only consider the cost incurred by distance computation, the total distance computation cost be expressed as follows:

cost=costlp+costhp=nlp⋅tlp+nhp⋅thpcost = cost_{lp} + cost_{hp} = n_{lp} \cdot t_{lp} + n_{hp} \cdot t_{hp}cost=costlp​+costhp​=nlp​⋅tlp​+nhp​⋅thp​

  The optimization of nlpn_{lp}nlp​ is closely related to specific algorithm workflow, while tlpt_{lp}tlp​ is primarily determined by the computational cost of FLOAT32 vector operations - both of which remain relatively constant. Consequently, the VSAG framework focus primarily on optimizing the parameter tlpt_{lp}tlp​ and nhpn_{hp}nhp​ in the three following ways:

  • The combination of quantization techiniques, hardware instruction set SIMD, and memory-efficient storage achieves exponential reduction in low-precision distance computation(tlpt_{lp}tlp​)
  • Enhanced quantization precision by parameter optimization mitigates candidate inflation from compression loss, achieving sublinear growth in required low-precision conputations(n_{hp})
  • Selective re-ranking with dynamic thresholding establishes an accuracy-efficiency equilibrium, restricing high-precision validation(nhpn_{hp}nhp​) to logarithmically scaled candidate subset

Minimizing Low-Precision Computation Overhead

  SIMD and Quantization Methods: Modern CPUs employs SIMD instruction sets(SSE/AVX/AVX512) to accelerate distance computations rhtough vectorized operations. The instructions process 128-bit, 256-bit, or 512-bit data chunks in parallel, with vector compression techniques enabling simultaneous processing of multiple vectors. Besides, Prodcut Quantization(PQ) enables high compression ratios for batch processing through SIMD-loaded lookup tables. While PR-Fast Scan excels in partition-based searches through block-wise computation, its effectiveness diminishes in graph-based searches due to random vector storage patterns and inability to filter visited nodes, resulting in wasted SIMD bandwidth. In contrast, Scalar Quantization(SQ) proves more suitable for graph algorithms by directly compressing vector dimensions(e.g., FLOAT32 -> INT8/INT4) without requiring lookup tables. As demonstrated in VSAG, SQ achieves the optimal balance between compression ratio and precission preservation while fully utilizing SIMD accelation capabilities, making it particully effective for memory-bound graph traversals/
  Distance Decomposition: VSAG optimizes Euclidean distance computations by decoupling static and dynamic components. The system precomputes and caches invariant vector norms during database indexing, then combines them with real-time dot product computations during queries. This decomposition reduces operational complexity while preserving mathematical equivalance, as shown by the reformulated distance:

∣∣xb−xq∣∣2=∣∣xb∣∣2+∣∣xq∣∣2−2xb⋅xq||x_{b} - x_{q}||^{2} = ||x_{b}||^2 + ||x_{q}||^{2} - 2x_{b} \cdot x_{q}∣∣xb​−xq​∣∣2=∣∣xb​∣∣2+∣∣xq​∣∣2−2xb​⋅xq​

  The computational optimization strategy can be summarized as follows: Only the Inner Product term xb⋅xqx_{b} \cdot x_{q}xb​⋅xq​ requires real-time computation during search operations, while the squared query nore ∣∣xq2∣∣||x_{q}^{2}||∣∣xq2​∣∣ can be pre-computed offline before initiating the search process. By storing just one additional FLOAT32 value per database vector xbx_{b}xb​(specifically the precomputed ∣∣xb2∣∣||x_{b}^{2}||∣∣xb2​∣∣), we can effectively transform the computationally expensive Euclidean distance computation into an equivalent inner product operation. This space-time tradeoff reduces the subtraction CPU instruction in distance computation, while saves one CPU cycle.

Improving Quantization Precision

  Scalar quantization(SQ) compresses floating-point vectors by mapping 32-bit float values to lower-bit integer representations in each dimension. In SQ-b(where b denotes bit-width), the dynamic range is uniformly partitioned into 2b2^{b}2b intervals. For SQ4(4-bit), this creates 16 intervals over [0,1][0,1][0,1], where the k-th interval corresponds to [(k−1)/15.k/15)[(k - 1)/15. k/15)[(k−1)/15.k/15). Values within each interval are encoded as their corresponding integer index. However, pratical implementations face critical range estimation challenges: direct use of observed min/max values proves subpotimal when data outliers existing.
  To enhance robustness, we propose Truncated Scalar Quantization using the 99th percentile statistics rather than absolute extremes. This approache discards outlier-induces distortions while preserving quantization resulution over the primary data distrbution, achieving superior balance between compression efficiency and numerical precision as shown in Firgure 6.

Selective Re-rank

  Quantization methos can significantly enhance retrieval efficiency, but quantization error may lead to substantial recall degradation. While re-ranking with full-precision vectors can mitigate this performance loss. Howevre, applying exhausitive re-ranking to all candidates is inefficient. The VSAG framework addresses this challenge through selective re-ranking, effectively compensating for approximation erros in distance computation without compromissing system performance. A straightforward approache is to select only the candidates with small low-precision distances for re-ranking. The optimal number of candidates requiring re-ranking varies significantly depending on query characteristics, quantization error distribution, and search requirement kkk. To address this dynamic requirement, VSAG implements DDC scheme that can automatically adapt re-ranking scope based on error-distance correlation analysis.

References

  • source code on Github
  • ZHONG X, LI H, JIN J, 等. VSAG: An Optimized Search Framework for Graph-based Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-07-08]. https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.17911.

entry.title: EnhanceGraph, A Continuously Enhanced Graph-based Index for High-dimensional ANNS
entry.content:
Overview

  In this paper, we address the issue that construction and search logs has not been well utilized in existing graph-based indexed for ANNS. We introduce the EnhanceGraph framework, which integrates two types of logs into a novel structure called conjugate graph. The conjugate graph is then used to improve search quality. For the search logs, the conjugate graph stores the edges from local optima to global optima to enhance routing to the nearest neighbor. For the construction logs, the conjugate graph stores the pruned edges from the proximity graph to enhance retrieving of k nearest neighbors.

Details

Framework

  We distinguish the edges of the proximity graph into two categories: routing edges and non-routing edges. Routing edges connect to the next nearest neighbor in the candidate set and are used to quickly locate the reion near the query during the search process for finding the finaly nearest neighbor. Non-routing edges do not change the next nearest neihbor in candidate set and are used to find the k-NNs. However, during the incremetal edge pruning process in the construction of proximity graph, it’s inevitable to encounter situations where these edges are not recognized.
  Utilzation of Search Log: we adopt a data-griven aproach using the search log. If we have the historical query logs, we can identify the local optimum that most queries converge to. A local optimum arises due to the absence of routing edges from the local optimum to the global optimum. If many similar queries all lead to the same local optimum, we can guarantee that all those queries can reach their global optimum by adding edges from the local optimum to the global optimum. Therefore, the search log can be utilized to continuously optimize the graph-based indexes.
  Utilization of Construction Log: to improve Recall@kRecall@kRecall@k is to increase the overlop between the graph-based indexes and the full-kNNs graph and the key issue is how to construct an approximate k-NNs graph that retains more important non-routing edges and utlizes them in the specific search phase. We can leverage the construction log to help us achieve this. During the graph construction process, each base point is repeatedly searched on the graph for its k-NNs. However, the search results are only used for pruning. Instead, we can store the pruned edges of each base point into a conjugate graph to complement the proximity graph.
  Framework: specifically, each base point is searched for its k-NNs during the constrction process. Then we insert pruned edges into the conjugate graph and insert the remaining edges into proximity graph. We use the search log from both generated and historical queries to further improve the conjugate graph. That’s, we connect the local optima with their corresponding global optima in the search log. Then, the proximity graph is used for searching a preliminary result, and the conjugate is used as an enchancement for the result.

  As shown in Algorithm 2, we utlize the conjugate graph to enhance the greedy search process. First, we search the proximity graph for preliminary nearest neighbors and the local optima(line 1-2). Next, we utilize the connections of those local-global optima pairs that are stored in the conjugate graph based on search log. It’s possible to retrieve the global optimum from the neighbors of G′[xl]G^{'}[x_{l}]G′[xl​](line 3). Once we reach the global optima of the query point, we use its neighbor G′[xg]G^{'}[x_{g}]G′[xg​] in the conjugate graph as the complement of the K-NNs(line 4-5).

Opportunities of Enhancement

Observations and Opprotunities

  Theorem IV.1.: Given the query point, it’s accrate k-NNs set NNk(xq)NN_{k}(x_{q})NNk​(xq​) and approximate k-NNs set ANNk(xq)ANN_{k}(x_{q})ANNk​(xq​), we assume xlx_{l}xl​ is the local optimum of approximate k-NNs of query point xqx_{q}xq​. If Recall@k>0Recall@k \gt 0Recall@k>0, we have xl∈NNk(xq)x_{l} \in NN_{k}(x_{q})xl​∈NNk​(xq​)[ 使用反证法证明，见原文 ]
  Opprotunity 1: Local optimum is likely the one of k-NNs of the global optimum. Any query point xqx_{q}xq​ is in the neghborhood of its nearest neighbor xgx_{g}xg​. Since they are both surrounded by the neighbors of xgx_{g}xg​, we have another heuristic: the neighbors of query point xqx_{q}xq​ and the neighbors of its nearest xqx_{q}xq​ are highly overlapping. According to the theorem IV.1, as long as the Recall@k>0Recall@k \gt 0Recall@k>0, the local optimum xlx_{l}xl​ of the search process must be in the accurate k-NNs of the query point xqx_{q}xq​. Combining the heuristic and theorem, we can infer that xl∈NNk(xg)x_{l} \in NN_{k}(x_{g})xl​∈NNk​(xg​) with high probability.
  Opprotunity 2: Similar points may converage to the same local optimum.

Self-Generated Search Log

  In addition to utilizing historical search logs, we can also generate queries using heuristic methods. The search log from these generated queries can also continuously optimize the graph through identifying potential flaws. Thus, we first investigate which types of queries are more likely to encounter graph flaws by Voronoi Dagram.
  Definition 4(Varonoi Diagram): Given a dataset DDD consisting of points in RdR^{d}Rd with d-dimensioal real numbers, the Voronoi cell of any point xg∈Dx_{g} \in Dxg​∈D is represented as VD(xg)={x∈Rd,dis(xg,x)≤dis(xb,x),∀xb∈D}V_{D}(x_{g})=\left \{ x \in R^{d}, dis(x_{g}, x) \le dis(x_{b},x), \forall x_{b} \in D \right \}VD​(xg​)={x∈Rd,dis(xg​,x)≤dis(xb​,x),∀xb​∈D}, where each point xgx_{g}xg​ is noted as a Voronoi site. The set of all Voronoi cells of DDD is its Voronoi dagram VVV or (D)(D)(D).
  According to this definition, each Voronoi cell of VD(xg)V_{D}(x_{g})VD​(xg​) is a subspace in RdR^{d}Rd. Any point that lies within the subspace have xgx_{g}xg​ as its closest Voronoi site. It means that for any query within this cell, its nearest neighbor should be the point xgx_{g}xg​.
  We consider each base point xbx_{b}xb​ in the dataset DDD as a Voronoi site. In a high-dimensional space, each base point and its k-NNs are likely to be locally homogeneous. This means that the cells where the k-NNs are uniformly distributed in various directions of the cell VD(xb)V_{D}(x_{b})VD​(xb​).
  (Heuristic) We use a heuristic to generate query points to detect flaws: points near the boundary between two adjacent Voronoi cells are more likely to encounter flaws. It’s because these points have similar distance to the two Voronoi sites. The base point is guranteed to be adjacent to the two cells belonging to its nearest neighbor. The k-NNs with larger rankings may fail to meet the homogeneity reqiurement.
  (Approximation) To address this problem, our simple approximation is to only consider the k-NNs with similar ranks(i.e., smaller k) for point generation. Simultaneously, this approache avoids comparing with distant neighbors. Under the widely used egde pruning strategies, these’s a high probability to prune the longest edge in any triangle. Thus, in the original proximity graph, the distant neighbors will not have an edge connected to the base point.
  Given the base point xbx_{b}xb​ and its nearest point xk∈NNk(xb)x_{k} \in NN_{k}(x_{b})xk​∈NNk​(xb​), the generated query point is:

xe=w⋅xb+(1−w)⋅xk [EQ1]x_{e} = \mathcal{w} \cdot x_{b} + (1 - \mathcal{w}) \cdot x_{k} \space [EQ1]xe​=w⋅xb​+(1−w)⋅xk​ [EQ1]

where w\mathcal{w}w is a parameter used to control the distance between the generated query point and the base point.
  As shown in Figure 6, the generated query point lies near the perpendicular bisector of the line connecting two base points. To ensure that xe∉VD(xk)x_{e} \notin V_{D}(x_{k})xe​∈/VD​(xk​), we control w>0.5\mathcal{w} \gt 0.5w>0.5. In most cases, we can ensure that xe∈VD(xb)x_{e} \in V_{D}(x_{b})xe​∈VD​(xb​). In other words, given the base point xbx_{b}xb​, we can generate its corresponding error-prone points based on its k-NNs. Further, by searching on the graph, we can obtain a self-generated search logs to enhance the recall for all queries whose global optimum is the given base point.

Log-Based Search Enhancement

Optimization on the Nearest Neighbor Search

  According to Theorem IV.1 and Observation 1-3, we can infer that local optima are likely to be among the k-NNs of a base point. We can then group queries based on the local optima they converage to. Since the number of queries greatly exceeds k, many queries will converage to the same local optimum. This suggests that routing edge from the local optimum to the global optimum is missing. To address this, we can construct a conjugate graph with edges connecting local optima to their corresponding global optima. After the first-stage search concludes, the conjugate graph directs all queries that converaged to local optima towards the global optimum.
  We use two categories of search logs: the self-generated search logs and the historical search logs. Following Theorem IV.1 and observations 1-3, we generate queries for each base node to identify optential flaws. Then, the historical search logs are used to complement queries that their local optima do not belong to their k-NNs. Note that, the global optima of the search log can be obtained through both user complaints and asynchronous computations.
  As shown in Algorithm 3, the first step is to add the historical search log to the experience set EEE(Lines 1-2). The experience set is used to record specific local optima found by greedy search with parameter L2L_{2}L2​ and their corresponding global optima. Note that we emphasized L2L_{2}L2​, which is the search parameters of the log that converage to the local optimum. When the query is performed, the best enhancement with conjugate graph be achieved only when search parameter L=L2L = L_{2}L=L2​. When L≠L2L \neq L_{2}L=L2​, the search process may converage to a different local optimum. Thus, the routing edges in conjugate graph cannot be utilized.
  Then, we use the self-generated method to obtain more local optima. Firstly, we choose to generate queries using kg−NNsk_{g}-NNskg​−NNs of each base point, where %k_{g}% is the parameter to adjust the number of generated queries. Since we can hardly search the accurate kg−NNsk_{g}-NNskg​−NNs for each base node, we use the approximate kg−NNsk_{g}-NNskg​−NNs as replacement(Lines 4-5). It can be quickly obtained by using the construction log stored in the conjugate graph. For each neighbor in kg−NNsk_{g}-NNskg​−NNs, we generate a query point xex_{e}xe​ with Equation 1.
  After generating queries, we perform a greedy search to obtain potential local optimum(Line 7). Since xe∈VD(xb)x_{e} \in V_{D}(x_{b})xe​∈VD​(xb​) and VD(xb)V_{D}(x_{b})VD​(xb​) is surrounded by the Voronoi cell of its k−NNsk-NNsk−NNs, we can quickly obtain an approximation global optimum from these cells(Line 8). Then we add self-generated search lgs to the experience set EEE(Line 7-10). Finally, each element in the experience set EEE is treated as a directed edge and added to the conjugate graph G′′G^{''}G′′(Lines 11-12).

Optimization on k-NNs Search

  Some existing graph-based indexes, approximate RNG or MRNG by adopting the same edge pruning strategies to remove redundant edges. They strive to carefully select edges in the graph index to reduce the number of iterations and shrink the fan out of seach iteration. They use incremental insertion for construction, similar to the Algorithm 4. Initially, a greedy search is performed for each newly insrted point(Lines 1-2). Then, for the vistited list VVV, redundant edges are elimated based on a specific edge pruning strategy(Line 3). For example, the pruning strategies prune the longest edges of all possible triangles(RNG strategy), or ensure that the angle between any two edges is greater than 60 degrees(MRNG strategy). Finally, the remaining edges are insrted into the graph(Lines 4-7).
  During the construction process, approximate k-NNs are found for each base point(Line 2). However, this construction log is not further utilized. Only the pruned set of edges NbN_{b}Nb​ is kept for insertion into the proximity graph(Phase 1). The pruned edges may reduce the navigation efficiency, but they are valuable as non-routing edges. We store them in the conjugate graph G′G^{'}G′(Line 8). Finally, we remove redundant edges that already exist in the proximity graph to improve storage efficiency(Lines 9-10).

Thoughts

  • 一个可以自我增强和修复的图索引方案
  • 如果在此基础上加上对动态增删向量数据的支持又该如何扩展，i.e., 恰好删除的节点就是一些节点的 global optima，那么是否需要寻找新的 global optima 并更新 conjugate graph？

References

  • Source code has been integrated into Ant Group’s open-sourced vector library, VSAG
  • ZHONG X, JIN J, CHENG P, 等. EnhanceGraph: A Continuously Enhanced Graph-based Index for High-dimensional Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search[EB/OL]. arXiv, 2025[2025-07-01]. https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.13144.

entry.title: ACORN, Performant and Predicate-Agnostic Search Over Vector Embeddings and Structured Data
entry.content:
Overview

  In this papaer, we present ACORN, an approach for performant and predicate-agnostic hybrid search. ACORN builds on HNSW, a state-of-the-art graph based approximate nearest neighbor index, and can be implemented effciently by extending existing HNSW libraries. ACORN introduces the idea of predicate subgraph traversal to emulate a theoretically ideal, but impractical, hybrid search strategy. ACORN’s predicate-agnostic construction algorithm is designed to enable this effective search strategy, while supporting a wide array of predicate sets and query semantics.

Deatils

Prelimary Work

Hybrid Search Definitions

  Let D={e1,e2,...,en}={(x1,a1),(x2,a2),...,(xn,an)}D=\left \{ e_{1}, e_{2},...,e_{n} \right \} = \left \{(x_{1},a_{1}),(x_{2},a_{2}),...,(x_{n},a_{n}) \right \}D={e1​,e2​,...,en​}={(x1​,a1​),(x2​,a2​),...,(xn​,an​)} be a dataset consisting of nnn entities, each with a vector componet, xi∈Rdx_{i} \in R^{d}xi​∈Rd, and a structured attribute-tuple, aia_{i}ai​, associated with entity eie_{i}ei​. Let X={x1,x2,...,xn}X = \left \{ x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n} \right \}X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​} denote the set of vectors in dataset, and dist(a,b)dist(a,b)dist(a,b) is the metric distance between any two points. Let A={a1,a2,...,an}A = \left \{ a_{1}, a_{2},...,a_{n} \right \}A={a1​,a2​,...,an​} be the set of structured attribute tuples in the dataset. We will denote Xp⊆XX_{p} \subseteq XXp​⊆X as the subset of vectors corresponding to entities in the dataset that pass a given predicate ppp. We refer to the selectivity(s) of predicate ppp as the fraction of entities from DDD that satisfy the predicate, where 0≤s≤10 \le s \le 10≤s≤1.
  We consider the hybrid search problem, described as follows. Given a dataset DDD, target KKK, and query q=(xq,pq)q=(x_{q},p_{q})q=(xq​,pq​), where xq∈Rdx_{q} \in R^{d}xq​∈Rd, and pqp_{q}pq​ is a predicate, retrieve xqx_{q}xq​'s KKK nearest neighbors that pass the predicate pqp_{q}pq​.

Formalizing Query Correlation

  Qeury correlation occurs when the vectors of XpX_{p}Xp​ are non-uniformly distributed in XXX and instead cluster together relative to the vectors in XXX. We refer to this phenomenon as predicate clustering. When predicate clustering occurs, a query vector may be either close or far away from the predicate cluster containing its search targets, inducing query correlation.
  Definition: Query Correlation: we will consider the query-to-target distances for the given dataset compared to the expected query-to-target distances for a hypothetical dataset, under which no clustering is present. Formally, we define the query correlation of the hybrid search workload QQQ over dataset DDD as:

C(D,Q)=E(xi,pi)∈Q[ERi[g(xi,Ri)]−g(xi,Xpi)]C(D, Q) = \mathbb{E}_{(x_i, p_i) \in Q} \big[ \mathbb{E}_{R_i} \big[ g(x_i, R_i) \big] - g(x_i, X_{p_i}) \big]C(D,Q)=E(xi​,pi​)∈Q​[ERi​​[g(xi​,Ri​)]−g(xi​,Xpi​​)]

  We let RiR_{i}Ri​ be a random set variable of ∣Xpi∣|X_{pi}|∣Xpi​∣ vvectors drawn uniformly from XXX, defined for each hybrid query (xi,pi)∈Q(x_{i},p_{i}) \in Q(xi​,pi​)∈Q. We define g(x,S)=miny∈Sdist(x,y)g(x,S)=min_{y \in S}dist(x,y)g(x,S)=miny∈S​dist(x,y) to be the function mapping the query vector xxx to the minimum distance of a neighbor from the given vector set S⊆RdS \subseteq R^{d}S⊆Rd. Note that g(xi,Xpi)g(x_{i},X_{pi})g(xi​,Xpi​) is the ground-truth hybrid-search target of the query (xi,pi)(x_i,p_i)(xi​,pi​).
  If, on average, query vectors are closer to their targets in XpiX_{pi}Xpi​, the true dataset of hybrid search targets, than in RiR_{i}Ri​, the no-clustering dataset, then the workload has positive query correlation. If the reverse is true, the workload has negative query work correlation.[ post-filtering 在正相关情况下时间复杂度可以认为是O(log(n)+K)O(log(n)+K)O(log(n)+K), 但在负相关情况下会退化到 O(n)O(n)O(n)]

Theoretical Ideal Hybrid Search Performance With HNSW

  For a given hybrid search, we define the theoretically ideal search peformance using HNSW data structures as the performance attainable if we know the search predicate pqp_{q}pq​ during construction. In this case, we could construct an HNSW index over XpX_{p}Xp​. We call this the oracle partition index for that query. The complexity of searching this index is Os(log sn+K)Os(log \space sn+K)Os(log sn+K). Notably, the seach performance of the oracle partition index outperforms both pre- and post-fiiltering across variations in predicate selectivity, data size, and query correlation.[ 最理想的图混合过滤性能与场景！]
  Despite its ideal search performance, the oracle partition index requires us to know all search predicates in advance and to create a full HNSW index for each. In practice, the oracle partition index is not possible to construct because query predicate sets are often unknown during construction and have high or unbounded cardinality. Building an HNSW per predicate would require prohibitive amounts of space and time. Thus, in this work, we will instead approximate search over the oracle partition index for a particular query, without ever explicitly constructing this index.[ 理想情况时间空间开销都很大，且无法提取准确预知所有的查询谓词 ]

ACORN Overview

  We now describe ACORN, a predicate-agnostic approach for state-of-the-art hybrid search. We propose two variants, which we refer to as ACORN-γ and ACORN-1. We design ACORN-γ to achieve efficient search performance, and we design ACORN-1 to approximate ACORN-γ’s search performace while further reducing the algorithm’s time to index(TTI) and space footprint for resource-constrained settings.
  ACORN’s core idea is to search over the index’s predicate subgraph, i.e., the subgraph induced by XpX_pXp​ for a given search predicate ppp. We modify the HNSW construction algorithms so that arbitrary predicate subgraphs emulate an HNSW oracle partition index without the need to explicitly constructe one. ACORN-γ achieves this by constructing a denser version of HNSW, which we parameterize by a neighbor list expansion factor, γ\gammaγ, a compression factor, MβM_{\beta}Mβ​, and the standard HNSW parameters, efcefcefc and MMM. Then by adding a filter step during search to ignore neighbors that fail the predicate, we find ACORN−γACORN-\gammaACORN−γ’s search can efficiently navigate to and traverse over the predicate subgraph, even under variations in query correlation. Meanwhile, ACORN−1ACORN-1ACORN−1 expands neighbor lists during search rather than during construction to approximate ACORN−γACORN-\gammaACORN−γ’s dense graph structure without building it.[ 稠密图 ]
  Overall, ACORN prescribes a simple and general framework for performant hybrid search based on the idea of predicate-subgraph traversal. The core techniqurs we propose are predicate-agnostic neighbor-list expansion and pruning during construction in combination with predicate-based filtering during search. While this framework can be applied to a variety of graph-based ANN indices, in this work we focus on HNSW due their state-of-the-art performance and widespread use.[ 本质上是一个框架 ]

ACORN-γ

Search

  Algorithm 2 outlines the greedy search algorithm ACORN uses at each level, beginning from a pre-defined entry-point at the top-level. The main difference between ACORN’s search algorithm and that of HNSW is how neighbor look-ups(line 9) are performed at each visited node ccc. While HNSW simply checks the neighbor list, Nl(c)N^{l}(c)Nl(c), ACORN performs additiona steps to recouver an approximate neighborhood for the given search predicates.

  Specifically, ACORN-γ uses two neighbor look-up strategies, a simple filter method, shown in Figure 4(a), and a compression-based heuristic, shown in Figure 4(b). which is compatible with the compression strategy we optionally apply during construction. For each visited node, vvv, the filter-based neighbor look-ups simply scan the neighbor list Nl(v)N^{l}(v)Nl(v) to find the sub-list of neighbors that pass the predicate, denoted Npl(v)N^{l}_{p}(v)Npl​(v). If Npl(v)N^{l}_{p}(v)Npl​(v) contains more than MMM nodes, we take the first MMM and return this as vvv’s neighborhood. The compression-based neighbor look-ups instead partially expand the neighbor set Nl(v)N^{l}(v)Nl(v) to include a subset of vvv’s two-hop neighbors, befor performing filtering and truncation. This procedure entails two phases. The first phase iterates through the first MβM_{\beta}Mβ​ nodes of Nl(v)N^{l}(v)Nl(v), simply filtering as in the previous strategy. The second phase iterates over the remainder of the neighbor list, expanding the search neighborhood to include neighbors of neighbors, before again filtering according to the predicate. MβM_{\beta}Mβ​ is a construction parameter which we will discuss later.

construction

  We construct the ACORN-γ index by applying two core modifications to the HNSW indexing algorithm: first, we expand each node’s neighbor list, and then we apply a novel predicate-agnostic pruning method to compress the index. Both of these steps are summarized in Figure 5.

  Neighbor List Expansion: While HNSW collects MMM approximate nearest neighbors as candidate edges for each node in the index, ACORN collects $M \cdot \gamma $ approximate nearest neighbors as candidate edges per node. To find these candidates during construction, ACORN uses a metadata-agnostic search over its graph index. Specifically, the neighbor lookup strategy at each node, vvv, on level lll, simply access the neighbor list Nl(v)N^{l}(v)Nl(v) and returns the first MMM nodes. Note that although each node contains up to $M \cdot \gamma $ neighbors, we assume by construction that MMM neighbors per node are suffcient for maintaining naviganility of the graph index. Thus, considering truncated neighbor lists while traversing the graph allows us to avoid unnecessary distance computations and TTI slowdonws.
  One simple choice for \gamme is $\frac{1}{s_{min}} $, where smins_{min}smin​ is the minimum predicate selectivity we plan to serve before resorting to pre-filtering( γ 越大，索引建立时间越长和空间开销越大). Note that pre-filtering becomes a competitive baseline at low predicate selectivity values, ACORN is able to balance construction and search effciency by using pre-filtering as fall-back for queries with low-selectivity predicates. This leads to a simple cost-based model during search: if the estimated predicate selectivity of a given is greater than 1/γ1 / \gamma1/γ, search the ACORN-γ index, otherwise pre-filter.
  Compression: A key challenge with ACORN-γ’s neighbor expansion step is that it increases index size and TTI, whic poses a significant issue particullay for memory-resident graph indices, like HNSW. To address this, we introduce a predicate-agnostic pruning technique. While we could apply compression to the full index, we specifically target the bottom level’s neighbor list since they contribute most significantly to the indexing overhead.
  The core idea of the pruning procedure is to precisely retain each node’s nearby neighbors in the index, while approximating father away neighbor during search. We use the tunable compression parameter, MβM_{\beta}Mβ​, where 0≤Mβ≤M⋅γ0 \le M_{\beta} \le M \cdot \gamma0≤Mβ​≤M⋅γ. During construction, ACORN choose each node’s final neighbor list by automatically retaining the nearest MβM_{\beta}Mβ​ candidate edges and aggressively pruning the remaining candidates. During search we can recover the first MβM_{\beta}Mβ​ neighbors of each node vvv directly from the neighbor list Nl(v)N^{l}(v)Nl(v), and approximaye remaining neighbors by looking at 2-hop neighbors during search.[ 保留预定数目 + 两跳维持关系 ]
  Figure 5 outlines this pruning procedure applied to node vvv’s candidate neighbor list. The algorithm iterates over the ordered candidate edge list and keeps the first MβM_{\beta}Mβ​ candidates. Over the remaining sub-list of candidates, the algorithm applies the following pruning procedure at each node. Let HHH be the dynamic set of vvv’s chosen two-hop neighbors, initialized to $\emptyset $. We prune candidate ccc id it’s contained in HHH; otherwise, we keep c and add all of its neighbors to HHH. The pruning procedure stops after iterating overl all candidates, or if ∣H∣|H|∣H∣ plus the number of chosen edges exceeds M⋅γM \cdot \gammaM⋅γ. The pruned and ordered neighbor list is stored in the ACORN index and HHH is diacarded.
  We highlight that the neighbor expansion during search can recover pruned neighbors regardless of the query predicate. If follows from ACORN’s pruning rule that any node xxx that was pruned from some node vvv’s neighbor list, Nl(v)N^{l}(v)Nl(v), must be in the neighbor list Nl(y)N^{l}(y)Nl(y) such that yyy is a neighbor of vvv with index greater than MβM_{\beta}Mβ​. During search, the neighbor lookup at vvv on level lll will perform a neighbor-list expansion for all neighbors with an index greater than M_{\bata}, thus checking Nl(y)N^{l}(y)Nl(y) and finding xxx before filtering and truncating.

ACORN-1

  We now descirbe ACORN-1, an alternative approach which aims to approximate ACORN-γ’s search performance, which further minimizing index size and TTI. ACORN-1 achieves this by performing the neighbor expansion step solely during search, rather than during construction, as ACORN-γ does. ACORN-1’s construction corresponfs to the original HNSW index without pruning. This construction corresponds to ACORN-γ’s construction algorithm, with fixed parameters γ=1\gamma = 1γ=1 and M_{\bta} = M.
  ACORN-1’s main difference from ACORN-γ during search, is its neighbor lookup strategy. Specifically, at each visited node, vvv, during greedy search, ACORN-a uses a full neighbor list expansion to consider all one-hop and two-hop neighbors of vvv, before applying the predicate filter and truncating the resulting neighbor list to size MMM.

References

  • source code on Github
  • PATEL L, KRAFT P, GUESTRIN C, 等. ACORN: Performant and Predicate-Agnostic Search Over Vector Embeddings and Structured Data[J]. Proceedings of the ACM on Management of Data, 2024, 2(3): 1-27.

entry.title: UNG, Navigating Lables and Vectors, A Unified Approach to Filtered Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search
entry.content:
Overview

  To tackle the challenges of FANNS, we introduce a novel approach called the Label Navigating Graph, which encodes the containment relationships of label sets for all vectors. Built upon graph-based ANNS methods, we develop a general framework termed Unified Navigating Graph(UNG) to bride the gap between label set containment and vector proximity relations:

  • We introduce the novel concept of the Label Navigating Graph, which serves as a dynamic guiding mechanism to strictly constrain the ANNS exploration within the filtered search space by leveraging the Entry Label Sets retrieved for the query labels
  • We propose a general UNG framework tailored for filtered ANNS, enabling seamless integration of various graph-based ANNS algorithms which gurantees versatility, fidelity, completemess and adaptability
  • By using Vamana as the underlying graph index, we conduct extensive experiments on 10 realworld datasets to compare the UNG framework with state-of-the-art fiiltered ANNS algorithm

Details

  UNG first partitions the dataset according to the label set fif_{i}fi​ associated with each vector viv_{i}vi​, such that the vectors sharing the identical label set fall into the same group. Then, UNG builds a derected acyclic graph named Label Navigating Graph to encode the label set containment relationships, where an edge from label set fff to f′f^{'}f′ indicates that f′f^{'}f′ is the Minimum Superset of fff. To ebale efficient ANNS, for all vectors within the group of each lable set, UNG can integrate existing graph-based ANNS approaches to build a proximity graph. Then Cross-group Edges are added following the direction of edges in LNG, which bridges the gap between vectors from different graphs. It consistutes a Unified Navigating Graph G combining both the LNG and proximity graphs. Given a query vector vqv_{q}vq​ with label set fqf_{q}fq​, by retrieving the Entry Lable Sets which directly cover all lables in fqf_{q}fq​, a greddy search from the entry vectors with such entry label sets delivers the final nearest vectors for vqv_{q}vq​.

Frequently-used Terms

Lable Navigating Graph

  For the query label set fq={l1,l2,...,l∣fq∣}f_{q} = \left \{ l_{1}, l_{2}, ... ,l_{|f_{q}|} \right \}fq​={l1​,l2​,...,l∣fq​∣​}, the filtered vectors VqV_{q}Vq​ satisfy that vi∈Vqv_{i} \in V_{q}vi​∈Vq​ iff fq⊆fif_{q} \subseteq f_{i}fq​⊆fi​. To obtain the filtered label sets defined as Fq={f∈F∣fq⊆f}F_{q} = \left \{ f \in F | f_{q} \subseteq f \right \}Fq​={f∈F∣fq​⊆f}, we follow the intuition that if a label set fff covers all query labels fqf_{q}fq​, any superset of fff also covers fqf_{q}fq​.
  Definition(Minimum Superset): For a label set fff, label set f′∈Ff^{'} \in Ff′∈F is a minimum supersey of fff iff (1) f⊂f′f \subset f^{'}f⊂f′ and (2)∄f′′∈F s.t. f⊂f′′⊂f′\nexists f^{''} \in F \space s.t. \space f \subset f^{''} \subset f^{'}∄f′′∈F s.t. f⊂f′′⊂f′. Naturally, all the minimum superset relations among all label sets in FFF consitute a directed acyclic graph(DAG), referred to as the Label Navigating Graph.
  Definition(Lable Navigating Graph, LNG for short): LNG is a DAG, where each vertex is a label set f∈Ff \in Ff∈F. A directed edge e(f,f′)e(f,f^{'})e(f,f′) from vertex fff to another vertex f′f^{'}f′ exists in LNG iff f′f^{'}f′ is a minimum superset of fff. And we could infer that for any lebel set f∈Ff \in Ff∈F, all its supersets in FFF are its descendants in LNG.
  Definition(Entry Label Sets): For query label sets fqf_{q}fq​, its entry label sets, denoted as F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​, are defined as folows. Given the query label set fqf_{q}fq​, we can first find its entry label sets F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​. Then, without checking all label sets in FFF, the filtered label sets FqF_{q}Fq​ can be dereved from the LNG based on the retrived F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​, which are equal to the entry label set F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​ and all their descendant in LNG.

F^q={{fq},if fq∈F,all the minimum supersets of fq in F,if fq∉F.\hat{F}_q = \begin{cases} \{f_q\}, & \text{if } f_q \in F, \\\text{all the minimum supersets of } f_q \text{ in } F, & \text{if } f_q \notin F.\end{cases}F^q​={{fq​},all the minimum supersets of fq​ in F,​if fq​∈F,if fq​∈/F.​

Unifying Label Navigating Graph and Proximity Graphs

  For each filtered label set f∈Fqf \in F_{q}f∈Fq​, we can find the top-k nearest vectors in the corresponding group VfV_{f}Vf​. Merging the results for all filtered label sets delivers the final top-k vectors in the filtered search space Vq=∪f∈FqVfV_{q} = \cup _{f \in F_{q}}V_{f}Vq​=∪f∈Fq​​Vf​. Specifically, to fine the top-k nearest vectors in each group VfV_{f}Vf​, we consider proximity-graph-based algorithms where each vector usually has a degree bound dmaxd_{max}dmax​.
  However, when there are a large number of filtered label sets FqF_{q}Fq​, conducting ANNS searches on ∣Fq∣|F_{q}|∣Fq​∣ groups separately may still be inefficient. This is because for some groups where most vectors are far away from the query vector vqv_{q}vq​, computing ANNS does not contribute to the final top-k results. Therefore, to dynamilcally avoid iterating over such groups during the search process, we propose the Unified Navigating Graph(UNG) framework described as follows.
   Inspired by ANNS proximity graphs that approache the query vector greedyly through graph traversal, we can also greedily expore a portion of groups that may lead to the final top-k nearest vectors. Specifically, to dynamically navigate the search towards such groups, we first build proximity graphs on vectors of each group VfV_{f}Vf​ separately, and our general idea is to add new edges to bridge the gaps between diaparate groups. Moreover, to avoid visiting any vectors that do not satisfy the filter condition, such new edges must lead to vectors associated with the filtered label set in FqF_{q}Fq​. Reacll that in LNG, if a label set f∈Ff \in Ff∈F satisfies that fq⊆ff_{q} \subseteq ffq​⊆f, then any descendent of fff in LNG also belongs to FqF_{q}Fq​. Thus, we define the concept of cross-group edges.
  Definition(Cross-group Edge): An edge from vector viv_{i}vi​ to vector vjv_{j}vj​ is a cross-group edge if there exists a directed edge from fif_{i}fi​ to fjf_{j}fj​ in LNG. Additionally, we ensure that cross-group edges exist between any groups VfV_{f}Vf​ and Vf′V_{f^{'}}Vf′​ if f′f^{'}f′ is an out-neighbor of fff in LNG.
  Let Gf=(Vf,Ef)G_{f}=(V_{f},E_{f})Gf​=(Vf​,Ef​) denote the proximity graph built for group VfV_{f}Vf​, where EfE_{f}Ef​ is the set of edges in GfG_{f}Gf​. Since we build cross-group edges following the edges in the label navigating graph, the finaly graph unifies both the label navigating graph and the proximity graph. This graph is called the Unified Navigating Graph G=V,EG={V,E}G=V,E, where its edge set EEE consists of both the cross-group edges and the edges EfE_{f}Ef​ within each proximity graph.

Answering Filtered ANNS Queries

  To answer a filtered ANNS query with query label set fqf_{q}fq​, we first retrieve its entry label sets F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​ through the label navigating graph LNG, and then search in the unified navigating graph GGG by starting from entry vectors associated with the label set f∈F^qf \in \hat{F}_{q}f∈F^q​.

Retrieving the Entry Label Sets

  To avoid the high cost of examing a large number of label sets, we use the well-known Trie Tree structure to efficiently retrieve F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​. Without loss of generality, assume that all possible labels L={l0,l1,...,l∣L}\mathcal{L} = \left \{ l_{0}, l_{1}, ... , l_{|\mathcal{L}} \right \}L={l0​,l1​,...,l∣L​} are represented by integers 1,2,...,∣L∣1,2,...,|\mathcal{L}|1,2,...,∣L∣ according to the decreasing order of label frequency freq(li)=∣{f∈F∣li∈f}∣freq(l_{i}) = |\left \{ f \in F | l_{i} \in f \right \} |freq(li​)=∣{f∈F∣li​∈f}∣.
  Definition(Trie tree): Given the label sets FFF for the base dataset with DDD, its trie tree, denoted by TTT, is a tree structure, where each node uuu represents a label l∈Ll \in \mathcal{L}l∈L, except for the root rrr that serves as the entrance. Any child of node uuu correspond to a label larger than the one represent by uuu. And a node uuu is marked as a terminal node iff the path from rrr to uuu constitutes a label set f∈Ff \in Ff∈F. Based on this definition, there are two cases for obtaining F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​:

  • case 1: fq∈Ff_{q} \in Ffq​∈F. Using the trie tree TTT, line 1-5 of Algoritm 1 determine whether fq∈Ff_{q} \in Ffq​∈F. By Definition of “Entry Label set”, it returns F^q={fq}\hat{F}_{q} = \left \{ f_{q} \right \}F^q​={fq​} if fqf_{q}fq​ can be represented by a path from root rrr to a terminal node uuu.
  • case 2: fq∉Ff_{q} \notin Ffq​∈/F. In this case, F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​ should consist of all the minimum suprtset of fqf_{q}fq​ in FFF. In the trie tree TTT, any label set f∈F^qf \in \hat{F}_{q}f∈F^q​ can be represented by a path ppp, which must include nodes covering all the labels in fqf_{q}fq​. Thus, for each label l∈Ll \in \mathcal{L}l∈L, we construct an inverted list \mathbb{I} = \left \{ all \space nodes \space in \space T \space corresponding \space to \space l in the trie tree. Since the largest label lmax∈fql_{max} \in f_{q}lmax​∈fq​ has the smallest frequency, line 8-10 of Algorithm 1 iterate over each node u∈Imaxu \in \mathbb{I}_{max}u∈Imax​ to check whether the path from root rrr to uuu includes all labels of fqf_{q}fq​, using the function EXAMINE(u)EXAMINE(u)EXAMINE(u). Traveling from all such nodes u∈I(lmax)u \in \mathbb{I}(l_{max})u∈I(lmax​) will lead to all supersets of fqf_{q}fq​, i.e., the filtered label sets FqF_{q}Fq​.

Search on UNG

  For the query label set fqf_{q}fq​, the unified navigating graph GGG ensures that if we search from vector viv_{i}vi​ s.t. fq⊆fif_{q} \subseteq f_{i}fq​⊆fi​, then for any vector vjv_{j}vj​ that viv_{i}vi​ can reach in GGG, it also satisfies f_{q} \subsetrq f_{i}. Thus, we only need to start the search from the entry label sets F^q\hat{F}_{q}F^q​ that cover query labels fqf_{q}fq​, then any visited vectors will satisfy the filter condition. Specifically, for each entry label set f∈F^qf \in \hat{F}_{q}f∈F^q​ found by Algorithm 1, Algorithm 2 randomly select σ\sigmaσ entry vectors and pushed them into the priority queue pq. To conduct the best-first search on the unified navigating graph GGG, at each iteration, we pop the nearest unexplored vector viv_{i}vi​ from the pq, and then push all its out-neighbors into pq. In line with existing graph-based ANNS approaches, we set a maximu size limit w>kw \gt kw>k for pq, and line 7 only preserves the nearest vectors in pq. If all vectors in pq have been explored, we terminate the search and the top-k nearest vectors in pq are returned.

Index construction

Constructing the Label Navigating Graph

  Recall that the label navigating graph LNG consists of all minimum superset relations between label sets in FFF. In practice, we simultaneously construct the LNG, the trie TTT and the inverted lists I\mathbb{I}I. For each label set f∈Ff \in Ff∈F, Algorithm extracts its minimum supersets to add edges to LNG in line 4-5. To ensure that all minimum superset can be extracted, we follow the devreasing order of label set size in line 3. Then, line 6 inserts fff into TTT and updates the corresponding inverted lists I\mathcal{I}I

Constructing the Unifed Navigating Graph

  For vectors viv_{i}vi​ and vjv_{j}vj​ in different groups(i.e., fi≠fjf_{i} \neq f_{j}fi​=fj​), we consider building a directed edge from viv_{i}vi​ to vjv_{j}vj​ if there exists a directed edge from fif_{i}fi​ to fjf_{j}fj​ in LNG. However, it’s infeasible to add edges between all pairs of viv_{i}vi​ and vjv_{j}vj​ s.t. fif_{i}fi​ is the minimum supertset of fif_{i}fi​. Thus, to build the desired graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), Algorithm 4 utilizes graph-based ANNS approaches to build the proximity graph GfG_{f}Gf​ for each group VfV_{f}Vf​. Then, by taking each vetor viv_{i}vi​ as the query vector in line 10, in conducts traditional ANNS to find the top−δtop-\deltatop−δ nearest vectors S~vi\tilde{S}_{v_{i}}S~vi​​ among vectors in Ufj is the out-neighbor of fi in LNG VjU_{f_{j}\text{ is the out-neighbor of } f_i \text{ in } \text{LNG }} V_jUfj​ is the out-neighbor of fi​ in LNG ​Vj​. For each vector vj∈S~viv_{j} \in \tilde{S}_{v_{i}}vj​∈S~vi​​, we add a directed edge e(vi,vj)e(v_{i},v_{j})e(vi​,vj​) from viv_{i}vi​ to vjv_{j}vj​ in line 14.
  To inherit all the connections of LNG for ensuring the connectivity of the unified navigating graph GGG, we achieve this goal by ensuring that there are at least δ\deltaδ cross-group edges between any two groups VfV_{f}Vf​ and Vf′V_{f^{'}}Vf′​, provided that f′f^{'}f′ is an out-neighbor of fff in LNG(line 12 in Algorithm 4).

  In Algorithm 4, the ∣F∣|F|∣F∣ proximity graphs are built for all the groups in line 4. Since there are no writing conflicts in the construction process of different graphs, we use a single thread to construct a graph for each group, and the graphs across different groups are construct in parallel. In line 6, we also iterate each (vi,fi)∈D(v_{i},f_{i}) \in D(vi​,fi​)∈D in parallel, during which there are no writing conflicts for lines 12 and 14, as they only write the out-neighbor list for different vectors simulatenously[ 并行加速 ].

Dealing with Data update

  Note that UNG is general framework built on a graph-based ANNS algorithm. Thus, the underlying graph index update mechanism aplies when inserting or deleting vectors in a group VfV_{f}Vf​. Next, we dicuss how to update the trie tree, label navigating graph(LNG), and cross-group edges in the UNG index.
  Insertion: When adding a vector viv_{i}vi​, if its label set fif_{i}fi​ is new, we insert fif_{i}fi​ into the trie tree and update the LNG according to minmum superset relationships between all subsets and the minimum supersets of fif_{i}fi​. If fif_{i}fi​ already exists, there is no need to update the trie tree and the LNG. Then, for each in-neighboring label set f′f^{'}f′ of fif_{i}fi​ in the LNG, the cross0group edges will be rebuilt for all vectors in group Vf′V_{f^{'}}Vf′​. Finally, we create the cross-gruop edges that starts from viv_{i}vi​.
  Deletion: When removing a vector viv_{i}vi​, if no vectors remain with label set fif_{i}fi​, we remove fif_{i}fi​ from the trie tree and then update the LNG similarly. If fif_{i}fi​ is still used, the trietree and the LNG remain unchanged. Then, for each in-neighboring lebel set f′f^{'}f′ of fif_{i}fi​ in the previous LNG, we rebuild cross-group edges for vectors in the group Vf′V_{f^{'}}Vf′​.

Refercnes

  • Source code on Github
  • CAI Y, SHI J, CHEN Y, 等. Navigating Labels and Vectors: A Unified Approach to Filtered Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search[J]. Proceedings of the ACM on Management of Data, 2024, 2(6): 1-27.

entry.title: VecFlow, A High-Performance Vector Data Management System for Filtered-Search on GPUs
entry.content:
Overview

  Modern AI-based applications require ANNS with filtered search. However, indexing and search algorithms with filters on GPUs must be re-designed to achieve high performance potential. We present a new GPU-based indexing and search algorithm called VecFlow(leveraging CAGRA graphs[3]), which applies a hierarchical and divide-and-conquer design of filtered-ANNS for GPUs:

  • a novel label-centric indexing and search algorithm
  • architecture-aware optimizations for VecFlow’s functional modules for supporting both small batch and large batch queries
  • single-label and multi-label query processing

Details

Preliminary and Definition

  Definition 1(Filtered Nearest Neighbor Search): Given a finite data point set XXX of NNN points in a vector space RDR^{D}RD, each data point(a.ka. vector) x∈Xx \in Xx∈X has an associated set of labels LX⊆LL_X \subseteq \mathcal{L}LX​⊆L, where L\mathcal{L}L is a finite set of labels. The goal of filtered-NNS is to answer a given query point q∈RDq \in R^{D}q∈RD with labels Lq⊆LL_{q} \subseteq \mathcal{L}Lq​⊆L by finding the closest point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with LqL_{q}Lq​, i.e., points in XXX that have the label LqL_{q}Lq​ associated with them
  Definition 2(Filtered Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search): The goal of ε−filtered−NNS\varepsilon -filtered-NNSε−filtered−NNS is to design an algorithm that answers a given query point q∈RDq \in R^{D}q∈RD with labels Lq⊆LL_{q} \subseteq \mathcal{L}Lq​⊆L by maximizing the recall of finding the top-k closest points Atopk∈XA_{topk} \in XAtopk​∈X with LqL_{q}Lq​ while minimizing the search time spent to return TtopkT_{topk}Ttopk​
  Definition 3(Specificity Definition): a property that measures the fraction of data points in XXX that have the label l∈Ll \in \mathcal{L}l∈L associated with them:

specifity(l)=number of datapoints with label ltotal number of data points Nspecifity(l) = \frac{number \space of \space data points \space with \space label \space l}{total \space number \space of \space data \space points \space N}specifity(l)=total number of data points Nnumber of datapoints with label l​

  Based on it, we further classify a label as:

  • High-specificity(HS): specifity(l)≥T/Nspecifity(l) \ge T/Nspecifity(l)≥T/N
  • Low-specificity(LS): specifity(l)<T/Nspecifity(l) \lt T/Nspecifity(l)<T/N
      where T is a chosen threshold. A data point xxx therefore can also be categorized according to its lables:
  • High-specifity data: xxx has at least one high-specificity label
  • low-specificity data: xxx has at least one low-specificity label
      There has been several recent works on filtered-ANNS which can be categorized into three major types:
  1. Ad-hoc methods integrate filtering through pre-/post-processing or inline filtering on top of existing ANNS systems(i.e., FAISS-IVF, Weaviate, Milvus, pgvector, PASE, ADBV, SingleStore-V)
  2. Specialized Index Methods: take Filtered-DiskANN as an example, it builds a specialized filtered-ANNS index that achieves excellent results by building filtered search on top on Vamana graph-based ANNS solution DiskANN.
    3.Label-Centric IVF: more recently, IVF-2 inreoduces a label-centric IVF-based method that wins the NeurIPS’23 Big-ANN competitionFilter Track

Overview

  Following figure shows the overview of VecFlow’s design that adopts a label-centric IVF design to improve the selectivity of ANNS with filters, where data points are grouped based on shared labels instead of spatial proximity or distance. We also design a dual-structured index along with tailored search algorithms for the two groups, maximizing GPU utilization to enable fast and accurate filtered-ANNS.
  In addition, VecFlow designs high performance GPU kernels to achieve (1) redundancy-bypassing IVF-Graph that reduces memory usage by avoiding redundant vector replication, (2) interleaved-scan-based IVFBFS that maximizes GPU memory bandwidth efficiency for brute-force distance computations, and (3) persistent kernels for streaming small batches that eliminate kernal launch overhead and maintain high GPU utilization.

Dual-Structured Label-Centric IVF

  In tradictional IVF methods, vectors are clustered based on their distance to the cluster centroids(typically using k-means clustering), creating “inverted lists” where the cluster centroid becomes the keyword and the posting list comprises all vectors in the corresponding cluster. During a search, the system first identifies the most promising clusters by comparing the query vector with centroids, then performs exact searches only within those selected posting lists. In contrast to traditional IVF, one can construct an inverted index where the keyword is the label, and the posting list contains vectors that share the same label. This label-centric IVF knows exactly which posting list to search for each query based on its lables, eliminating the cluster selection overhead.
  We introduce a dual-structured label-centric IVF that leverages the high computational throughput and parallelism of GPUs high-performance filtered-ANNS. VecFlow adopts a label-centric IVF design to improve the selectivity of ANNS with filters, because a query only needs to search the posting list that has the query’s label. In additio, we define label specificity, a metric for quantifying the density of a given label in a dataset, and we divide the IVF posting lists into distincy groups, each with its own characteristics of label distribution. VecFlow employs a dual-structured index and search algorithms to achieve fast and accurate filtered ANNS. For each group, we design high-performance GPU kernel optimizations to maximize GPU resource utilization.
  Specifically, for each label l∈Ll \in \mathcal{L}l∈L, we define Cl={i∣l∈LXi,0≤i≤∣x∣}C_{l}=\left \{ i|l \in L_{X_{i}}, 0 \le i \le |x| \right \}Cl​={i∣l∈LXi​​,0≤i≤∣x∣}, which stores the global indices of points in XXX associated with label lll. Using ClC_{l}Cl​, we can efficiently retrieve the actual vectors for label lll as Xl={Xi∣i∈Cl}X_{l} = \left \{ X_{i}|i \in C_{l} \right \}Xl​={Xi​∣i∈Cl​} without canning the entire data point set. Once we build the Label-Centric IVF, we divide the posting lists into groups: the high-specificity group(HS) and the low-specificity group(LS), and develop a dual-structured index construction and search algorithm to enable efficient filtered-ANNS for both HS and LS.
  For the HS patition, we build a separate GPU-friendly graph index(e.g., CAGRA) over an individual posting list Cl(IVF−Graph)C_{l} (IVF-Graph)Cl​(IVF−Graph) that avoids an exhuastive search within a posting list while taking advantage of the hardware-friendly GPU-based ANNS solution. For the LS partition, we directly resort to brute force search(IVF-BFS, more easily parallelized to efficiently leverage modern GPUs. And the distance computation between a query and a set of vctors can be efficiently formulated as batched matrix-vector multiplication(GrMV) operation, which can be tailed across Streaming Multiprocessors(SMs) on a GPU)
  During the search, whether a query searches the HS or LS partition is determined by the specificity threshold TTT. Given a query with label lll, we route the query based on the size of its corresponding clstuer ∣Cl∣|C_{l}|∣Cl​∣: if ∣Cl<T|C_{l} \lt T∣Cl​<T then IVF-BFS; otherwise, IVF-Graph.

Index and Search Strategies of VecFlow on GPUs

Bottom-level IVF-Graph with Redundancy-Bypassing for HS

  Indexig: While combinding IVF with graphs significantly improves the search speed, build an individual graph for each IVF list leads to one major challenge - the memory consumption becomes much higher compared to a single index for all data points, beacause some vector will be duplicated stored when its corresponding data point XiX_{i}Xi​ belongs to multiple labels. To address the redundancy issue, we propose an approache called IVF-Graph with Redundancy-Bypassing. For each label lll, VecFlow builds a local virtual graph GlG_{l}Gl​, where each virtal graph only contains the graph structure information expressed via local vertex IDs. Alongside these graphs, VecFlow has a single global vectors XXX that contains all data points. In addition, VecFlow maintains a local-global index mapping table MHSM_{HS}MHS​ that translates these local vertex IDs(within each GlG_{l}Gl​) to their corresponding global indices in the global vectors. This mapping mechanism allos VecFlow to maintain only a single copy of data point set while having multiple virtual graphs to share the same global vectors. Besides, we design a readily integrable and GPU-efficien index structure that compact all virtual graphs into a single, continuous memory space, organized by and ordered by their label lll. This compacted structure not only avoids the overhead of switching between indices but aso represents multiple virtual graphs as a unified structure.

  To make this structure functional, VecFlow maintains three key metadata components:(1) Label Size SHSS_{HS}SHS​: the number of data points in each posting list ClC_{l}Cl​, (2) Label Offsets OHSO_{HS}OHS​: the starting position of label’s virtual graph GlG_{l}Gl​ within the compacted Label Graphs GHSG_{HS}GHS​, which together help VecFlow efficiently locate GlG_{l}Gl​, and (3) Index Mapping MHSM_{HS}MHS​: which translates local vertex IDs in GlG_{l}Gl​ to their global indices in XXX. As shown in Algorithm 1, to manage labels, VecFlow’s indexing follows a two-pass process: first, VecFlow collects all data points’ indices associated with each label lll into posting list ClC_{l}Cl​. Then, VecFlow builds separate virtual graphs for each high-specificity label while establishing meatadata for each label that includes size, offset, and mapping information. This approach allows VecFlow index to construct multiple virtual graphs into a compacted Label Graphs GHSG_{HS}GHS​ referencing a single global vectors XXX, thereby reducing memory consumption while preserving search efficiency.
  Search: For queries with high-specificity labels, VecFlow routes the query to the HS partition and performs the graph-based search in the posting lists that have the query’s labels. VecFlow uses the same elemental technologies from CAGRA to boost the GPU utilization for the graph traversal on GPUs, including (1) warp spliting that divides a warp into fine-grained thread groups(a.k.a, teams) to allow all threads within each warp to maximize the bandwidth utilization through 128-bit load instructions, (2) single warp-level bitonic sort to quickly sort the priority queue in the registers of a single warpm without the shared memory footprint, and (3) the forgettable hash table management to keep the hash table in the fast shared memory for managing the vistied node list

Bottom-Level GPU-Friendly Brute Force Search for LS

  While BFS for LS is conceptually straightforward, requiring only target vectors and query vectors, performing BFS on GPUs presents challenges, especially when prcessing multiple queries in parallel, as each query in the batch must search different parts of the dataset based on its labels. Unlike cuVS brute-force search methods, VecFlow introduces an interleaved scan based IVF-BFS method for low-specificity data. This methods is built on top of cuVs IVF-Flat. During the index construction phase, VecFlow employs an interleaved memory layout where vectors within each posting list of IVF are organized into blocks of interleaved components to enable efficient memory access atterns in two ways. First, when 32 threads in a warp process different vectors simultaneously, they access contiguous memory locations, allowing the GPU to coalesce these accesses into fewer memory transactions. Second, each thread can use wide load instructions(L.D.E. 128) to fetch 16 bytes at once, as the components for each vector are stored in chunks sized according to veclen.

  For the search process, VecFlow uses ivfflat_interleaved_scankernel by cuVS which achieves high throughput through hierarchical parallelism and efficient distance computation. At the grid level, each CUDA block processes one query that searches inside its corresponding label-specific posting list from the IVF index. Within each block, the query vector is first loaded into shared memory for fast access by all threads. The block then processes vectors in its assigned posting list through coordinated warp execution. Each warp rocesses one group of 32 interleaved vectors. Within a warp, each thread computes the distance between one vector from the current group and the shared query vector. Another important step during the brute force search is to filter out the top-k candidates. The kernel fuses an optimized blobk-select-k operation into the distance computation to identify nearest neighbors efficently.[ blocks can independently process different query-label pairs, while warps provide efficient parallel distance computation and sorting within each cluster]

Persistent Kernel-based Search for Small Batch Queries

  Since all queries within a batch are independent, VecFlow uses a single-kernel implementation for handling batched queries but use an individual CUDA thread-block(single-CTA) within a kernel to handle large batch sizes. Overall, when the batch size is large(e.g., >100\gt 100>100), each query is mapped to a single thread block, and multiple of these blocks are executed in parallel.
  In practice, vector search services often execute queries in small batches and maintain low latency. However, traditional GPU-based methods like CAGRA are optimized for large batches and suffer from high overhead when processing small batches due to repeated kernel launching overhead. To address this, VecFlow introduces a persistent kernel on the GPU to process queries are they arrive, which not only eliminates the repeated kernel launch overhead but also avoid synchronization at all costs by using atomic-based control structures. We use a job queue system with atomic ring buffers to manage incoming queries and a worker queue to track available GPU thread blocks. When a query arrives, it is assigned a job ID and mapped to an available worker. The persistent kernel continuously monitors for new work, with each thread block handling one query independently.

Multi-Label Query Processing with Predicate Filtering and Early Stopping

  In practice, one query is often associated with multiple label and VecFlow handles it through GPU parallelism, where each thread block processes one query label.

Handling OR Operations

  For multi-label query connected by OR operations, we can simply convert it into single-label search problem, treating each label as a separate search request and launch multiple standard single-label searches in parallel, using IVF-Graph search for high-specificity labels and IVF-BFS for low-specificity labels, followed by merging results to find the nearest neighbors that statisfy any of the query labels.

Handling AND Operations

  Our key insight to support efficient AND operations is that it’s not necessary to check all paths to identify candidates that satisfy A AND B. Instead, we develop a predicate function that efficiently verifies whether a point contains all specified labels and uses this predicate function to obtain a selective early-stopping search strategies for both HS and LS partition to handle AND queries effciently.
  Predicate function for efficient multi-label verification: To efficiently verify whether a data point contains all specified labels, we use a compact data structure based on three arrays: a global label array, a label offset array, and a label size array. The global label array stores the label of all data points sequentially, keeping each data point’s labels contiguous and sorted. The label offset array marks where each point’s labels begin in the global array, and the label size array records how many labels each point has.
  Further more, our array-based approach stores only the actual labels each point has, reducing memory fragmentation and enabling efficient GPU parallel processing through a compact, contiguous memory layout. For each data point, we employ a binary search algorithm to retrieve its portition of labels from the global array. For queries with multiple labels, we optimize the search process by first sorting the query labels. It then searches from the smallest and largest query labels to establish the valid range that must contain all other query labels.
  IVF-Graph AND search for HS: For queries with multiple labels connected by AND operations in the high-specificity partition, we develop a greedy search policy that combines IVF list selection with inline-processing during graph traversal. The key idea is to minimize the search space while maintaining high accuracy through two main component. Our search space selection is straightforward: given a query with multiple labels connected by AND operations, the search selects the IVF list corresponding to the label with the lowest specificity. For each iteration of graph traversal, we employ the inline-processing approach that interagtes label verification directly into the search process. After computing distances at each graph expansion iteration, we apply our predicate function to check whether candidate points contain all the rest higher-specificity labels from the query. Points that fails this verification step are removed from consideration before the next iteration begins.
  If very high accuracy is desired, we also provide a full parallel search policy for handling AND queries in the HS partition. This approach converts AND queries into single-label search problems, similar to what we do for OR operators, but incorporates inline processing with our predicate function. Instead of starting from the IVF list with the lowest specificity, we launch parallel searches in each label’s IVF list. Each search applies the predicate function during graph traversal to verify if points contain all other labels in the query(寻找 A AND B,A里面过滤B，B里面过滤A). Each search is executed by a dedicated CTA. After all CTAs complete their searches, the finaly results are obtained by merging the top-K candidates from all parallel searches.
  IVF-BFS AND search for LS: For queries with multiple labels connected by AND operations in the low-specificity partition, we select the IVF list corresponding to the label with the lowest specificity. Before performing a brute-force search within the selected IVF list, we apply our predicate function to verify whether each point satisfies all query labels which eliminates unnecessary distance computations for points that do not meet all label constranis.

References

  1. Source Code on Github
  2. XI J, MO C, KARSIN B, 等. VecFlow: A High-Performance Vector Data Management System for Filtered-Search on GPUs[EB/OL]. (2025). https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.00812.
